question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed listening to Professor Lubiano's lectures—she is one of the most intelligent and well-spoken professors I've ever met—and has a profound ability to integrate the theory and literature we encounter in class. I also appreciated how she elevated "colloquial" knowledge to the level of the academy (asking us, for example, to include hypertext and internet sources within our final paper, or bringing up the example of the online forum on dragons). This is something I haven't seen any other professor do before, and as someone who has a few reservations about the nature of literature and the academy, something I didn't take for granted. Additionally, I enjoyed the format of having one or two students come up with discussion questions for each work we talked about in class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This was an extremely tedious course, but the work was minimal (3 short essays and one longer final paper). Professor Lubiano is very intelligent but often struggles with conveying information, so her lectures are quite disjointed and convoluted. Many times, she would leave no room for students to speak during the entire 2.5-hour class. There was a lot of assigned reading, but, as stated, we rarely discussed them and were instead lectured at about them for 2.5 hours. And, as the lectures were so hard to follow anyway, it felt like doing the readings was pointless. If you’re looking to learn something about literature, look elsewhere. There are many other excellent professors in the English department with significantly more engaging methods of instruction.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Yoo encouraged pair shares where students were allowed to talk with their partners about discussion questions. I liked how we had the option to write or send in questions beforehand, and I also like how we were able to talk in smaller groups before sharing to the whole class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Great course to take for T-Reqs, I learned a lot about not just Asian American history, but why Asian American as a term exists in the first place--it's a term that homogenizes Asians, and yet it's a ubiquitous term because of how similar and interconnected the histories of immigration to the US from each Asian country and the experience of Asian American immigrants are. Very insightful course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned how to apply aspects of postcolonial theory to analyze the meaning behind different post-9/11 novels. This involved learning about how the cold war fed into modern US foreign policy decision making, and the role of imperialism.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think one of the most important skills I have developed and improved on is my ability to step out of my comfort zone and be more empathetic to opinions different than my own. Additionally I learned how to critically analyze a text a discuss over it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Theoretical approaches to ideas surrounding conflict, in-depth analysis of how post 9/11 media connects to the event itself, gained insight on how surveillance states and their contribution to community divisions

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have never taken a literature class before so I have never had to take a novel and connect it with global issues. I learned how to take how the novel was written and what happened in the novel and connect it with why the novel was written.!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Thi course was very eye opening to me; it taught me to approach 9/11 from a global perspective, introducing me to the historical background that led to its occurrence which are often ignored and concealed in the American retelling of 9/11. It pushed me to interact with a variety of texts, from essays of post-colonial scholars, to novels.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned about how 9/11 is situated in the larger context of the global cold war.
I got to connect primary sources in the Rubenstein to themes we discussed in class (e.g. regarding representation, and humanitarian incarceration).
I learned about how the geography of Afghanistan made it particularly unique in setting up the country for certain historical events to occur within it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to read 9/11 through legacies of colonialism and empires. I developed insights into the aesthetics of violence. I also learned about the forever wars in Afghanistan.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course was a great introduction into understanding film on a more technical level! We began with elements of movies like mise-en scene and cinematography and worked our way into more specific details like acting and sound design. This course has fundamentally changed the way I think about movies and made them so much more fun to watch! For example, for the film Punch Drunk Love, before this course, I would have seen it simply as a quirky and confusing romcom. However, after paying attention to things like cinematography, shot composition, the use of a telephoto lens, etc. it took on a whole new meaning and became so much more engaging to watch. Really grateful for this course helping me to put general intuition about a film into clear meaning and technical wording!One of my favorite things we learned about this semester was looking at the evolution and history of film. The course itself follows this progression in the movies we watch. It was really cool to watch clips of earlier work and inspiration for a certain film and then watch the film itself. This gave us a great perspective on where some of these creative and innovative ideas in cinema came from.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the formal elements of film, such as cinematography and mise-en-scene; I also learned to think critically about sound design and the role of directors and actors; and I learned to write formal analyses of films.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned new ways to analyze films, different things to look for when watching films, and a newfound respect for filmmaking as a whole.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Cason is an extremely knowledgable professor who clearly cares a lot about his students! question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

Some of the films required more thought and engagement, and the pre-screening content helped students prepare and be engaged.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Please take this course to fulfill the ALP Trinity requirement! question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

It will be a wonderful choice if you are seeking to get credits for humanities/art classes.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Ferraro and Joel did an excellent job of facilitating my learning throughout this course. I appreciated the class group discussions as well as how productive one-on-one conversations were. Going through poems, especially at our own pace, and encouraging students to read helped me connect to the content. I wouldn't change anything about the course for future years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved the question-based discussion format of the class and the three-essay structure. I loved that the essay prompts were a jumping-off point rather than a rigid template. I loved that the professor made connections to our own lives through stories in an effort to make difficult texts and ideas make sense. I also think the TA, Joelle, was absolutely fantastic and incredibly helpful!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Class discussions were very engaging and made it easy to literary analysis as a group. Think sometimes the conversation got a little too elevated/far off topic.

response_text: The instructors were engaging with students, always asked thoughtful questions, and kept the discussion interesting. They should keep up the engaging and thoughtful discussion, leaving the discussion open to students, and keep the engaging literary works.

We would always pull ideas from outside the text while connecting them to it, which helped us view the work more abstractly. This allowed me to develop critical thinking skills and develop new skills when approaching texts.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Professor Ferraro is a wonderful teacher, engager, intellectual. I would've wanted to hear more from Joelle Troiano, another accomplished and talented presence in the class, and have her lead a couple of classes.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Professor Ferraro made this class very stimulating and interesting. He continually presented ways of looking at things that we as a class hadn't considered.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you're thinking about taking any English class, take it with Professor Ferraro!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a course that anyone, no matter their interest in English, should take. Be prepared for Professor Ferraro's passionate rants and tangents — there are always gems in what he says.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You will talk about English in a way you have never before.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Ferraro is the best professor at Duke and one of the smartest, most incredible teachers I have ever had. This class made me fall in love with reading and writing again and I looked forward to it every time.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Very fun course, would definitely recommend taking it as an introduction to Duke English.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Great professor. Super engaged and very VERY VERY knowledgable. Sometime slightly tricky to follow, but very interesting.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would encourage you to take a class with Professor Ferraro during your time at Duke, especially this course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared for a new approach to reading which will have a permanent effect on how you view literature in the future.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Go in with an open mind, enjoy the process of learning because what is what you are here for, to be surprised

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Highly recommend. Fair amount of work and not too much reading, but requires you engage fully.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
reading and writing critically
importance of the structure of arguments
stylistic imitations

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to apply critical literary theory to reading texts; understanding how literary devices can be utilized differently in narratives; how to structure an essay

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I improved my ability to critically analyze classic novels and literature, improved my writing ability and skill of framing arguments within an essay structure.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In general, we learned how to critically engage with literature and develop frameworks to track the plot, characters, and themes. In terms of writing, we learned the basics of how to write a literary critical paper, in addition to practicing imitating different authors' styles and unique voices.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Better analyze literature (story structure, literary elements, etc), better understand selected readings and literature as a whole from critical essays, how to write critical essays.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to pick up various little things that create an author's unique style of writing for their books. I also learned new aspects of reading such as what makes up free indirect discourse in books. And I learned how to think of new ways when discussing books in terms of plot and any themes an author way trying to convey.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze novels way more deeply than I could prior to the course. I learned about different types of narrations, sentence structures, how to make people feel certain emotions through wriitng, and much more. I think I became a significantly better reader and now think about the book and its writing and what the author is trying to do in many more layers than before.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: class was discussion-based which was really helpful and books were all very interesting. discussion led class

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I would keep the wide selection of books and the discussion-centric nature of the course. I found the reading questions helpful in structuring my reflections on the texts before each lesson.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This was potentially my favorite class I have taken at Duke, which I did not expect WHATSOEVER from fulfilling a random writing requirement for GenEd. The novels we read were spectacular, the discussions in class were amazing, and I often found myself using the work for this class as a way to procrastinate other work for other classes (because it was ENJOYABLE and FUN). I feel like we broke down several novels in this class in ways I had never done before and only wish that we had read more (though this class already has a massive reading requirement so this is not saying add more to this, I just wish I could be a part of this class as an extracurricular every year i'd been in college). Professor Mitchell is SPECTACULAR and I plan to go out of my way to hopefully continue interacting with him in the future.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Mitchell was always very approachable and willing to provide feedback on written pieces. During in-class discussions, Professor Mitchell was highly engaging; in addition to discussing the books we were working on, we would also break into small groups. This kept in-class sessions fun and engaging.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: There are reading questions due every class to help you keep up with the book (completion/best effort grade), optional smaller writing assignments to help understand how to write, very detailed essay prompts, many opportunities to ask questions about the readings or topics. Very discussion-based course but open and friendly environment. Many options to rewrite writing assignments for a better grade.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think having the reading questions for each portion of each book that we talked about helped to facilitate my learning, it helped me think about the books I read on a deeper level and helped me get ready for each session for this class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved the learning environment of this class. It was discussion based and the professor is super engaging. I thought the questions he asked were phenomenal and really enhanced my learning. I liked all the assignments and thought they tied in very well to the course and what we were learning.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: the books were all very interesting and the topics we discussed in class were also all interesting, we each had our own interpretations of the book and reading questions were very helpful to guide the readings

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I would have liked to read a wider range of literary critical theory as those essays often contained insights that I would not have arrived at independently. Unfortunately, this is an English 101 course, so I understand if there are limitations to doing so.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Professor Mitchell made this class extremely intellectually stimulating and I have been much more excited to actually do the assignments for this class than I have been in the last four years I've been at Duke. The discussions in class were PHENOMENAL (especially around Germinal and Never Let Me Go, in my opinion, but maybe that is just because they were my two favorites. Woolf was also great but I was less engaged in that novel due to personal time constraints). I loved how this novel has shifted the way I analyze and think about classic novels, a genre I already adored.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I appreciate how the assigned novels were each different in their own right. Each novel felt new and exciting, yet I could also see how their themes all tied together. If the class size permits, I think it could be fun to have each student "adopt" one of the novels and be assigned a short presentation on their assigned book to ensure that each student deeply engages with at least one of the novels.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Relaxed and open environment to engage in reading. Allows you to understand literature in a deeper way. You also have a lot of freedom to interpret the book how you see it. Very fun and engaging lectures. A very well-paced schedule and workload. Reading questions due every lecture (best effort/completion), 3 required smaller writing assignments (1~2 paragraphs), 2 longer critical essays (one due middle of semester and one due end of semester). There are rewrites available to improve your grade.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Hearing what other students thought about the books I was reading made this class stimulating as well as the professor's insights.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The professor! He is so passionate about writing and reading, it's beautiful. He asks thought-provoking questions and instead of just lecturing us on what he thinks is correct (which for interpreting novels is subjective), he is involved in the discussion and also learning with us.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: reading and discussion based class, requires you to think critically about given books and topics. doing the required readings and coming with questions/things you want to discuss will be helpful

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Professor Mitchell is a good professor - knows his stuff, engages with students' perspectives, and gives thoughtful comments on work. The class is not particularly difficult but interesting if you are into developing core literary analysis skills.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The more effort you put in, the more you will get out of the course. As one of the classes I put the most effort into this semester, I can fully say it is one of the classes that has made my Duke experience worthwhile.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is a lot of fun if you enjoy reading and critically analyzing literature. In full transparency there is a lot of reading involved–I believe we read 6 or 7 novels by the end of the semester, but it's definitely rewarding!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take it!! You will definitely enjoy it if you love reading. If you do not enjoy reading/think you are too busy for it (like I was), you will still really enjoy the class. The literary concepts you learn are very digestible, easy to understand (nothing overly-complex), and lots of time devoted to teaching them. Professor Mitchell is so engaging and fun, wants to see you do your best. He is happy to explain the concept/novel until you understand and will offer lots of feedback and rewrites (guaranteed A with good effort). I think this class might change your mind on reading and/or give you a chill class (ALP) to enjoy good books.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be aware of how much reading this course has before taking it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you hate reading or are not open to books of different genres and writing styles than what you're used to, do not take this course. It will definitely push you with the types of writing you encounter but it is an amazing course and you will learn so much about novel analysis and narration!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about reading thoughtfully and analytical, and my writing and even thinking improved a lot during this class. Throughout the three essays we wrote, my ability to convey my thoughts fully through writing really improved with the help of Professor Ferraro and Samara.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to read more closely and better question my initial assumptions about a text. I also feel that I generally improved my creative writing skills

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1 - I learned how to critically understand how Author's convey messages and themes and plots.
2 - I learned how to write with nuance to understand the "both/and" rather than the "either/or"
3 - I learned how to read poetry without overanalyzing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I was really engaged in all of the readings. Ferraro helped me think critically about various pieces of literature and analyze them far beneath the surface.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to discuss in a larger group in ways that were a lot more abstract and creative than is expected in other classes. I learned how to talk about books and explore themes in my essays more for the sake of the actual exploration process—going down different rabbit holes and digging out different concepts—rather than for the sake of coming to a concrete point at the end. I also learned how to make my essays more concise, although that is something I am still working on for sure.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Sharpened skills in close reading and communication. Learned to articulate ideas and themes in literature. Learned to connect pieces of literature.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think critically about the text that I read. I also learned how to take in multiple interpretations of the text that I learned and not to "kill a poem." I also learned what to think about while reading a text.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. To speak confidently 
2.To speak up
3. To think critically about poetry

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to engage in discussions about the books we were reading at a college level, leave room for uncertainty and further exploration in my essays, and enjoy class again

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to write analytical essays about books, talk about and analyze poetry, and write essays about poems

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to read analytically and pick up on word level choices and connections, make connections between a range of different texts with real world/contemporary/personal issues (i.e. make the text accessible), write about prose and poetry in a direct manner.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to deliver my participation with Marilyn Monrovian skill. I had wonderful debates with my peers—TF fosters a class camaraderie with impeccable finesse. The class improved my critical reading abilities.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Close readings skills, integrating interdisciplinary sources in my writing.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Ferraro is a very passionate teacher, but would sometimes dominate discussions if students were too shy or not quick enough with responses or insights. There would often be times were he was asking very leading questions instead allowing for a more open discussion, however this improved some over the course of the semester.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the open discussion format of the class and splitting the course into main 3 essays.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that the discussion format was a good way to learn about books and reading.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This class was really fun honestly. Ferraro is hilarious and I always looked forward to our classes -- they were so entertaining. Our class discussions were good, but Ferraro's teaching style is unfortunately not the most conducive to class discussions (which I hate to say because I think he's so great).

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that the overall approachable feeling in our classroom and the way that we are not expected to come up with a "right answer," just an answer, helped discussions to feel more free. There wasn't a limit on what we could explore, and I thought that was really refreshing.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Ferraro's way of conducting the class facilitated a positive learning environment. The classes are just discussions of the books and readings, but often go into much deeper topics or include aspects of current events and history.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I definitely loved the discussion styles of the text a lot! The way we would talk about the text and then at the end of class the main ideas from Professor Ferraro were discussed. I really loved that.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked how the class was small and we read just the right amount of books (not too many or too little). I also liked how there are 3 main papers.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: At the beginning, Professor Ferarro provided more guidance and structure about the way the discussion should go and book should be thought about. Gradually, Professor Ferraro gave us less structure and framework to work with, which I appreciated and think generated more organic conversations. I also like the diagnostic writing pieces we did at the beginning of the year.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the conversations we had in class - they were very engaging.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Ferraro often facilitated open discussion with the class, inviting student to call out their thoughts, challenge each other, and challenge him. I really liked this structure because it felt more casual yet more productive in creating an environment where people freely voiced their opinions and engaged with each other.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: TF is the diadem on the forehead of the English Department. His energy is unmatched. He engages and entertains. Mediterranean thought theater with jazz inflection. Don’t miss a minute. The laughs are on tap. Still, you will walk away feeling older and wiser, like you really learned something about the world, and today that’s got to be worth something.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Ferraro encouraged us to look for underlying themes in the books we read that I otherwise wouldn't have picked up on, such as the homoerotic undertones in Billy Budd. I also liked that the prompts weren't restrictive and that we could write about topics we were interested in.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The works we read and the discussions we had made the class very intellectually stimulating, Professor Ferraro pushed us to explore new ideas and analyze parts of the novels we read.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The challenge of analyzing nuance and having nuanced analysis in doing so was very intellectually stimulating and forced me to look at questions and problems from a variety of perspectives.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was very stimulating I just think that if we could have more open discussion with each other (without interruption) we could be more engaged.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I really liked the variety of books/stories/poems we read, and I think that made it very stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Ferraro made this class stimulating, period. From the first day, he makes it clear that this class won't fall into the habits of your usual Duke class. He encourages students to be outspoken and contrary. The conversations in class are quick and clever, and many of Ferraro's comments go above students' heads or require further explanation. I felt more stimulated in this class than in nearly every other class at Duke due to the fast-paced nature.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The different ways to interpret text and reading really opened new ideas to me and made this class stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: We talked about real-world topics and the course was discussion-based. Could have been more intellectually stimulating if we delved more into analysis on symbolism or interpretation. We often talked more about details and facts rather than analysis, which would have been more insightful.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The books we read and the knowledge that Professor Ferarro has on these texts made the class incredibly stimulating

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Prof. Ferraro offers a constant stream of insights, comedy, historical tidbits, and theatrical commentary in his instruction of the class's texts. I found myself excited to come to class and have my perspective changed or opened on whatever we were reading and its modern implications. You never knew where the class was going each day, and it highly intellectually stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The essays encourage self-exploration and creativity. This is intellectually rewarding.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Ferraro made the class stimulating by the nature of his being. There is no way you could be bored in the class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This was my favorite class this semester, probably one of my favorites that I've ever taken!! If you don't like to read, don't take this class. The readings were manageable, but some of the assigned chunks were pretty long. Also, Professor Ferraro is very extroverted, passionate, and not afraid to push his students out of their comfort zones in discussion. You need to be able to be bold in discussion and can't be afraid to respond to questions that have the rest of the class in silence. He is also a very realistic grader, you won't get an A+ just for writing a "good" paper. He is of the mindset that grades don't define us and shouldn't matter, but for many people they do matter a lot so if you're looking for an easy A+ this probably isn't it. He does give only within the B+ to A+ range, and he is very effort and improvement conscious.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Professor Ferraro is one of a kind, and it is worth taking this course if you are interested in reading and literature.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared to analyze a lot of things multi-dimensionally. You cannot write an argument, you must write everything very objectively from all perspectives imaginable. Also, do the reading if you want to keep up at all.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you want to take an English class, definitely take this one. It is fun and not very difficult but very thought provoking. It's a very atypical class setup though so you have to be open-minded.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would advise them to push themselves to jump into discussion. Although it might feel at times like there is a right answer to these books, there really is not, and so there is no harm in speaking up.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: For a first English class, it is a challenging one. The essays require not only good writing and critical thinking but also creativity. I think the discussion settings can get overwhelming and be prepared for that.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned how to "queer" a text, how to understand different experiences of homosexuality through literature and their meanings, and how to use forms of creative expression as argumentative devices.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: To be gayer, weirder, and more myself than before. And beyond that I learned to think more critically about the ways queerness is presented to the world differently by queer people and heterosexuals, and how that relationship translates to many forms of hegemony. Furthermore, I learned how to better listen for what is being said without people saying it.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Great in-class discussions, tremendous feedback in and out of class, understanding and flexible with course content as the semester progressed, and exceptional application of subject matter knowledge.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved the variety of types of media that we studied and how Taylor facilitated discussions that really made us think more deeply about the topics and their context. This class went in way less of a queer theory direction that I anticipated, and I loved how it made me learn and think differently about different aspects and aesthetics of queerness that I had not encountered in depth before. It was so evident throughout the course that Taylor cared way more about us learning to think and write in new ways rather than grades or forcing us into the normal academic/english standards for writing. The freedom of the writing prompts allowed me to learn more about myself and experience of the world along the way and write about things that wouldn't be considered conventional in a typical english class. Taylor just being himself made this class so special and I loved the class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think critiquing our writing every week was helpful to see what we were doing wrong, but I wish there was much more emphasis on how to write well and actually learning tips and structural tools to craft good pieces. It got kind of boring and monotonous over time to do the same thing week after week and I felt like I wasn't learning very much by the end.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed memorizing poems week to week. It was really not that hard if you start early enough. I also loved the weekly writing assignments and going over them in class. The fiction unit was by far my favorite, but the poetry unit at the beginning actually was really helpful later on when it came to recognizing small but important errors in longer pieces.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Sharma genuinely cares so much about his students and that is what makes learning in this class so easy. He's a dynamic, engaging professor who's teaching style really clicked with me. I have a relatively low attention span and this class is 2 hours and 30 minutes long, yet I actually managed to stay focused and engaged pretty much every single class. I learn a lot from all his feedback and I really liked how we'd go around and read everyone's works.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Sharma is **jokingly* rude in his evaluations of our writing. I really appreciated that. Professor Sharma does a great job of showing the just how many mistakes students make in their writing. And how they can fix those mistakes.**He isn't actually being mean, he's being silly and adding comedy to the class.**

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class with Dr. Sharma has such an intense focus on the use of the English language to generate / recreate an experience for a reader. This is not something I have ever cared about before with my writing, but now it is something that follows me with each sentence I write.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The feedback is the most intellectually stimulating part. You learn how to see your writing in a totally new light and actually figure out how to make your writing tolerable to read. It steers you away from the idea that writing has to be flowery or pretentious or "complex" to be good.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think adding background music via speaker, tv, or whatever could make it more stimulating. A lot of classes are just him talking to us for 2 hours and 30 minutes. That gets very boring.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is not going to be easy, but if you put in the time and work you will learn a lot

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it!!!!!! Its a fun time and great to do something creative

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Professor Sharma actually cares about you as a person and is FUNNY while he does it. He is genuinely one of my favorite professors at Duke. You are missing out if you do not take a class with him. Amazing person and smart professor.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: In this course, I've come to realize few people deserve the title critic, even fewer deserved to be called honest. Dr. Sharma facilitated my learning by being honest. He is honestly critical, what some may phrase as "brutally so." On the first day of his class, I thought I would pass out from his glare alone. He's not scary, in fact, he'll likely be shorter than you. What makes his presence looming is he is completely in the moment. He is almost naked in his analysis of you as a person and writer. However, he may dress it up by not cussing. Through this method, he may appear 'cruel,' or 'harsh,' potentially, shall I say, disturbing? But he is none of those things. I would almost go as far as to say he's wise; though, he is unlikely to accept such an adjective. He cares too much about writing to pretend you're good at it, and too much to berate you as just bad--even though he will designate you as such in the beginning. He wants you to succeed, and he did that for me by being one of the most honest men I know.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's a very interesting class... Basically the format is that we write one writing assignment (differs between poems, a profile, or a fiction story based on what unit we are in) and then the entire 2.5 hour class is devoted to him critiquing people's work (we also have to recite a poem we memorize each week). It's not a hard class but you are randomly called on a lot.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Please take it. Dr. Sharma is one of the most interesting people I've ever met. His personality is different from any other professor I've met. Take his criticism and critique as a challenge to get better and you will. Please actually do the writings and read your classmate's work. It makes the class so much more interesting and fun. You form a good community throughout the semester. The more effort you put in, the more you will improve, but Dr. Sharma will do his best to make you a better writer no matter what.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Do not get intimidated by the first week. If you don't like writing at all then don't take it, obviously, but if you actually enjoy creative writing and reading other people's stuff than go for it. It's a hilarious, super-fun class to take and honestly was the highlight of my freshman spring. It teaches you how to take harsh criticism if you aren't used to it already, but you need to remember nearly EVERYONE will get critiqued harshly and it is NEVER presented in a way that is mean or ill-mannered. And you NEED that criticism to learn. Writing doesn't improve if you're in an echo chamber of people too afraid to tell you about your shortcomings.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
It is a very helpful course. Professor Sharma does a great job of pointing out weaknesses in writing. 
He's going to be **jokingly** rude, don't the teasing seriously. 
Be assertive and ask questions. You get more out of the course what *you* put into it. Trust me.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned how to write fiction and critically revise my work. Learned how to recognize different writing techniques too.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed skills in four genres of writing: poetry, playwrighting, creative nonfiction, and fiction. I learned how to read and analyze as a writer as well as constructively give and take feedback on writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned what the CRP (critical response process) is for creative writing and how this can be used as a method for getting feedback, I developed useful personal tools for editing my own writing, and I had the opportunity to explore a few different literary genres.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to develop summary, scene, and muse throughout my writing, use the Critical Response Process for editing, and revise our work with creative nonfiction, fiction, poetry, and screenplay.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think I became a better writer in general. I was introduced to 4 very unique but interesting genres of writing, and was exposed to professional literature that really taught me how to write. I learned to revise and draft while thinking like a creative writer.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to draft and edit writings; how to give feedback using critical response feedback method; I learned how to write creative pieces

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to give better feedback, write (kind of) a screenplay, and have better public speaking.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really liked that there were no hard deadlines on our final drafts until the end of the semester. I feel that a lot of the techniques and material that I learned about other genres helped me to revise and gave me ideas for previous genres, so I was able to improve my draft throughout the semester rather than have each piece be due at a certain point the semester. I also enjoyed getting to go see the plays in order to get a sense of how to write a scene in a play. I also enjoyed the Critical Response and revision sessions that we held in class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: keeping all the prompts open ended

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor was amazing!! She made the classroom and incredibly welcoming environment and made the class excited to read and write. I think that the course was structured in a great way that made it engaging and fun.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Fox brought in modern pieces for us to read outside the traditional English classes that we have been conditioned with over our academic careers. It was so great to read a large mix of different genres from authors that are alive and publishing new stuff.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The CRP was really useful. Hearing the entire class's feedback was immensely helpful and helped me get a lot of different viewpoints on my writing to better my work. The 2 required plays were also really fun and insightful as I was exposed to another avenue of writing.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the CRP processes for helping to edit our own writing because it was very insightful to understand how other people read and interpreted the work. In addition, I felt like Dr. Fox created a very safe space for us to get feedback. I also liked how we would write shitty drafts just to practice putting something on the paper. I also really liked how we read and discussed works from a diverse set of writers which opened up my creativity to more styles of writing.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Fox created a very safe space for all of us to feel comfortable sharing, editing, and discussing our pieces of work. I never felt embarrassed to learn or receive critique about my work becuase of the CRP process.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was less about getting assignments done and more about learning how to write. I never felt like I was pressed to do any of the work, despite the fact that there could be a lot of writing involved sometimes. Instead, everything felt like it gradually built up over the semester, and it helped me to become a better writer as I continued to work on and improve my drafts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I also learned how to analyze poetry with more care, and overall, the importance of appreciating all that is happening around you. Poetry often has a way of capturing the small, everyday details of life that most people overlook.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Toby is a great and interesting teacher who made the class fun, interesting, and helped me develop as a writer. He was very kind, understanding, and genuinely cared about us and what was happening in our lives. I loved starting each class catching up with everyone and hearing what was going on in everyone's lives, and I liked when Toby would tell us stories about him as well. It all felt very friendly, open, and supportive, which created a safe writing environment. I liked how our creative work was not directly graded; it was very validating and created less pressure. The feedback we received on our writing from Toby was also very helpful. I also liked the break we received halfway through class because of how long the class period was. I liked how we did not have too much work out of class, I never felt overwhelmed and was always excited to write.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Workshopping was great and I feel like the prof did do a good job of giving thoughtful feedback. I do think, however, that there was a sense of "this is right, this is wrong" attitude to many of the comments, which I felt went completely against the whole idea of a "creative" writing class. Many of us are not writers (usually stem), so if we are told it's wrong by the prof we will instantly listen and do whatever will please the prof best without even thinking twice. However, I think it is more important to rationalise with the students why they made a decision on their writing, and what would be some alternatives, because suggestions are made to be considered, but they are always up to the writer themselves to take them or leave them. I also think that feeling able to defend one's work should be a part of the course, rather than simply feeling forced to take and accept the suggestions. Furthermore, I do not think anyone should use argument by authority such as being published or having worked with famous people etc in order to dismiss students' artistic choices, without even allowing us to justify ourselves.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class I learned a lot about different writing styles, different genres, and authors from around the world. The most important thing that I learned in this class is the way that we should look at the world with a writer's eye. We did one specific activity where we were released from class to record everything that we could from our five senses from our favorite spot on campus. Sitting in one place for an hour(ish) just to write everything down that we see, heard, smelled, tasted, and felt like a big task that was going to go by very slowly. But sitting there, in that spot, I found inspiration for so much of the writing that I did during the semester. It is amazing how when you look at the commonplace, what we observe around us everyday that doesn't seem that extraordinary, how much material you can really find. Without Toby's guidance and focus on this with our seed journals, I would never have realized how easy it was to find inspiration for our writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Writing flash fiction, haiku, erasure poetry, creative nonfiction, and many other styles and types of writing. I learned how to think critically about my own writing, and how to get more comfortable with writing creatively. I also learned how to form my ideas for writing and how to keep a seed journal.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned different mediums of creative writing, how to develop writing pieces varying in length, how to start a writing process, and how to create a diverse writing portfolio.

response_text: Toby was an incredible professor who cared deeply about us as students, but also taught us so many new things. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The structure of the class was perfect. It encouraged a balance of independent working on our portfolio pieces, collaborative working with our groups, and professor instruction. I never felt pressured in this class, and it never stressed me out because of the way it was organized. The grading system was great for the type of class, and it encouraged creativity and individuality rather than focusing on rigid deadlines and rubrics. I really never felt that there was any expectation to be perfect, and Toby was very laid back, and earned a level of respect within the class that encouraged everyone to do the work he asked, even if it wasn't necessarily a graded assignment.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Toby fostered a supportive learning environment where all of us felt comfortable to share about our lives and experiences. He encouraged us to get to know one another, which helped a lot when it came time to share our writing with one another. I like that, when learning about poetry, we started with easy forms of poetry such as haiku and erasure. I also liked that Toby gave us time in class to go out into the world and write, since many of us are very busy and have a hard time carving out space to write in our daily lives.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor offered extensive and incredible feedback on our work, gave many examples of the different types of creative writing we did some of which were his own, encouraged us to work together, and overall created a great learning environment. I would recommend keeping the interactive element–I did not realize how collaborative the writing process could be and I enjoyed working through it with peers. I also liked the wide range of writing mediums we practiced so I would keep that too.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Professor Martinez de las Rivas made an evening class that could have dragged feel more like a club, in the sense that there was a strong community in our group, facilitated by the fact that we talked about our lives along with our writing. The class had all different majors and all different grades, but by the end I considered every classmate a friend. This made sharing my writing feel easier, as I was not afraid of being looked down on or judged for what I wrote.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course was a great introduction into understanding film on a more technical level! We began with elements of movies like mise-en scene and cinematography and worked our way into more specific details like acting and sound design. This course has fundamentally changed the way I think about movies and made them so much more fun to watch! For example, for the film Punch Drunk Love, before this course, I would have seen it simply as a quirky and confusing romcom. However, after paying attention to things like cinematography, shot composition, the use of a telephoto lens, etc. it took on a whole new meaning and became so much more engaging to watch. Really grateful for this course helping me to put general intuition about a film into clear meaning and technical wording!One of my favorite things we learned about this semester was looking at the evolution and history of film. The course itself follows this progression in the movies we watch. It was really cool to watch clips of earlier work and inspiration for a certain film and then watch the film itself. This gave us a great perspective on where some of these creative and innovative ideas in cinema came from.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the formal elements of film, such as cinematography and mise-en-scene; I also learned to think critically about sound design and the role of directors and actors; and I learned to write formal analyses of films.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned new ways to analyze films, different things to look for when watching films, and a newfound respect for filmmaking as a whole.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The skills to identify and analyze formal elements in films, the history of film as an art and as a technology, and the production process of a film.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Cason is an extremely knowledgable professor who clearly cares a lot about his students! I appreciated the thoughtful slides before the films detailing the aspects of film we were considering that class which then directly connected to the film we were watching. Dr. Cason was really patient with the class and always gave us time to talk and participate in class and through online discussion forums.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I thought the rubrics for the assignments were very clear. For the first paper, the instructor set up 15-minute meetings to address any questions or look over any current draft we had written. He was also very understanding if we were busy in other classes and granted extensions for major assignments if we needed more time to construct a quality response.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professor did a great job in incorporating discussions and weekly reflection posts with the theme of the week and the films screened in class that week. This is great because we can discuss films together and draw inspiration from other students' commentary and practice using the language of formal analysis in the study of films.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
