Some of the films required more thought and engagement, and the pre-screening content helped students prepare and be engaged.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The papers and midterm encouraged us to think critically about formal elements and other components of films, which was intellectually stimulating. In addition, I appreciated how we were able to choose our own film to analyze for the first paper because that eased my approach to practicing formal analyses.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class was stimulating, intellectually challenging, and rewarding because learning to analyze films is like learning to speak a new language. We had to use such language in our papers and exams where we had to analyze the formal choices of the films. It was overall a great learning experience.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I think every student should take this class (or one similar)! Film and video is becoming this generations main source of content, and this course will take you from a passive consumer to analyzing and better understanding cinema. It's super interesting, the films are diverse and engaging!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Please take this course to fulfill the ALP Trinity requirement! I genuinely looked forward to attending this class each week because it was a great break from traditional lecture- or seminar-based classes in that you get to watch movies each class and then engage in some discussion afterward that encourages you to apply your knowledge of film techniques or theories to what you watched during that class session.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are interested in films--either you are a movie fan or someone who is pursuing a degree in film studies--I definitely recommend taking this class with Dr. Cason. Professor Cason is super accessible and helpful, and this class provides you with a taste of film analysis and film theory in a relatively low-stake environment where a diverse range of opinions and creativity collides. It will be a wonderful choice if you are seeking to get credits for humanities/art classes.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This was an amazing class for introducing students to film studies. I highly recommend this class to anyone who has even the slightest bit of interest!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Throughout this course I learned skills that not only shaped the way I viewed learning material (reading plays and understanding scene work) but it also allowed for me to see how all parts of theater are connected. We learned the historical backgrounds of many pieces while also understanding the foundations of acting in practice (Aristotle) and what makes a piece objectively successful.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. plays as blueprints and artifacts
2. the broad history of the development of Western theater--how we get from The Bacchae to Cloud 9
3. how to think about productions in terms of efficacy, how to direct a scene so that it is an effective adaptation of the text

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course I learned how to analyze the wide blueprint of theater throughout history. I learned how to look at theater from the perspective of the writer, the director, the designer, and the actor. I also learned how to apply these concepts in a final production project.

response_text: Exploring the specific components of a script or production that made it work a certain way (e.g. representation in Fairview, amphitheater setup for the Bacchae) was intellectually stimulating.Suggestion for improvement: I would add discussion of more non-white and especially non-European theater -- or change the course description to clearly indicate that the course focuses on Europe/US.* Even a "there is theater in the Global South too but we won't cover it here" would have been good.*The course description advertised "non-European and non-white perspectives," and while this was technically true, it was a bit disappointing to realize that the only non-European play was from the US.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed skills in recognizing the grotesque in southern literature, trends of fragile masculinity through film, and recognizing the serviceable blackness used to frame white innocence.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze intense literature, how to write in a way that I am not used and I learned how to have open discussions about hard topics.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to be a better reader, critic, and writer of English.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to recognize, understand, and discuss Flannery O'Connor's "grotesque" in literature: the representation by one image or idea of two disparate or even paradoxical points, which joins the symbolic and the concrete in a layered representation of reality. I learned about the complex and intense role that religion plays in both the Southern identity and in America's understanding of the "Other." I learned about the discrete (or sometimes indiscrete) yet integral role that blackness has played in American literature throughout history

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

Reading was always set, but the discussion originated from the class and students.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Discussions were always engaging and enjoyable yet challenging. Professor Black facilitates discussion thoughtfully, allowing students the time to contemplate the material and formulate a response, and letting students' insights guide the discussion. Professor Black's seminar is a space where it's okay to speak without raising your hand, it's okay to take risks with what you share, it's okay to think out loud and to draw far-reaching connections - your voice will be heard, considered, and respected by Professor Black and, in my class at least, by your peers as well. The class environment is wonderfully thought-provoking and endlessly interesting.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Try not to think of the readings or other materials (movies, music, etc) just as assignments; try to enjoy them! O'Connor's stories are actually funny, they're not just literary. If you're having trouble with something - one of the papers or anything else - meet with Professor Black, he will help. This class can be just as fun as it is challenging, so try to let it!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Professor Vadde assigned books that explored numerous genres. Thus, the assignments never got boring and were quite interesting to read. One book that stands out to me is Ballad of Black Tom. The satirical commentary on Call of Cthulhu was a genre that I had never explored and the meta factor was intriguing.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The discussion-type structure of the course made the experience extremely enjoyable. Having the discussions between Professor Vadde and the other students stimulated ideas and helped form new ideas that helped critically thinking skills.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Read the texts ahead of time and create meaningful connections and tangents of thought as you read.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Please take it! This was one of the most rewarding experiences I've had at Duke.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would recommend it, though I would be wary of the workload as it is a lot of work and a lot of deep thinking.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: There is a lot of readings but the discussions help understand the readings

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Despite the coursework and essays being quite substantial, they are for a reason force you to explore fiction with a deeper understanding. Yet by doing so, you come out with a refreshing view on the existence and need for fiction as a whole. Make use of the office hours as they provide very useful feedback on essays and offer pathways that you can explore in your themes that you hadn't though of previously.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Although you may have been discouraged from the class from the first few weeks, do not drop the class like the others. The best part of this class comes from the dialogues that occur between you, the other students, the TAs, and Professor Vadde. This is my favorite class I have taken at Duke so far, and I never thought I would enjoy a non-stem, much less a Writing/English class this much. The essays and writing are not that bad, if you discuss ideas, and pull ideas from the discussion, you will be more than well-equipped to tackle the essay prompts.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is an interesting course. Come if you like books.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take it. It wasn't too writing intensive, and if you go to office hours and ask for help, you'll do well on the essays. I think it's easier to understand the math if you have already taken linear, but Dr. Giugni does an excellent job of teaching what you need to understand even if you have no math background.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The math in this course is difficult if you have never taken math.But the computational methods for analyzing literature was very cool. The English portion is the most interesting part of the class by far.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The work is demanding but not unmanageable.  The professor and TA care deeply about the class - they want you to grow as a student.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you enjoy reading fiction or comedy, you'll enjoy this class (plus it gives you a QS credit)!  On the other hand, if you don't enjoy literature much but are interested in computational analysis, this would be a good way to step into the English world without feeling overwhelmed (plus it gives you a T-req).

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a great course to take if you are looking for a QS but be aware I would not call it easy. You will put in a lot of work (there are quizzes every week) and the papers take a lot of work. However, the professor is amazing and really wants you to do well so she is always around to help.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are interested in reading and analysis, take this class! And don't worry, the math portion isn't very hard at all. The workload is super reasonable and Prof. Giugni keeps the classes interesting through her own passion for the work.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Pay close attention to vocabulary and re-read the plays

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class looks into some FASCINATING plays from the 1600's and dives into the culture and values of people in city settings during this time. The plays are fun to read, the discussions are deep but enjoyable and the Professor is so willing to work with you and help you succeed in every way.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say don't expect this class to be a walk in the park. The papers are demanding and really require to both think and write well. Personally, I struggled less with the math than I expected coming into the class and I am not very good at math generally so that goes to show that she is a good teacher who goes at a good pace. Don't be afraid to talk in class. Professor Giugni is wonderful, both as a teacher and a person. If you need the t-req, there are probably easier options but I doubt any class will be as cool as this one.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

On the other hand, if you don't enjoy literature much but are interested in computational analysis, this would be a good way to step into the English world without feeling overwhelmed (plus it gives you a T-req).

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

Don't be afraid to talk in class. Professor Giugni is wonderful, both as a teacher and a person. If you need the t-req, there are probably easier options but I doubt any class will be as cool as this one.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the development of the English language, including its predecessors, its progression, and its interaction with global languages. Some examples include Grimm’s Law, the Great Vowel Shift, and the formation of American English dialects.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned what characteristics from old English shaped "interesting" features of modern English such as irregular verbs, subject pronouns, noun cases, and how the language evolved from contact with the Latin, French, and Norse.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Basic structures of old/middle english
2. Cultural influences on language change
3. Interrelatedness of modern languages and how they interact with one another

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about linguistics studies, early British history, and how different types of English might have been influenced over time.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In my linguistics class, I learned about the historical development of languages, how to analyze linguistic patterns like syntax and phonetics, and the connection between language, culture, and identity. While it wasn’t my favorite course, it offered interesting insights into the history and structure of language.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The course was most enriching when it questioned how modern conventions connect to ancient practices. I also appreciated the careful analysis of how linguistic features often have strange societal bases. Sometimes, the features of modernity aren’t carefully calculated or more “advanced” — instead, things can be random.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed Professor Baran's lectures! Sometimes the readings were really dense or confusing, but Professor Baran always explained the concepts in class in a way that was easy to understand. I also enjoyed hearing Professor Baran's own anecdotes of learning English and her experiences with different languages. It helped a lot to hear the perspective of someone who had to learn English growing up rather than speak it as their first language. I also think the activities we did in class helped a lot with breaking up the lectures. They were fun and helped to understand the material! The homework each week was also reasonable, fairly graded, and a good application of what we talked about in lecture.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

I've found myself becoming more empathetic to those people while also understanding my own Englishes. I had never taken a linguistics class before, but I'm really glad that I challenged myself to take the course. I learned a lot about English grammar and phonologies, and I feel more confident in being able to tackle older English texts and reading global Englishes that I'm not so familiar with.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class was very foundational to the English program. I am a first year English major, and I feel that this class should be required. The sheer exposure to content and theory I gained was remarkable, but the skills I picked up were also integral. I learned how to approach translated works, gained a basic insight into linguistics, and shifted my perspective on English works in the literary horizon.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about translation as a process, novels that were translated, and the sociopolitical cultural contexts around novels.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about how to approach linguistics and close reading of texts. Specifically, I learned a lot about the process of translation and the caveats to world and global literature within the world of English. I also learned a lot about how the experiences of the author and translator impact storytelling.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the different schools of thought in translation (Damrosch, Venuti, House), how to close read for the translator's choices, and the external economic, political, and social forces that impact the act of translation.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course I learned how to research context about how a book was written/published (meaning, who is the author and what might have influenced them to write the novel, etc.). I learned how translation has been present throughout history (during colonization) and the heavy responsibility translators have.

response_text: I learned the basic principles of writing a play, through actually writing a play! course: ENGLISH-218S-01 : PLAYS THAT CHANGE THE WORLD.ENGLISH-218S-01.

course: ENGLISH-218S-01 : PLAYS THAT CHANGE THE WORLD.ENGLISH-218S-01.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Fox did not hold back in terms of reading and writing assignments, and it was slightly daunting in the beginning to see just how many things were expected to do on a weekly basis -- on top of penning full-length plays. However, she always endeavored to make each of those aspects engaging, and I could see the value by the end.

course: ENGLISH-218S-01 : PLAYS THAT CHANGE THE WORLD.ENGLISH-218S-01.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Every week, we watched a play virtually or in person. This was very insightful for our own plays as we saw new techniques and strategies we could use. We also did CRP feedback sessions every week where we would read a section of someone's play and give our feedback and answer their questions. This was extremely helpful in figuring out the details of our plays and nudging each other in the right direction.

course: ENGLISH-218S-01 : PLAYS THAT CHANGE THE WORLD.ENGLISH-218S-01.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that Professor Fox created lots of opportunities for us to engage with a variety of play and material and this allowed us to discover the things that we liked, didn't like and felt connected to. This also helped me with the writing of my own play. I feel like discovered tools and things that I wanted to emulate in my own play.

course: ENGLISH-218S-01 : PLAYS THAT CHANGE THE WORLD.ENGLISH-218S-01.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the play discussion posts were very effective. I always enjoyed our discussions in class. I also loved watching all of the plays throughout the semester.

course: ENGLISH-218S-01 : PLAYS THAT CHANGE THE WORLD.ENGLISH-218S-01.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The once-a-week structure was really good, as was the focus on the Critical Response Process which fostered a welcoming classroom environment. I also liked that we read a new play every week, and I'm glad we were able to play a part in selecting them. I like that plays were discussed in an open, discussion-based setting.I'm very grateful that I had the opportunity to participate in table reads in class. Also, being able to go outside of the classroom and attend live performances was really memorable and enjoyable.

course: ENGLISH-218S-01 : PLAYS THAT CHANGE THE WORLD.ENGLISH-218S-01.
question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was intellectually stimulating in that I was put outside of my comfort zone to learn about how to write creatively in a new format, and I read a ton of different playwriting examples from different periods in history and cultures. Sometimes I didn't feel as intellectually stimulated because so much of what we did in class felt like busywork - from the detailed play responses to often redundant readings on craft.

course: ENGLISH-218S-01 : PLAYS THAT CHANGE THE WORLD.ENGLISH-218S-01.

course: ENGLISH-218S-01 : PLAYS THAT CHANGE THE WORLD.ENGLISH-218S-01.

course: ENGLISH-218S-01 : PLAYS THAT CHANGE THE WORLD.ENGLISH-218S-01.
question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It covered a wide variety of important topics to our world through plays, from climate change to social/economic injustice and more. It wasn't all about heavy topics like that, and some of the plays were more lighthearted comedies. I think it was a good mix of plays that kept the tone of the class interesting yet not overbearing, and I really enjoyed that the class got to choose the plays we wanted to see at the start of the semester.

course: ENGLISH-218S-01 : PLAYS THAT CHANGE THE WORLD.ENGLISH-218S-01.

course: ENGLISH-218S-01 : PLAYS THAT CHANGE THE WORLD.ENGLISH-218S-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take your time to develop your ideas about your play! This doesn't mean you have to plan everything out to the last detail - definitely free write and don't silence your creative flow. However, think critically about in which direction you want to take this production if you want to come up with a cohesive and impressive work by the end of the semester.

course: ENGLISH-220S-02 : INTRO TO THE WRITING OF POETRY.ENGLISH-220S-02.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Different forms of poetry, as well as style options that we could use in our poetry (e.g. rhyme & half-rhyme, haiku, prose poetry). Also some general wisdom about writing poetry like being careful of adverbs.

course: ENGLISH-220S-02 : INTRO TO THE WRITING OF POETRY.ENGLISH-220S-02.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- How to read a poem, i.e. how to be a good reader, re-reading it again and again, underlining, looking things up, thinking about the context of the author 
- How to workshop other people's poetry
- How to write different types of poetry, like haiku, haibun, prose poetry and ekphrastic poetry

course: ENGLISH-220S-02 : INTRO TO THE WRITING OF POETRY.ENGLISH-220S-02.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to feel comfortable sharing written work, different poetic forms, and learning the value of keeping a collection of drafts

course: ENGLISH-220S-02 : INTRO TO THE WRITING OF POETRY.ENGLISH-220S-02.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Different types of poetry, from ekphrastic and erasure, to prose and haibun, I didn't know such existed.
2. How to be intentional with words. What makes poetry special is not only the way words are arranged but the words we use themselves. What works for regular prose won't always work for poetry, especially with regard to adverbs and adjectives.3. Poetry and the lessons it provides are very subjective, and is not always meant to be understood.

course: ENGLISH-220S-02 : INTRO TO THE WRITING OF POETRY.ENGLISH-220S-02.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Toby's ability to curate diverse writing prompts each week not only stimulated our creativity but also expanded our literary boundaries in unexpected ways. The group workshops were vibrant hubs of collaboration, where ideas flowed freely and peer feedback enriched our understanding of each other's work. Beyond the classroom, one-on-one poetry review meetings with Toby truly stood out. His personalized guidance and genuine investment in our growth made every conversation meaningful and inspiring. Toby's approach transcends mere instruction; it cultivates a community of passionate writers dedicated to honing their craft.

course: ENGLISH-220S-02 : INTRO TO THE WRITING OF POETRY.ENGLISH-220S-02.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This class was awesome, and I genuinely looked forward to it every time I went to class, despite it being on east campus. The small group format was lovely, and I feel like I got to know the people in my group and kind of hear each of their sort of ~poetic style~ more and more the more I interacted with them. The big group workshop was great as well, it was really nice to get feedback on a poem/set of poems like that.

course: ENGLISH-220S-02 : INTRO TO THE WRITING OF POETRY.ENGLISH-220S-02.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Toby is incredible. He was so accessible outside of class and strongly valued each and every member of his classroom. He made the environment very casual so that everyone felt comfortable speaking their minds. Poetry can be really vulnerable so I think that this aspect of the course was absolutely essential.

course: ENGLISH-220S-02 : INTRO TO THE WRITING OF POETRY.ENGLISH-220S-02.

course: ENGLISH-221S-01 : INTRO. TO THE WRITING OF FICT..ENGLISH-221S-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

course: ENGLISH-221S-01 : INTRO. TO THE WRITING OF FICT..ENGLISH-221S-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: When I started this class I had no knowledge on how to write fiction. This class taught me the nuts and bolts of writing fiction, down to the technical level. It was an incredibly informative experience. We learned how to construct narrative engines, beginnings, endings, characters, natural spaces, time management, and much more.

course: ENGLISH-221S-01 : INTRO. TO THE WRITING OF FICT..ENGLISH-221S-01.

response_text: how to read as a writer (taking note of narrative engine, time, POV, character), how to workshop effectively, how to revise a story

course: ENGLISH-221S-01 : INTRO. TO THE WRITING OF FICT..ENGLISH-221S-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Constructive peer reviewing

course: ENGLISH-221S-01 : INTRO. TO THE WRITING OF FICT..ENGLISH-221S-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Before this course, I was not able to point out the way a story is structure. However, now I am able to name the process of writing a story, its tools, and be able to give feedback to my peers.

course: ENGLISH-221S-01 : INTRO. TO THE WRITING OF FICT..ENGLISH-221S-01.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Ahmad was extremely intentional and thoughtful about his way of teaching. Before each class, we would read a specific set of stories that were extremely relevant to the technique we were focusing on. Our discussions were rigorous yet open: We didn't just say random things we "liked" or "didn't like" about the stories, rather, we analyzed technical components of the stories and discussed their role in the story.

course: ENGLISH-221S-01 : INTRO. TO THE WRITING OF FICT..ENGLISH-221S-01.

course: ENGLISH-221S-01 : INTRO. TO THE WRITING OF FICT..ENGLISH-221S-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you're interesting in learning how to write: this is the class you should take. Our class had a wide range of experience levels, some were incredible writers already and some had literally no experience (me). Every class was extremely engaging, and the discussions we had were fascinating. Professor Ahmad cultivated an incredibly rich classroom community, you could tell everyone was excited for class. I improved SO much in my writing as a result. This is one of if not THE best class I took at Duke, and this is coming from a Computer Science major. While I wouldn't say this class is hard, you have to be willing to put in the work to get the maximum out of it. But unlike other classes, that isn't really a challenge, it's so interesting that you want to put in the work, it's fun and rewarding!

course: ENGLISH-221S-01 : INTRO. TO THE WRITING OF FICT..ENGLISH-221S-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Professor Ahmad is the lesser of two evils, if the alternate choice is Akhil Sharma. That doesn't make him not bad. Just less bad compared to Sharma.

course: ENGLISH-221S-01 : INTRO. TO THE WRITING OF FICT..ENGLISH-221S-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I loved it, Amin was very friendly and funny and I learned a lot about writing and got a lot of practice- first half of semester are weekly short story prompts and weekly short readings that you analyze, then you have two other pieces that you workshop as a class and really get to revise.

course: ENGLISH-221S-01 : INTRO. TO THE WRITING OF FICT..ENGLISH-221S-01.

course: ENGLISH-221S-01 : INTRO. TO THE WRITING OF FICT..ENGLISH-221S-01.

response_text: If you are a beginner in creative writing, I think this is the best course to start with. Not only is the professor very supportive of your writing and the feedback you receive, but the way the class is taught makes it fun and easier to learn because you get to read short stories from famous authors, read your classmates' work, and write your own stories. course: ENGLISH-221S-01 : INTRO. TO THE WRITING OF FICT..ENGLISH-221S-01.

course: ENGLISH-221S-01 : INTRO. TO THE WRITING OF FICT..ENGLISH-221S-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I came into this class expecting to learn from contemporary fiction writers by reading a lot with the hope of diving deeper into the craft of past fiction writers. Although my expectations were not met, I came out of the class with a deeper understanding of language and a sensibility to words which has allowed me to become a better writer. In other words, this class was essential for my growth as a writer and learner. By reading the texts of my classmates and peer reviewing them, I gained an understanding about the thinking and planning that writing fiction requires along with the essence of sticking to the basics. This is probably the best English course I've taken so far.

course: ENGLISH-221S-01 : INTRO. TO THE WRITING OF FICT..ENGLISH-221S-01.

response_text: Prof Akhil Sharma was a wonderful professor. He is careful to create an environment that feels safe to be open to direct and honest feedback while also encouraging you and discovering what you are poised to do well in writing and how to leverage that. I like the seminar component and seeing how we are all making mistakes together as students and writers. It was helpful that everyone in the class had such different levels of experience and writing styles.

course: ENGLISH-221S-01 : INTRO. TO THE WRITING OF FICT..ENGLISH-221S-01.

response_text: Akhil Sharma was an awesome instructor with a teaching style I would not change. course: ENGLISH-221S-01 : INTRO. TO THE WRITING OF FICT..ENGLISH-221S-01.

response_text: I honestly really appreciated the brutally honest feedback – I think that Dr. Sharma is right in saying that we don't get enough of that at Duke. His feedback was always fair, honest, and helpful, and I genuinely feel that it made me a better writer.

course: ENGLISH-221S-01 : INTRO. TO THE WRITING OF FICT..ENGLISH-221S-01.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, I found that the instructor’s thoughtful guidance and the course structure really supported my growth as a writer. One of the most valuable components was going over our essays in class with detail—breaking down what was working, what wasn’t, and why. This level of close attention helped me see my writing more objectively and learn from others at the same time. I also appreciated being able to share my opinions openly during discussions. There was a real sense that all voices were welcome, which made the classroom feel collaborative rather than competitive. I think both of these elements—detailed feedback and open dialogue—are worth keeping for future years.

course: ENGLISH-222S-01 : INTRO TO THE WTG OF CREAT. N-F.ENGLISH-222S-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me to not be afraid of my own thoughts and words - it allowed me the space to grow creatively through its comprehensive writing assignments. I also learned how to workshop essays with the several rounds of feedback and workshopping we did. By reading the plethora of essays provided in the class, I also learned a lot about finding a specific writing style that I am comfortable with and increased me tenacity by requesting multiple drafts of a single essay.

course: ENGLISH-222S-01 : INTRO TO THE WTG OF CREAT. N-F.ENGLISH-222S-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Telling can be as valuable as showing in the right context. Physical description births prose. We write about things as if they are interesting, to make our lives seem more interesting than they are. I think a lot of the most engaging ideas took place in the descriptions section of the course.

course: ENGLISH-222S-01 : INTRO TO THE WTG OF CREAT. N-F.ENGLISH-222S-01.

response_text:
1. I learned how to make yourself into an interesting story character when you are writing a creative nonfiction story with yourself as the main character. 
2. I learned the importance of reading and reflecting on other authors' creative nonfiction works when trying to write your own.
3. I learned how a creative nonfiction work can at first seem to be just a fun story but then have a much deeper message throughout the writing.

I also found that the readings were all really helpful examples of different styles of writing, which gave me tools that I could then incorporate in my own writing. In addition, I found the in-class writing assignments to be a lot of fun!

course: ENGLISH-222S-01 : INTRO TO THE WTG OF CREAT. N-F.ENGLISH-222S-01.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Shuman's informal attitude and sense of humor allows the class to relax and talk without hesitation. It facilitates a lively discussion which makes the three hour class feel like a regular 75 minute one. I also love the in class writing assignments because it allows us to write with absolutely no pressure and have some fun.

course: ENGLISH-222S-01 : INTRO TO THE WTG OF CREAT. N-F.ENGLISH-222S-01.

course: ENGLISH-222S-01 : INTRO TO THE WTG OF CREAT. N-F.ENGLISH-222S-01.
question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

course: ENGLISH-222S-01 : INTRO TO THE WTG OF CREAT. N-F.ENGLISH-222S-01.
question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The readings were outside of my scope and thus very stimulating. It was cool to see pieces from a unique variety of sources and structures. I learned so much in this course.

course: ENGLISH-222S-01 : INTRO TO THE WTG OF CREAT. N-F.ENGLISH-222S-01.
question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class was stimulating because the material was interesting and personally relevant. Because everyone was participating in class discussions it felt like I had a safe space to share unfinished ideas and also to pose questions.

course: ENGLISH-222S-01 : INTRO TO THE WTG OF CREAT. N-F.ENGLISH-222S-01.

course: ENGLISH-222S-01 : INTRO TO THE WTG OF CREAT. N-F.ENGLISH-222S-01.

course: ENGLISH-222S-01 : INTRO TO THE WTG OF CREAT. N-F.ENGLISH-222S-01.

course: ENGLISH-222S-01 : INTRO TO THE WTG OF CREAT. N-F.ENGLISH-222S-01.

course: ENGLISH-222S-01 : INTRO TO THE WTG OF CREAT. N-F.ENGLISH-222S-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is a lot of work, but the pay off is worth it. You will improve as both a reader and writer as well as develop relationships with your classmates and Dr. Shuman. It is a great course!

course: ENGLISH-222S-01 : INTRO TO THE WTG OF CREAT. N-F.ENGLISH-222S-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are interested in developing your own nonfiction writing, this is an amazing class and a great place to start. It's not only your own writing, but reading others (profesional and student) that helped. Prof. Shuman gave each of us attention and help with all multiple drafts.

course: ENGLISH-222S-01 : INTRO TO THE WTG OF CREAT. N-F.ENGLISH-222S-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is great for any student who wants to learn how to create a narrative, how to write about their own life, and how to give and receive feedback. It is also accessible for students with any amount of writing experience.

course: ENGLISH-222S-01 : INTRO TO THE WTG OF CREAT. N-F.ENGLISH-222S-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Do all of the readings you are assigned, and look at all of the feedback you receive from your peers and from Professor Shuman. course: ENGLISH-222S-01 : INTRO TO THE WTG OF CREAT. N-F.ENGLISH-222S-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I think this is a great class for those with and without experience in creative non-fiction writing. Even as a Pratt student, I was able to keep up with the class and felt comfortable in a space that I'm not used to. I learned a lot about writing and about myself in the process. This was an awesome class and Professor Shuman is amazing.

course: ENGLISH-222S-01 : INTRO TO THE WTG OF CREAT. N-F.ENGLISH-222S-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This was a great course to improve my writing ability! Even though it was geared to creative writing, I found that I was using things that I learned in class for my academic writing in other courses. Additionally, I found that it was really valuable to stretch my writing in different directions. I'm very used to writing academic papers and reading responses but haven't had as much experience writing creatively, so it challenged me in new ways.

course: ENGLISH-222S-01 : INTRO TO THE WTG OF CREAT. N-F.ENGLISH-222S-01.

course: THEATRST-284S-01 : HOW TO WRITE A HORROR MOVIE.THEATRST-284S-01.CINE-281S-01.ENGLISH-223S-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
This is such a unique course, and was a wonderful experience! I think the horror genre is fascinating, though I hadn't had much contact with it previously, and it's great that we got to engage with it in an academic context. Professor Bell was great, and I had so much fun with this class. There's a lot of writing, but I think that's a good part of the class. Making myself dive into writing for a new medium (as I had no previous experience with screenwriting) is what really started to give me a sense for what goes into a script.
Stay on top of your long script at the end, though. Checkpoints are built into the class, so don't get behind on them, because that 80 page script is very manageable if broken up over multiple weeks, but very scary if you've let it pile up!

course: THEATRST-284S-01 : HOW TO WRITE A HORROR MOVIE.THEATRST-284S-01.CINE-281S-01.ENGLISH-223S-01.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

response_text: I learned a lot of skills that I haven't had the opportunity to develop at Duke as a stem student. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

-generation of ideas beyond what tv shows already exist

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class we were thinking about how to plot, format, and write television screenplays. Through this class I learned about screenplay formatting, the level of detail required to write a TV episode, and how to connect plot points in a sensical way.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

-force us to read almost every class. There are so many things I learned on how to better write when we did out loud readings. As shy as I am, I really needed this to learn!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Writing specifically for the stage. I had experience with other methods of writing, but did not have exposure to theater writing. This course gave me hands-on experience with that. I also became more comfortable sharing my work with others. Finally, I learned how to tell a compelling story from start to finish, and also how to craft scenes based on specific, engaging prompts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed my writing skills, took constructive criticism, and learned how to make an engaging story.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed my ability to write long-form scripts for the stage. I improved my skills at writing believable dialogue. I worked on my story-writing skills based on a given prompt and creatively interpreting set boundaries.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to write for plays! It is a very new style of writing to me and at first I was quite unfamiliar with it, but after writing a couple of scenes, I've gotten the hang of it and learned how fun and flexible this writing style is. It is interesting since you have to also consider stage directions since ultimately you are writing for a play which will be acted on stage, so it is cool to think about how your story and play will appear on stage and think about what stage directions are the most effective to achieve your vision of the play.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to think about injecting drama in playwriting, how to build plot, and how to improve dialogue.

response_text: How to write for the stage, how to format scripts, how to best use language for dramatic effect.

response_text:
- Learned how to structure a play
- Learned how to write for a stage, rather than just tell a story throughout words, including stage directions, use of the stage, costumes, effects etc
- Learned how to talk about theatre

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked how we did the work outside of class and read them out loud in class. This gave us time to think our pieces through and see them played out visually.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class structure of bringing in written pieces and casting classmates to read them aloud was very helpful, as well as entertaining. In the dramatic writing format, there is nothing like hearing a piece read aloud to help make decisions and elicit feedback. Both giving feedback on others' work as well as getting feedback on my own writing was incredibly helpful in learning how to successfully write for the stage.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Bell gives amazing feedback. He fosters a learning environment in which everyone feels (or seems to feel) comfortable. I love the workshop style of the class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: He would give feedback in and out of the classroom and check in on you.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Implementing in-class readings of student scripts was both an effective tool for figuring out what did and didn't work in a given script, as well as facilitating a fun and engaging environment for all students. Even when your script wasn't being read, it was exciting to read what other students were working on and fostered a flowing marketplace of creative ideas.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I love the assignments! They are so fun and creative! I also love the structure of the class. It is very interactive and super fun and gives students an opportunity to appreciate other student's work!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The acting out of scripts made class engagement very high.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed reading each others scripts during class and providing feedback

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Having us just write plays and table-read them rather than telling us how to write plays was super effective in my opinion. It allowed us to reach our maximum creative, while also teaching us indirectly what works and what doesn't.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professor always gave constructive feedback in a very kind way that still fostered growth within the class. He also created a very welcoming and inclusive environment which made people comfortable with sharing their work.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The diversity of thoughts and students. I am also not typically creative so this class was a great class to test my creative boundaries.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: As mentioned previously, the format of reading pieces aloud was very stimulating, and fun too.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I really liked how in the first few weeks we were exposed to plays written by professionals in the industry. I wish we did more of that throughout the semester.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It helped me craft my writing skills aside from academic writing

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Perhaps more readings and discussions of what makes professional plays work and how to incorporate these writing strategies into our work. I know this is hard to balance while prioritizing student work, but if there was a 300-level version of the class that was able to delve deeper into technique, that is certainly something I'd love to take. As an introductory class for all ability levels, however, I don't see this as a shortcoming. More so a humble request for more course offerings for students to explore these concepts on a deeper level.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The writing assignments and the reading out-loud of the student's work made it so stimulating!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Being given different prompts to write scripts about was fun.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Learning about others' perspectives through their plays was absolutely fascinating to me.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Professor Bell is an expert in his field and knows when things need to be changed in a play

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! A good class to add to overload with. Not much work but it is fun and energizing.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it!! I learned so much about dramatic writing, Professor Bell is a great professor and a great person, and we as a class had so much fun and bonded so much. Another great thing about this class is that by the end you will have a large portfolio of short dramatic works that you can submit to journals, readings, and competitions - I was able to have one of my pieces performed at the Duke Players Playhouse Shorts event and it was an amazing experience.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this class! Or any class with Professor Bell. Because sharing writing is so intimate, you will form great bonds and connections with your classmates and teacher, which is really special. You will gain more practical writing experience and have the opportunity to workshop your pieces with a decent amount of people! Great for anyone interested in writing in the future, or anyone who loves writing/telling stories just for fun :)

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Engage in class and do your work and you should be fine.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you enjoy creative writing, take this class. If you enjoy theater and want to get more experience on the playwright side, take this class. If you have no experience in writing or theater and want a fun and rewarding creative outlet, take this class. Come to class ready to engage with your peers' scripts, but that may not even need to be said because everyone in the class was eager to read each others' scripts. The only possible reason I can fathom that someone wouldn't be satisfied with this class is if they didn't put in any effort; this was not the case of anyone I know who's taken it, but I suppose in the abstract it is theoretically possible. I would STILL encourage that person to take this class because even shy or "too-cool-for-the-arts" students will get a kick out of this class. It is genuinely the most fun class I've taken at Duke.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: TAKE THE CLASS! It's the best!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's a ton of fun! Buy in with the acting and writing and you'll have a great time.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! Hands down my favorite class at Duke.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Come and be creative

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It may seem intimidating at first but the class is loads of fun and helps you learn a lot about both theatre and yourself a writer.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze movies in terms of incidents and dramatic action, adapting source material to screen and the many ways that can be done, and how to more accurately describe scenes in terms of action and meaning and uncover what the deeper meaning/main purpose is instead of objectively what happened.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
An understanding of dramatic action
Basics of screenwriting
How to effectively analyze a film and how to understand story

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: You learn an approach to screenwriting that emphasizes dramatic principles---understanding your main character's motivation, how to structure a plot around incidents, and three-act structure.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. How to structure a screenplay
2. How to edit a literary work in order to make it more fit to be a movie
3. How to identify the most important parts of a scene and character motivations

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: There was a very open dialogue in this class and the class is set up as a larger writer's room, so it is a space with constructive feedback.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really liked the weekly presentations, and I like that it was split into two halves, one for watching movies and one for writing

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Prof McAuliffe is very experienced at providing writing feedback and pushing students to better understand the screenwriting paradigm she presents in the class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The learning environment was very hands on, where we would often go over movies or literary works together in class to identify the important parts. After you start writing the screenplay, you also have the chance to read it aloud in class and get feedback from everyone, which was helpful.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: There was a lot of space for conversation and critically thinking which was intellectually stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The professor wasn't afraid to really challenge us, which I really liked. We learned a lot and we learned fast.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: You get the opportunity to write your own screenplay based on material of your choosing, which is very fun and a good challenge. I just wish the course would be more of a true writer's workshop for the whole semester.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class presented some very particular expectations and focused on skills I haven't had to think about before. The process of figuring out the incident lists for a given movie and determining character motivations really made me think.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take it! It was very helpful for both writers with experience and writers without experience and everything in-between.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is my favorite class I've taken at Duke

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you like screenwriting but don't have time to do it on your own outside of class this course gives you a great opportunity to get better at it and have something to show for yourself at the end, even if it's not a full feature screenplay.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is very particular and can take a bit of getting used to in the beginning, but once you understand what it's about, especially once you start writing your own screenplay, it becomes really enjoyable. If you like creative writing I would definitely recommend this course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: To investigate the true meaning of intention of a word if I don't understand it. For instance, if I don't know what Shakespeare means by saying "Forture," look it up, and learn that Fortune was a goddess with a wheel of powerful men.Critical theory; understanding cultural significance of choices made in literature.Appreciation for the depth of Shakespeare's writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Close reading of texts, reflecting on the nature journal, and sharing thoughts through class discussion.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned how to view Shakespeare through his applications and allusions to nature
2. I became more aware of the role nature plays in the human experience
3. I learned alot of new Shakespeare stories

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I really enjoyed the "book club" type discussion style of the class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Reading/translating Shakespeare improved, close reading within essay writing, journaling my thoughts while writing the nature journal -- but also creative aspects.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One of the things I learned from this course was how to think outside the box. I was able to develop new skills of detail reading and thinking. Another thing I learned was annotating my thoughts with complete sentences. This allowed me to think freely, but also little by little it gave birth to awesome and newer ideas. Third thing I learned was how to write an "essay". I loved how much freedom we had to write our essays and I enjoyed the process of focusing on something we found really interesting.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much! Coming into the course, I was really nervous because I didn't have much experience reading Shakespeare. It was great to be surrounded by actors in the class who could help me better read and decipher the plays as we covered them.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I feel like I learned how to closely read Shakespeare and hone in my analytical skills, especially with medieval works.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a sense of the theatrical... an better understanding of how the written word can be played with in many ways, and nuance can be created through acting decisions... This changed the way I think about performance in dialogue and conversation in general

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. The art of attention! How to read Shakespeare with extreme attention and empathy
2. How to understand Shakespeare from a formal perspective, how his tragedies, comedies and romances work as drama. 
3. How to discuss and argue the texts with an emphasis on the words themselves.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much in this class, both about Shakespeare in general (trajectories in his work, frameworks for evaluating the plays) and about several individual plays! I also improved my close reading and argument writing skills.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
Class discussion.
Saying which character you'd play and why. 
Reading beautiful sections from the text aloud in class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Beckwith and Effie were such incredible instructors. They are so knowledgable about Shakespeare but also care incredibly deeply about what everyone has to say :)

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dedicating each week to a different play was a great way of structuring the class. For future versions of the course, I would consider removing a play or two from the list to be able to dedicate two full classes to each play, and also have a workshop day.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that the professor did an excellent job at keeping discussions engaging. In a class with no technology, this can be difficult. The seminar style also worked really long

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think it would be nice to have each person bring in a question so that everyone gets the chance to speak. It felt like there were some loud voices in the class, and I didn't always feel like there was space for everyone to bring up their points.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
