question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed being part of this class because everyone was actively engaged and always eager to learn. I like the amount of time the professor spent talking about Shakespeare, the use of the board to get a better sense of what was being taught, and the activities we had throughout the course like sharing our favorite characters, Shakespeare story, etc.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed how we spent longer on the plays that required more analysis! It gave us room to really unpack the plays we felt the most passionate about.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think Professor Beckwith has a lot of passion for shakespeare.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Encouraged participation

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Beckwith has an incredible ear for the words and through this ability guides us in understanding/appreciating Shakespeare. I like how open-ended and listening-oriented her classes are.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Beckwith is a wonderful professor— so kind, caring, knowledgeable, and genuinely interested in what her students think. I loved learning from her and having interesting discussions in class. I also liked that our first written assignment was a more informal, explorative essay and the second one was a formal research paper— this helped me develop different skills and appreciate different forms of academic writing.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Made me consider the impact of religious and cultural ideas on the way in which people write.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think that the plays that we only spent one class on made reading the play feel a little pointless. I'd also appreciate connecting pop culture into the course a little more just so we can see some more modern applications of these plays (and see how these adaptations connect or do not connect to nature).

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I loved Dr. Beckwith's analysis. I could listen to her speak forever.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The wide variety of plays we got to explore, which expanded my familiarity with Shakespeare's works, and how those can connect to the world from an environmental standpoint.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: That nature journal made it interesting and something new. It is like a diary for this class that we get to keep forever. I want to continue reading Shakespeare and completing my nature journal.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Professor Beckwith is very knowledgeable about the content and was able to provide important context.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I wish the class was more interactive and we read more during class. A performance aspect would be fun!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Everything--the text are just so incredible that they're almost infinitely stimulating and Dr. Beckwith is incredible at leading us through them

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I was so happy to take a class on Shakespeare that delved into so many wonderful plays!! The nature angle was fascinating, and the order in which we read the plays was so thoughtful and interesting— the plays truly seemed to speak to one another, and it helped me understand each play differently, even ones I’d already read.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Your vocabulary, ability to read for comprehension, eloquence, scholarship, and cultural capital will all greatly improve by taking this course and studying this much Shakespeare.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would love to be able to take this course again. As this was my first time reading any Shakespeare, this was such the perfect environment to learn about these works.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! And take any Shakespeare course with Dr. Beckwith. They've all been fantastic so far and you learn to read Shakespeare's plays in a different light. Amazing course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Pretty interesting and not too much work. Few graded assignments, but the professor is very willing to help you out with assignments and essay planning.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! There is space for people who are non english majors too, just be prepared for a lot of essay writing.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Start brainstorming your essay topics earlier, as you read the plays.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a great way to get introduce to Shakespeare. For example, I have never read Shakespeare before and was always scared it will be hard. However, with this course, the professor was always explaining the plot and leading us to thinking different meanings within nature. I love how we got through a lot of stories in just one semester. I really fell in love with his writing, Shakespeare takes you to this whole new world. I am very grateful for this class and the professor because I got so much from it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a great course to better understand Shakespeare!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Enjoy! Have fun reading and watching plays

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Professor Beckwith is extremely enthusiastic about Shakespeare, and her passion is passed on to the students in her class! We are encouraged to voice our own opinions, whether or not they contradict hers. She has a great respect for each student's perspective.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Dive in as much as you can

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this class (or if not this one, something else with Dr. Beckwith)!! It’s one of my favorite classes I’ve taken at Duke. To be fair, I already knew I loved Shakespeare before I took the class, but it seems like even students who weren’t as experienced with Shakespeare enjoyed the class. You will have to do a lot of reading— it helps if you watch the plays instead of just reading them (take advantage of Duke Libraries’ access to wonderful productions by companies like the RSC, Stratford Festival of Canada, and Globe Theater), but also have a copy with good notes in the margins (like the Folger or Arden edition). There are only two major written assignments, which means that each one counts a lot in your grade, but I didn’t mind because it meant that for most of the course we could focus on reading the plays and discussing them in class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Traditional english class skills like reading/writing/deciphering a text, some engagement with the lives of important authors who wrote some short fiction, learned some background on Europe as a continent and as an idea in modern times

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to read more critically, analyze literature on a deeper level, and compare works of grouped literature(s) (by nationality, language, time period, theme, etc.)

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The scope of modern European fiction, critical thinking skills, active reading

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- coming from a German student background, learning a plethora of new authors and important works from other European cultures 
- the thematic nature of the class allowed me to compare seemingly different works 
- analyzing film and visual art pieces (Nasher visit!) as well

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a bit about Kafka's life. I learned how to speed read. I had to figure out how to do a group project and work with others.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor was really well-prepared for all classes and could discuss basically all aspects of the book in a pretty engaging way. Regardless of what point got brought up, they always had an interesting way to facilitate good discussion about it. They seemed to have a lot of slides, I feel like they could've conducted a lecture twice as long if needed (and I mean that in a good way!).

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Our professor had wonderful and very well-made slides for each of our classes, with plenty of topics to choose from to discuss. I was very impressed with how knowledgeable and well prepared she was, and thought that if anything, Professor Ziolkowski should speak more on what she thinks rather than ceding the floor to us, though the discussions were also quite informative.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We became well-versed in modern European short fiction and the genre's many renowned authors, such as Kafka, Svevo, Joyce, Woolf, Dostoevsky, Pirandello, Mann, Sartre, Camus, etc. We examined these works through the lens of five primary themes—animals, family and home, love, guilt, and the Holocaust—and determined how the stories can be categorized under one or more of these themes. We learned the distinction between modernism, post-modernism, existentialism, absurdism, communism, syndicalism, anarchism, and other ideologies in a literary context. We had the privilege of visiting the Rare Books library and picking works to analyze closely and the Nasher to look at the works of Chagall, Dali, and other relevant artists, as well as to do a compare/contrast essay on a short story and its film adaptation. These experiences allowed us to appreciate the important differences between different media: short vs. long-form fiction, final versions vs. galley proofs, film, and art. I also learned how to write a concise but effective paper, since our longest paper had a limit of three pages. Lastly, I learned how to appropriately analyze a short story by taking into consideration the plot, characters, author, and political/social implications.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how to analyze literary works in relation to their  historical context. I learned about surrealism in literature and I also learned about the impact of stylistic features and literary devices (as similitudes or imagery) on the reader.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze writing styles, word choice, and how to access the rarebook library.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think my analytical writing improved. I gained a better understanding and general knowledge of European literature.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Got better at analytical writing, was exposed to writers of Europe's past, and got better at interpretive reading.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained substantial knowledge of authors, works, and movements that are significant to European literature.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I love the way the course was structured, both the overarching structure of different themes for different groups of stories and the day-to-day structure of reading 1-5 short stories for class, coming to class to discuss in-depth, and then writing a short paper about a handful of these stories later on. I loved the unique opportunities the class had to offer, namely the Rare Books and Nasher visits and Francesca Magario guest lecture (I loved that lecture!). I loved the variety of papers: the close reading of a Kafka short short story, Rare Books object paper, animal research paper, and film and passage comparison essay. This is also the only humanities class in which I've had an exam, but I think it made sense to include it as an assessment because it forced me to stay on top of the readings (and come to class) and not just skim them. It meant I thoroughly read each story to learn the author's style and the story's influence. Professor Z is very insightful, prepared for class, engaging, and accommodating with deadlines, and she really shines when her students reciprocate an interest in the content. I was in a class with her last semester where the students were in general less engaged, which I think limited her teaching. This time around, most of the class came having done the readings with interesting takeaways/interpretations and ready to discuss, and this meant she could offer more as a professor as well. The professor and the students, in addition to the stories we read, made this class truly one of my favorites that I have taken at Duke.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class continuously operated in a space between discussion and lecture that I don't think was best. First off, it couldn't really operate as a discussion with there being 25 people in the class. I think breaking up classes, or parts of each class, into either lecture or discussion would be more engaging and let the material stick more. I think students would get more out of it that way.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this course if you can! It was one of my favorite classes that I have taken at Duke. The readings are both thought-provoking and entertaining, as are the in-class discussions we had about them. By the end of the course, you'll be able to say that you're well-versed in modern European short fiction authors like Kafka, Joyce, Woolf, Dostoevsky, Mann, Sartre, Camus, etc. You get to do some cool out-of-class excursions too, like to the Rare Books library and the Nasher. The professor is very knowledgeable, effectively facilitates class discussions, and is very accommodating with deadlines. Plus the papers are very short (max 3 pages). There is one exam where you have to match 12 or so quotes to their author/work and write about the immediate context and significance of the quote, but it is very doable if you do all the readings and come to class consistently. I genuinely have no criticisms of this class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The prospect of reading and analyzing plays was itself a new methodology for me, and one I'm please to say I have enjoyed. Reading plays is a unique skill and I think this course did a fantastic job providing some guidance on how to do that without ever coddling or resorting to a "how to read theater" style lecture. In terms of insights, I think the course provided an outlook on the breadth and depth of American literature genres, styles, and movements in the past century or so, and has generally made more more eager and open to further exploring the category.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor D'Alessandro was exceptionally receptive to all idea regarding each play. Art is subjective, and he never made us feel like our opinion was wrong as long as we could back it up with evidence from the text. He was very open to admitting if one of our points had changed his mind or was a new way of interpreting the play.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved this class a lot. I'm sad it's ending. Professor D'Alessandro created a super warm, fun, and welcoming class environment that fostered a lot of lively discussion about the text and got everyone engaged regardless of their personal background (or lack thereof) with theater. He was always willing to chat about the text and clearly cared about us as students and people. I liked the pace of the class—I felt super accomplished that I read like 2 texts a week in the class. I like the response posts and the fact that they are on Monday was helpful because I could read and think over the weekend and felt like I could take risk because there was low-stakes grading. I really enjoy the lectures at the start of class, especially learning about a playwright's background and watching clips of the texts live. The conference structure before essays was helpful. My peer review drafts were always horrible but at least they forced me to get something on the page. I also really liked the variety of plays we read, especially the political plays at the end and how different they felt from more abstract expressionism stuff at the beginning. The bad choices assignment was also fun.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Strandberg's lectures were filled with interesting and relevant information. The exams were very fair and the expectations were clear– as long as I attended every class, listened carefully, took good notes, and studied them in detail, I was prepared. Because he grades the exams on a curve, using the highest grade in the class as the standard for an A, if there is any material that the class as a whole does not understand, no one is penalized for it. I did not write the optional term paper because I was satisfied with my exam grades, but it seemed like a good option for anyone who might have struggled with the exams and preferred to have an opportunity to write a paper. The professor was understanding, reasonable, and approchable, and the classroom environment was welcoming and engaging.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a great course to take if you're looking to fulfill the Area III requirement for the English major or just to take an engaging literature course with an excellent professor. You would be hard-pressed to find a professor at Duke who is as passionate and knowledgeable about early 20th-century American literature, not to mention as experienced and legendary, as Victor Strandberg is. Even though some of the authors we studied are not my favorite (Hemingway, Faulkner, Updike), I truly enjoyed the lectures and appreciated the opportunity to learn more about this pivotal moment in American literary history. One interesting part of this course is that unlike most English classes, which are writing-based, center on discussions, and encourage you to develop your own opinions, this course is exam-based and is mostly about listening to lectures, memorizing as much as you can, and repeating what was said in class on each of the exams. One of my friends who took the class with me joked that she was losing her ability to think for herself, and to a limited extent, I agreed, but it was nice to take this course that was a different structure than the other English classes I was taking. Even though my interpretations of the readings were very much guided by what Professor Strandberg believed, I didn't doubt his ideas, given that he is such an expert, and I still developed my own opinions, just in a different course structure than I was used to.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyse theatre critically and (somewhat) objectively, some of the history of theatre in London, and what it means to be a tourist.

response_text:
I developed stronger skills in analyzing my surroundings in relation to my own personal experiences.
I gained a wider view of art, through multiple mediums, and gained comprehension of my own artistic goals and desires.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Cross-cultural analysis of London's arts scene and the United States (theater, dance, visual arts, street art, etc.)
- The effects of government subsidization and other funding sources on arts production
- Evaluating art from both a disciplinary and personal perspective (and combining those two perspectives into ethnographic research)

response_text: I learned how to approach theatre, art, tourism, and global communities in New ways. I learned how to evaluate productions. I also learned how to evaluate my place in London.

Artistic evaluation as a discipline

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I also learned about my comfort living in a large city as a potential place for living after college.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a knowledge of eras, how those eras and the events during shaped the thoughts of philosophers during those times, and how those philosophers built thoughts on previous thoughts. And all of this knowledge was achieved through reading prominent, classic literature that we were able to learn how to interpret and interact with in order to gain philosophical insights from them. It was very interesting how each philosopher's circumstances drove their thinking, and how that thinking was able to be built upon and developed over time throughout many more eras and philosophers. And it was all about arguably the most important question one can ask themselves: what is the meaning of life? I was able to learn more about philosophers who thought there is an inherent meaning to life and what that meaning looked like to them, that there is not meaning to life, or that certain factors/experiences/mindsets could give one meaning.

response_text: I would say that the content is very interesting and that you learn, what I think, is an essential way of thinking in life. response_text: Professor Henry worked more than most any of my professors here to engage the class in not only understanding the material, but applying it to itself and to modern society. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The class is super easy, but not the most exciting. I would definitely recommend it for a low-stress senior year, but you probably won't get as much out of it as you think.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned not only how to further analyze the writing of Nobel prize winners themselves, but also how to unpack the historical and social contexts behind them. By covering a new work of literature every week, we got a sense of the type of writing that earns this sort of recognition, in addition to an understanding of the breadth of form and topics that have been awarded the Nobel Prize.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Reading a book a week and analysis readings critically, it also helped with writing literary texts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to read cross-textually and consider themes that persisted across all texts. I learned how to place texts in their historical, political, social environments. I learned how to bring in philosophical ideologies when reading texts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Critical thinking, analytical writing, literary criticism.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Critical Analysis of Literature: One of the most significant skills I developed in this course was the ability to critically analyze literary works. We learned to dissect complex texts, examining their themes, narrative structures, character development, and use of language. This involved not only understanding the surface-level content but also interpreting the deeper meanings and societal implications. 
Historical and Cultural Contextualization: The course enhanced my ability to place literary works within their historical and cultural contexts. This skill was crucial in understanding the significance of each author's work in their time and its lasting impact.
Diverse Perspectives and Empathetic Understanding: Engaging with a broad range of authors from different cultural backgrounds greatly enhanced my ability to appreciate diverse perspectives. This course encouraged an empathetic approach to literature, urging us to understand and respect viewpoints and experiences different from our own.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think more analytically about a literary text. I improved my skills in close reading, synthesizing my thoughts, and identifying themes that run throughout a piece.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Creative thinking and critical analysis

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Historical and cultural context in which prominent works of the 20th century were written. 
- Techniques and frames with which we can analyze literary texts 
- Practice writing interpretive essays.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The course provided extremely interesting insights into the literary "greats" of the 20th century and into different cultures. I learned about the roles of bystanders/authors and the many tragedies that have shaped certain countries and communities.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to how to relate history with personal experiences, close reading analysis, and the more historical background on the communism and colonization.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned so much. We learned a lot about history and philosophy, and I think our explorations of so many texts in such depth made me a better critical reader and writer.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Our discussions of Nobel Prize-winning literature let us view these works through the lens of the author's personal background, the communal context in which they lived, and the goal with which they wrote—and of course, touched on colonialism as a recurrent theme in all the novels, short stories, dramas, poetry, and essays! I thought that although it was primarily lecture-based, I still felt that I was engaged and interested in each topic covered.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The discussions were very helpful to actually get to talk to about things that were sometimes too complex for me to understand on my own.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors were the smartest people I've ever heard. Their lectures were incredibly insightful and I feel like I walked away from each class with new knowledge and insight and ways of looking at texts. I loved the discussion in class as well as the pre-responses to facilitate engagement.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I would definitely keep the class discussion component, it was super engaging, as well as the introductions about the authors.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Pfau and Professor Stan are two of the most intelligent and well-spoken people I have ever met. Learning from them was invaluable.

But even with a less enthusiastic group, this class is fantastic. The professors do everything in their power to encourage engagement and support anyone who might be struggling.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: TAKE IT! it's one of the best classes I've ever taken and SO rewarding.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! You will feel so much more informed about world literature and will be forced to think in such a fascinating way.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's a lot of work, but very worth taking.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: TAKE IT. lots of work but fantastic

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are willing to challenge your literary analysis skills and time management, go for it. The class is not easy whatsoever, but is worth it due to how intellectually stimulating and thought provoking it is. If you are wanting to expand the authors/works you've read or learn about last century Europe through a literary lens, this class is great.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course requires a lot of reading, but challenges students to think critically and explore how literature and history intertwine.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is an ESSENTIAL course. You would be doing yourself a disservice not to take it. The texts you engage with and the skills you acquire will bolster your learning for the rest of your life. This should be a required class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Journalism

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I developed a deeper understanding of the societal impact of journalism, learned to evaluate it from diverse perspectives, and gained familiarity with various storytelling forms and evolving methods. The exposure to superior reporting and writing and an AMAZING, artfully curated lineup of guest speakers enhanced my research and writing skills, and the exploration of social issues expanded my cultural/historical knowledge.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course fundamentally altered the way in which I view my Duke education. Frank Bruni went above and beyond what it means to be a college professor and in the process helped shape the way in which I view my future career. I garnered the knowledge to engage critically with masterworks of journalism, how to speak to (super impressive) people with confidence and intelligence, and how to be a better eriter!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course helped me grow a lot as a critical thinker and as a writer. I have always loved writing, but have never taken a journalism class before so it was really exciting to get to write pieces about current events and issues that matter in the world today.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Concise language, ability to probe a question from multiple vantage points, journalistic ethics

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I've become a much better writer because of this course. 
I have a much better idea of what good long-form journalism looks like.
I've read some amazing writing that I had no idea about before this course. 
By exposing me to some of the best examples of writing that do so, this course has made me think a lot about how to make connections between seemingly disparate things. I believe that I will continue to actively do so in my daily life.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I had never taken a journalism course before, and I certainly learned what good journalism reads like, and how to get my writing closer to that. I also talked to many individuals who have devoted their lives to writing in various ways, which has allowed me to get a better understanding of my own future after college.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. How to analyze what elements comprise a good piece of journalistic prose.
2. How to explore different forms of written response to satisfy various writing goals.
3. The goals and motivations of journalists.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: By reading some of the best journalism and discussing what made it so excellent, my writing skills improved tremendously, as well as my ability to read thoughtfully and critically.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Writing, critical reading, appreciation of writing

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Good readings

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Frank truly does a commendable job engaging every single student in this class and making each contribution feel important and worthwhile. He makes sure time is shared fairly and appropriately and does his due diligence entertaining different perspectives. Frank is always professional and prepared, but also adaptable. It was always exciting to come to class and see where he would take us with the material. I particularly liked when he picked specific marvelous sentences out of the readings to share with us.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The interviews were incredible (guest speakers), the readings were astonishing, and the open class debate format was exceptional.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed having speakers come in to begin our discussions about the readings and topics we were learning about. It gave us an interest insight into what we were learning and also helped us "warm our brains up" to the topics we were discussing.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Loved the guest speakers. Such a privilege to be able to ask them questions of our own. The varied reading assignments kept the class super engaging throughout

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
This class was really special. I'm reflecting on the number of great writers and thinkers I've been able to engage with through this class-- both directly and through their writing. It's truly astounding. If I'm counting correctly I've had the chance to speak to six Pulitzer Prize winners. It makes feel really grateful to be at Duke.
Even though it was a two and a half hour class, I never felt disengaged on bored. The way our time was divided between discussing our readings, hearing from guest speakers, and reflecting on what we heard in the context of what we'd learnt made every minute of each session very interesting. I also feel that the workload was very reasonable.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The comments that both Matt Schossler and Professor Bruni left on my writing were insightful and motivated me to put more effort into my assignments. Additionally, having regular speakers from a variety of backgrounds has strengthened my understanding of what being a writer entails.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Out of all the professors I've had, Professor Bruni was the best discussion leader I've had the opportunity to learn under. In the safest way possible, Professor Bruni was able to bring dissent and unique opinions into our discussions. Every reading was also very interesting. Probably one of my top two favorite classes at Duke University.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class structure encouraged class discussion, and breaking it up into half-speaker and half-discussion made the long class time not feel too lengthy.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Frank was an incredible professor. He is one of the smartest people I've ever met and he facilitated conversations that were thought-provoking, intellectual, and open-minded. He also brought in fantastic guest speakers - the most engaging group of speakers I've ever seen.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Challenge in the writing assignments did help me appreciate the arduous process of writing the pieces that we read, and content of pieces was relevant and interesting

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I thought the guest speakers and readings were generally interesting. The instructor was friendly, intelligent, and made himself available to meet with students.

response_text: Great material, excellent speakers

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:

I wasn't always sure what was most important to focus on, and it was difficult to retain everything.)

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Professor Bruni's insights and meeting true MASTERS of journalism each week we could speak to.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was fascinating to hear about current events and getting to speak about them in a journalistic context. I have never taken a journalism class before and I wish I had taken this class earlier so I could consider doing the journalism certificate.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Varied texts, varied speakers, engaging lectures

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Everything we read expanded my perspective on what journalism can be. All the people we got to speak to-- including Professor Bruni-- were incredibly thoughtful and wise. They all left me with a lot to think about. It was very intellectually stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The readings that Professor Bruni chose made the class particularly stimulating. He knows good journalism and makes it accessible to his students. He also provides unique opportunities to talk to influential figures across a variety of fields, including politics and academia.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The variety of topics, the quality of guest speakers, and the ability to discuss ideas instead of just listening to them.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The assignments were perhaps a bit too concerned with following directions rather than growing as a writer, particularly for a course that was cross-listed in English.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Guest speakers were great for contextualizing pieces and getting clarification

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Should take it, will read great stuff, talk to interesting people, and learn new things

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's not just that you won't regret taking this course. You will regret NOT taking this course. Being able to hear Frank speak about his experiences, career, and network alone would be worthwhile, but the speakers and readings will also broaden your horizons, help you learn more about yourself and your world, and make you feel accomplished.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this course if you want your life to be changed. Period. If you have all bad professors at Duke but you take this class once, you will leave satisfied with your experience.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take it!! It may be a lot of work at times but it so rewarding because the discussions and conversations are super interesting and relevant and really force you to critically think about the world around you. I would honestly take this class a second time if I had room in my schedule.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Prepare questions in advance of every class

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it you want to think! You won't be disappointed.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Every reading is intentional and worth doing. Not all classes at Duke are like that, and it is a great opportunity to read good writing.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's rare to be able to take courses from people who have existed for large swaths of time outside of academia, so it is really nice to be able to learn from people with other types of life experiences.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Whether or not a student is an aspiring journalist, taking a class with Frank and engaging with the materials he compiles is such a special experience. He is amazing to listen to and talk to, so kind, and facilitates productive conversations about powerful pieces of journalism.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Don't take the grading too harshly, and take time to actually read the assigned pieces - worth it

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You might enjoy it if you're already a Bruni superfan, or if you really like discussion based courses. Someone studying public policy or journalism would probably be most at home here. Personally, this course was not my cup of tea, and I wouldn't necessarily recommend it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned not only how to further analyze the writing of Nobel prize winners themselves, but also how to unpack the historical and social contexts behind them. By covering a new work of literature every week, we got a sense of the type of writing that earns this sort of recognition, in addition to an understanding of the breadth of form and topics that have been awarded the Nobel Prize.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Reading a book a week and analysis readings critically, it also helped with writing literary texts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to read cross-textually and consider themes that persisted across all texts. I learned how to place texts in their historical, political, social environments. I learned how to bring in philosophical ideologies when reading texts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Critical thinking, analytical writing, literary criticism.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Critical Analysis of Literature: One of the most significant skills I developed in this course was the ability to critically analyze literary works. We learned to dissect complex texts, examining their themes, narrative structures, character development, and use of language. This involved not only understanding the surface-level content but also interpreting the deeper meanings and societal implications. 
Historical and Cultural Contextualization: The course enhanced my ability to place literary works within their historical and cultural contexts. This skill was crucial in understanding the significance of each author's work in their time and its lasting impact.
Diverse Perspectives and Empathetic Understanding: Engaging with a broad range of authors from different cultural backgrounds greatly enhanced my ability to appreciate diverse perspectives. This course encouraged an empathetic approach to literature, urging us to understand and respect viewpoints and experiences different from our own.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think more analytically about a literary text. I improved my skills in close reading, synthesizing my thoughts, and identifying themes that run throughout a piece.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Creative thinking and critical analysis

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Historical and cultural context in which prominent works of the 20th century were written. 
- Techniques and frames with which we can analyze literary texts 
- Practice writing interpretive essays.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The course provided extremely interesting insights into the literary "greats" of the 20th century and into different cultures. I learned about the roles of bystanders/authors and the many tragedies that have shaped certain countries and communities.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to how to relate history with personal experiences, close reading analysis, and the more historical background on the communism and colonization.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned so much. We learned a lot about history and philosophy, and I think our explorations of so many texts in such depth made me a better critical reader and writer.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Our discussions of Nobel Prize-winning literature let us view these works through the lens of the author's personal background, the communal context in which they lived, and the goal with which they wrote—and of course, touched on colonialism as a recurrent theme in all the novels, short stories, dramas, poetry, and essays! I thought that although it was primarily lecture-based, I still felt that I was engaged and interested in each topic covered.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The discussions were very helpful to actually get to talk to about things that were sometimes too complex for me to understand on my own.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

I loved the discussion in class as well as the pre-responses to facilitate engagement.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I would definitely keep the class discussion component, it was super engaging, as well as the introductions about the authors.

course: ENGLISH-290S-02 : SP TOP IN LANG. & LIT.ENGLISH-290S-02.ICS-290S-02.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned how to use data mining software to distant analyze text
2) I became more comfortable with group discussions and contributing
3) I learned how to closely analyze text better

course: ENGLISH-290S-02 : SP TOP IN LANG. & LIT.ENGLISH-290S-02.ICS-290S-02.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I had never taken a coding class before or studying computational methods, and this class taught me how to use three different softwares: Orange, Voyant, and Python, do conduct Digital Humanities literary analysis. I also learned how to complete Distant Reading, a method of Digital Humanities used to analyze a text more in-depth and with contrasting texts being considered. Finally, I also learned more about Dystopian Literature where I had not had much exposure in the past besides Orwell and Bradbury, which broadened my literary horizons.

course: ENGLISH-290S-02 : SP TOP IN LANG. & LIT.ENGLISH-290S-02.ICS-290S-02.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned various techniques of distant reading and different programs to use when conducting a distant reading analysis. Programs such as Orange, Voyant, Python, and more were all very helpful and interesting when analyzing a book using code. I also learned to use StoryMaps as a presentation tool which I really enjoyed. Besides distant reading, I also became acquainted with various texts that I felt could be applied to other classes surrounding the issue of race, borders, and immigration. I felt that I gained a new perspective on these issues and can apply them elsewhere. Lastly, I also expanded my writing skills and feel that I have had growth in writing essays.

course: ENGLISH-290S-02 : SP TOP IN LANG. & LIT.ENGLISH-290S-02.ICS-290S-02.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Developed skills in close reading, critically engaging with texts, distant reading, and building arguments. Got lots of practice in reading academic/scholarly texts, as well as more literary novels.  I now have a much better idea of how to do close reading, improving in my ability to narrow down on a specific statement/syntax while also placing the analysis into the larger context. The selection and order of pieces we analyzed helped to develop and explore the idea of dystopia in different ways, giving practice in connecting multiple ideas and reinforcing the topics we learned.

course: ENGLISH-290S-02 : SP TOP IN LANG. & LIT.ENGLISH-290S-02.ICS-290S-02.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I developed the ability to do both distant reading and close reading for texts, as well as the ability to participate in a group discussion and share my own opinions.

course: ENGLISH-290S-02 : SP TOP IN LANG. & LIT.ENGLISH-290S-02.ICS-290S-02.

response_text: Professor Luthra is always very welcoming and charismatic. It is clear to see that he is very passionate about what he is teaching and truly cares about our thoughts during discussion. I think that the discussion posts are helpful to prepare for class and prevent discussion coming to a halt if people do not come prepared.

course: ENGLISH-290S-02 : SP TOP IN LANG. & LIT.ENGLISH-290S-02.ICS-290S-02.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

course: ENGLISH-290S-03 : SP TOP IN LANG. & LIT.ENGLISH-290S-03.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about Chinua Achebe's working from Things Fall Apart all the way through to Anthills of Savannah. I learned how to engage with other critical scholars in written essays on Achebe's work. I also learned about important events in Nigeria's history like the Biafran war.

course: ENGLISH-290S-03 : SP TOP IN LANG. & LIT.ENGLISH-290S-03.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a greater understanding of Chinua Achebe, his literature, and the context under which it was developed. This class explored the intersection of history and literature and encouraged me to analyze complex theories of conflict, gender, and African literature.

course: ENGLISH-290S-03 : SP TOP IN LANG. & LIT.ENGLISH-290S-03.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course deepened my, at first, surface-level understanding of African literature and particularly how Achebe’s works challenge colonial narratives and "wrote back" as a distinctly African/Nigerian genre. I also developed skills in close reading and contextual analysis, particularly in examining Achebe’s use of language to preserve, create, and elevate African storytelling traditions, while the research component taught me how to use literary scholarship to inform and strengthen my interpretations.  The interdisciplinary approach combining history and literature helped me see African literature as both art with important political and cultural significance . Overall, the course gave me a richer perspective on African history, culture, and postcolonial identity.

course: ENGLISH-290S-03 : SP TOP IN LANG. & LIT.ENGLISH-290S-03.

response_text: I learned how to effectively write an English essay, learned about African writers and African literature, and I learned about the sociopolitical context in African countries during the time of Achebe.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I learned a lot about the historical context behind Shakespeare plays and how that context can be recontextualized through adaptation for a modern audience. I really enjoyed this class as a means of thinking more deeply about film as a medium and how it connects to more historical mediums like plays.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Close and wide engagement with Shakespeare in text, across genre/culture in adaptation through various mediums, and written articulation of thoughts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned about film techniques (sound, camera angles, mise en scene, etc.) which I did not know much about before
2. I learned about the different definitions of what it means for a movie to be an "adaptation" of something and that adaptations are not merely derivative of the text
3. I learned how to closely analyze the language Shakespeare uses throughout his texts

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze films which is something I've never done before, especially putting them in conversation with texts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I never know what to write for this question because it is hard to come up with a new method or skill you learn in every class. I really enjoyed all of the plays though. I think it was fun to be able to see traces of his different plays bleeding into each other a little.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We went deep into analyzing Shakespeare texts as well as adaptations. I had never engaged with films like we did in this class, using cinematic terminology to discuss and analyze them. I think overall this made me more observant and a better reader/thinker.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze Shakespeare, Shakespearian films, and how to discuss aspects of Shakespearian literature.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about film techniques and terminology as well as read some scholarship on films (e.g. Mulvey's 'male gaze' theory). I read and reflected on a diverse range of Shakespeare plays and how they can be adapted into different times and cultures.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciated the freedom we have in when to submit our written responses and what we could write about.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the use of "gobbets" as a means of prompting analysis. They're a relatively low-stakes way to engage with whatever we're reading or watching, and I really enjoyed getting the feedback on it. It always felt like our professor was really interested in whatever we wrote about and why it struck us in particular. I also really enjoyed the balance between watching clips to spark discussion and letting us guide discussion naturally through conversation with each other.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Derek does such an incredible job at facilitating open discussion - he takes everyone's points seriously and is clearly so informed/knowledgeable on these plays. Writing our gobbets (reading responses, 8 total at any point in the semester) allowed me to synthesize my thoughts across the plays and their adaptations, and they were really accessible ways with engaging closely with the week's topics. Derek really made this class so fun, and his selections of the readings/plays/films were fantastic.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Derek made the course extremely conversational, allowing me to develop different perspectives on each text we read and movie we saw. He encouraged people to disagree with him, which left lots of room for independent analytical thought. I would keep this teaching style for future classes. Additionally, watching a variety of different Shakespeare adaptations, some strict and some loose, facilitated my understanding of what it means for a film to be an adaptation. I would continue showing films from different time periods and cultures in the future.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I thought Derek found a wonderful balance between lecture and seminar, which is something I've struggled with in classes before. I absolutely loved this course and think Derek would make a wonderful professor.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about love in all of its forms in the context of poetry, the bible, novels, and philosophy. I particularly loved Julian and Norwich, Plato's Symposium, and Iris Murdoch- and of course, ALL the Shakespeare we read was incredible!

course: ENGLISH-290S-1-02 : SP TOP MEDIEVAL/EARLY MOD LIT.ENGLISH-290S-1-02.MEDREN-290S-1-02.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: i analyzed love through many medieval works, include a couple of contemporary ones, specifically iris murdoch. through these texts, i built a lexicon of love, building a bank of greek and latin words as they relate to love. i also improved my writing by synthesizing what i learned in two essays.

course: ENGLISH-290S-1-02 : SP TOP MEDIEVAL/EARLY MOD LIT.ENGLISH-290S-1-02.MEDREN-290S-1-02.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: My ability to read — and to really digest my reading — improved drastically in this course. I say this as an avid reader, who has been an English major since the beginning of my college career. But I think the breadth of work we undertook for this course simply made me a better reader, a better scholar of literature.I learned, in this course, how to compare topics across different disciplines. Comparing Christian theology to Shakespeare's comedies seems a bit of a stretch, at first thought, but I have learned how to hold ideas up against one another even if they are different in form and subject. I loved that we read so many different types of literature in this class, from novel to drama to philosophy.I learned a lot about Christian philosophy, which I think is very necessary for an English major, and maybe not taught quite enough in other courses.

course: ENGLISH-290S-1-02 : SP TOP MEDIEVAL/EARLY MOD LIT.ENGLISH-290S-1-02.MEDREN-290S-1-02.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Through this course I learned how to interpret philosophy and how to apply it to classical writings, such as Shakespeare, and more modern pieces. The course texts gave me a different perspective on religious texts and I believe that the course dynamic allowed for great conversation.

course: ENGLISH-290S-1-02 : SP TOP MEDIEVAL/EARLY MOD LIT.ENGLISH-290S-1-02.MEDREN-290S-1-02.

course: ENGLISH-290S-1-02 : SP TOP MEDIEVAL/EARLY MOD LIT.ENGLISH-290S-1-02.MEDREN-290S-1-02.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

I think it would have been effective if there were clearer expectations for our journals so that we knew how to budget our time and what to, specifically do with them. They were helpful in how they gave us the opportunity to think broadly and freely but lacked some structure.  I liked the structure of each classes discussion a lot.
