question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The conversations we had in this class were engaging and fascinating. Prof Beckwith did an amazing job bringing in new perspectives and facilitating the conversation. The learning environment was welcoming and positive. I truly learned so much and felt like I ready such an amazing variety of texts!

course: ENGLISH-290S-1-02 : SP TOP MEDIEVAL/EARLY MOD LIT.ENGLISH-290S-1-02.MEDREN-290S-1-02.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: dr. sarah beckwith had immense knowledge on all the course material, she was able to readily provide background and open discussion on any question we had. it made it a very good environment to learn about the works, because we were able to play around and mold our idea of them by our discussions in-class, while having a very knowledgeable resource there to keep us on track. the commonplace book kept you on task when it came to taking away themes that you worked with before, during and after analyzing the text. the essays pushed us to dive deeper into topics we were interested in as they were brought up in class discussion, leaving no loose ends as the course wrapped up.

course: ENGLISH-290S-1-02 : SP TOP MEDIEVAL/EARLY MOD LIT.ENGLISH-290S-1-02.MEDREN-290S-1-02.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I found that this class struck a nice balance between Professor Beckwith lecturing and us students discussing our own ideas. I often find that English classes tend to lean too far one way or the other. As much as I value the discussion of my peers, I want to be taught by my professor. This class achieved that balance perfectly — we discussed our thoughts, and debated them at times, but I also filled my notebook with lecture notes about the writers we engaged with.

course: ENGLISH-290S-1-02 : SP TOP MEDIEVAL/EARLY MOD LIT.ENGLISH-290S-1-02.MEDREN-290S-1-02.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I love the classroom environment Professor Beckwith created. We each had the freedom to say how we interpreted texts, even if we were not confident. The variety of texts made this course engaging and relevant. I definitely found that the things I was learning and the literature I was being exposed to were ideas that I was able to apply to contexts outside of our classroom. I do wish that we would spend more time on each texts, especially The Black Prince. Towards the end of the semester it felt like we were trying to get in as much information as possible, and didn't have the ability to explore texts the way that we were with Aristotle and Plato. Additionally, I think the set up of professor lecturing for 10 minutes and then giving us the opportunity to discuss was very effective and hearing the contexts of texts and how they have been interpreted throughout time allowed me to feel more confident in my discussion. Lastly, I appreciated that there was so much freedom in the essay prompts.

course: ENGLISH-290S-1-02 : SP TOP MEDIEVAL/EARLY MOD LIT.ENGLISH-290S-1-02.MEDREN-290S-1-02.
question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Professor Beckwith is brilliant. I could sit back and hear her thoughts on all the texts all day if that were a class option.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: We had great discussions, read good books, and were given the opportunity to both think from ourselves and learn from Professor Beckwith.

course: ENGLISH-290S-1-02 : SP TOP MEDIEVAL/EARLY MOD LIT.ENGLISH-290S-1-02.MEDREN-290S-1-02.
question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The material in and of itself I found to be fascinating. Yes, some weeks were hard, especially reading old english, but it was part of the process of this class! Looking back, I appreciated reading it.

course: ENGLISH-290S-1-02 : SP TOP MEDIEVAL/EARLY MOD LIT.ENGLISH-290S-1-02.MEDREN-290S-1-02.
question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: i think the way dr. beckwith framed this course from the very beginning with the focus on classical languages and the root words to love made it interesting from the start. the knowledge she gave to us throughout also pushed you to think about the text in ways you hadn't before. if the discussions were laid out like the "bounce back and forth style" i think it would be more intellectually stimulating.

course: ENGLISH-290S-1-02 : SP TOP MEDIEVAL/EARLY MOD LIT.ENGLISH-290S-1-02.MEDREN-290S-1-02.

We did this once in the very beginning of the course, and it would encourage more participation and engagement with the course.

course: ENGLISH-290S-1-02 : SP TOP MEDIEVAL/EARLY MOD LIT.ENGLISH-290S-1-02.MEDREN-290S-1-02.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Read ahead of time and ask questions. Professor Beckwith knows what she's teaching and won't make you feel bad about not understanding a text.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I obtained skills for analyzing Shakespeare, discussing Shakespeare, and viewing adaptations critically.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I had a casual interest in Shakespeare prior to this course, but this course taught me to really dive deeply into his works in ways I have not before. I learned a lot about the historical context behind Shakespeare plays and how that context can be recontextualized through adaptation for a modern audience. I really enjoyed this class as a means of thinking more deeply about film as a medium and how it connects to more historical mediums like plays.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Close and wide engagement with Shakespeare in text, across genre/culture in adaptation through various mediums, and written articulation of thoughts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned about film techniques (sound, camera angles, mise en scene, etc.) which I did not know much about before
2. I learned about the different definitions of what it means for a movie to be an "adaptation" of something and that adaptations are not merely derivative of the text
3. I learned how to closely analyze the language Shakespeare uses throughout his texts

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze films which is something I've never done before, especially putting them in conversation with texts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I never know what to write for this question because it is hard to come up with a new method or skill you learn in every class. I really enjoyed all of the plays though. I suppose something I learned was just how much Shakespeare recycled themes and character tropes. I think it was fun to be able to see traces of his different plays bleeding into each other a little.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We went deep into analyzing Shakespeare texts as well as adaptations. I had never engaged with films like we did in this class, using cinematic terminology to discuss and analyze them. I think overall this made me more observant and a better reader/thinker.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze Shakespeare, Shakespearian films, and how to discuss aspects of Shakespearian literature.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about film techniques and terminology as well as read some scholarship on films (e.g. Mulvey's 'male gaze' theory). I read and reflected on a diverse range of Shakespeare plays and how they can be adapted into different times and cultures.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciated the freedom we have in when to submit our written responses and what we could write about.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the use of "gobbets" as a means of prompting analysis. They're a relatively low-stakes way to engage with whatever we're reading or watching, and I really enjoyed getting the feedback on it. It always felt like our professor was really interested in whatever we wrote about and why it struck us in particular. I also really enjoyed the balance between watching clips to spark discussion and letting us guide discussion naturally through conversation with each other.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

How to connect texts back to a specific genre

How America's foundations are connected to the gothic/processing the past/processing traumaI'd never taken a genre english class before. I definitely hated classifying these texts to the gothic/horror because it felt so unnatural and pointless to me (like why do we care if this text could be said to fit into the gothic/horror space, I would rather just talk about the text itself). However, I think as we progressed throughout the class and saw the ways these genres could show up in more modern ways like with race in the bondwoman's narrative or with trauma in Get Out, I had more appreciation for this way of reading.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
Professor Harrington was excellent. She did a great job of having everyone feel welcomed by having a spotify playlist for the class that she would play before class started and by talking with each student before class as they came in. She also did a great job of listening to each student's point and finding something positive to say about it, as well as finding a way to connect it back to the main point. 
I liked the 2 critical analysis papers and the option to do a redo. I liked the blog posts. I liked going to the rubenstein (maybe go one more time?). I really enjoyed these books and how they connected to the overall aims of the course: Alice in Wonderland, Goblin Market, Christmas Carol, Rousseau/Locke, Wordsworth, Blake. I also loved the days where she did the context/overview powerpoints. I would love for her to do that before every class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Effie Harrington created an open learning environment where all comments, questions, and thoughts were welcome. She facilitated our class discussions well - always coming prepared with background points & questions to provoke thought. Through her instruction, I got much more out of each work we read & how it related to the development of childhood than I would have if reading alone.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Harrington provided a variety of different methods to facilitate engagement and learning. Sometimes we would have lectures, other times we split into groups to handle certain parts of a text, and often we would have large discussion. I liked how Harrington framed these discussions around a larger question to help us think about the text in a certain context within childhood at large. I also liked the final project in the liberty we had to apply what we’ve studied throughout the year into a modern project. Something I’d change is replacing the day we went to the library’s archive for another activity because I didn’t feel that the course brought a lot of new knowledge that was particularly relevant to our class. Or to change the structure for the archivist to bring in more specific objects relating to legal codes or references we’ve learned in class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Effie Harrington is a fantastic instructor: engaging, funny, understanding, kind, and full of interesting insights. The class environment is laid-back and welcoming, but at the same time, we were always pushed to think critically, question and complicate our own ideas, and engage deeply with the texts. Professor Harrington's lectures, which provided context for the books we read and literary/philosophical movements that we studied, were a highlight– I looked forward to them at the beginning of each unit. Biweekly blog posts and occasional critical analysis papers were an effective way to explore ideas that we found interesting in what we read and practice our analytical writing.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Although the discussion posts were tedious, I think they were a good way to keep a log of our class's thoughts, especially since we could go back and look at them when writing our essays. I also really enjoyed Professor Harrington's lectures, as they were very insightful and provided good context for the pieces we were reading. Doing the presentations were also fun because we could see how much we could apply what we learned about childhood to more modern media.

response_text: The course was well-paced and well-organized. We read a great array of works: Enlightenment phliosophical treatises, Romantic poetry, and Victorian novels, each of which contributed somethnig new, different, valuable angle to the class theme while also relating to each other. Blog posts, class discussions, critical analysis papers, and final presentations on contemporary children's culture were all great ways of engaging with the course material and improving our writing skills. I appreciated Professor Harrington's detailed comments on our blog posts and essays– this was very helpful and encouraging as we refined our ideas and figured out what went well in our work or what could be better in future assignments.  The class was inspiring and pushed us to be better students and thinkers, but was never overwhelming or stressful.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
How to connect texts back to a specific genre
How to analyze films in a formal way
How America's foundations are connected to the gothic/processing the past/processing traumaI'd never taken a genre english class before. I feel like my other english classes were based on one author or one time period, so this was different for me. I definitely hated classifying these texts to the gothic/horror because it felt so unnatural and pointless to me (like why do we care if this text could be said to fit into the gothic/horror space, I would rather just talk about the text itself). However, I think as we progressed throughout the class and saw the ways these genres could show up in more modern ways like with race in the bondwoman's narrative or with trauma in Get Out, I had more appreciation for this way of reading.

response_text: I really enjoyed hearing others' perspectives either from their discussion posts or in class. It prompted me to think about these texts from a variety of different angles.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Professor D'Alessandro energy and passion really drove the course and energized class discussions.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Loved the breadth of works (classic horror films, Twilight, Get Out to Edgar Allan Poe and Emily Dickinson) covered in discussions. I think the foundation of literary criticisms on genres of Gothic/Horror, constantly tying back to them in class/analyzing through this lens made it accessible and intellectually stimulating. Really thoughtful selection of course material by D'Alessandro.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: He was extremely open and bubbly and so class was always really enjoyable. I felt challenged to articulate my ideas not in a pressured way intellectually but in a way that felt like we truly were here to explore and learn.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The discussions in the class were very intellectually stimulating. I also really enjoyed when we would be split into groups to have mini-discussions, because that was a good opportunity to flesh out points with just a couple other students instead of broadly with the whole class.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I liked the syllabus, I think that was really the strong point of this class. We covered so much and so broadly and really got to see a lot of aspects of horror and a lot of different types of writing (poems, short stories, films, books). I thought the Bondswoman narrative for how it connected to the trauma of Race in america, but I thought the writing was bad and excessive so maybe do excerpts of that in the future. Also I really liked Blue Velvet and Get Out, and the Shining, but I didn't like Sleepy Hollow or The Village so maybe do some more classics like Psycho or Silence of the Lambs.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The selection of works on our syllabus was stellar. The class discussion was always interesting, and Professor D'Alessandro did a great job fascilitating discussion. He was also always open to meeting with students after class or during office hours, and was especially receptive to talking out ideas before our assignments.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it!!! It's really interesting and you will learn a lot. It's also a lot of fun!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Proactively engage, you won't regret it

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely recommend this class to anyone, even if you aren't a typical horror fan. This class is like a highly academic bookclub and is extremely engaging. The course covers a wide variety of texts and movies that expands your literary palette.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Regardless of the material, Professor D'Alessandro will always be an interesting and engaging professor. The course was super fun and allowed me to learn new ways of looking at readings or movies I would've thought I knew most everything about.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it if you're excited to learn about horror!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would 100% take this course! The texts/films are great pieces, and Professor D'Alessandro is a wonderful professor that fosters a great class environment.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is a great for anyone who enjoyed seminar style English courses. Even if you're not the biggest horror fan, it is a great deep dive into the genre and you get a chance to read/watch a lot of great texts.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would highly recommend this course. D'Alessandro is an excellent professor, very knowledgeable and passionate about American Gothic literature. He provides excellent feedback and genuinely cares about his students.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Highly recommend this professor!! He cares deeply about the course material and the success of his students! You don't need to be a horror movie junkie to enjoy!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You will enjoy this class so much. I have never felt so comfortable in a classroom setting explaining all my thoughts even if they are unarticulated or maybe even a little weird. D'Alessandro provides a humor to learning  that I oftentimes think is missing in other classes. We are able to engage with these texts fully whether that means celebrating them, making fun of them, or personal connecting with them. I will really miss taking this class next semester.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would highly suggest taking this course!! The level of community we were able to build in the class is something I haven't seen in another class at Duke, and I think this comes from how the class was structured, the open and supportive environment the professor created, and the subject material we were discussing.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You won't regret it! The class is great and the professor is even better!

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-02 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-02.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-02 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-02.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-02 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-02.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-02 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-02.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to write a character sketch, which is something frequently discussed in creative writing contexts but rarely explained in my experience. It was helpful to see examples from other students and iterate on my own to develop a holistic portrait of a character without necessarily writing them into a full piece. I also developed new insights & skills around writing villains, which is often a nebulous task - I feel much more prepared to tackle the creation of villainous characters now than I did before the semester started. I also feel that I further developed my workshop skills to contribute increasingly more in workshops.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-02 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-02.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Overall, I really enjoyed this course! I liked the readings and assignments, and felt that this was a really productive and engaging seminar considering the varied levels of creative writing experience in this classroom.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-02 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-02.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professor facilitated our learning using fun, engaging texts, which I found very helpful - the books and movies that we studied were all a joy to read/watch on their own. I would keep the escalation from character study to character sketch in terms of assignment - it made a slightly intimidating, unusual task much more manageable from a student's perspective.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-02 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-02.
question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I thought this class was extremely stimulating. This wasn't my first creative writing class, but one that definitely pushed me. In response to a question posed about a time when I felt challenged, I thought that both the writing assignments of the study and sketch really did force me to step outside of my comfort zone. As writers, we love our protagonists and give them so much thought, care, and attention. Our villains, though loved as well, often don't receive the same level of care and attention. I've never been pushed to dive deep into a character I didn't really understand who may, psychopathically, think in ways inconceivable to most.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-02 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-02.
question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I feel like 2 and 1/2 hour long classes can kind of drag on, but I thought that the varied activities and quick break made it go by a lot quicker than some of the other 2 1/2 hour classes I've had at Duke.Since this was my second creative writing course and my first in fiction, I think that the most challenging part was just knowing some of the terminology / technical elements of writing fiction. I noticed that these were things I was struggling with in feedback, but including some sort of rundown before the first assignment on how to do these things could be beneficial for newer writers

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-02 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-02.
question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I really enjoyed how the writing prompts Professor Gritton gave us in class were related to the readings we had done that week. It made the prompts specific enough to spark creativity, but not so specific that it hindered my ability to write. Also, the semester of readings for this course was extremely interesting, informative, and entertaining.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-02 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-02.

I liked doing character studies & sketches as opposed to short stories, for example, because it seemed to flex a different muscle within the process of creative writing.

Moreover, a lot of the exercises we did in class, e.g. asking us to rewrite a passage from a different lens or to continue from the end of one, challenged the way I normally go about writing.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-02 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-02.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would recommend everyone take this course! As readers, we love villains. The villains certainly make the protagonists shine, but they also provide a space to further explore and add depth.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-02 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-02.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Would highly recommend this class to students who also have a little less experience in creative writing but kind of want to jump in? It was more hands-on than an intro course but not too in the weeds for people with less experience.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-02 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-02.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course was the right amount of challenging without it feeling overwhelming. As a creative writing minor, I was enrolled in several writing courses this semester, so I was worried I would not be able to produce my best work in Professor Gritton's course. However, I found both the structure of the course and Professor Gritton himself to be extremely supportive and applicable to my other writing workshops/courses. I could take what I learned in "Anti-Villains" and supplement the work I was doing both outside the classroom and within others. I highly recommend taking a class from Professor Gritton. His passion for writing and care for his students are palpable, and I learned a lot from him about character development, dialogue, and creative writing in general.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-02 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-02.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! This class was fun & engaging, and I learned a great deal. Not overly demanding, the class is a breath of fresh air, especially if you're looking for a break from the usual STEM classes. It certainly made me a better reader & writer. Professor Gritton is an excellent instructor who will help you improve your writing to meet any of your goals - I'd say this class is very "you get out what you put in".

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-03 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-03.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to properly approach revising, how to accept constructive criticism, and how to "kill your darlings".

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-03 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-03.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I've learned how to better write long formed creative writing, how to effectively craft a story, when to cut my own writing, etc.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-03 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-03.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned how to quantify my relationship with art, learned to write non fiction, learned how to workshop long works

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-03 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-03.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: It has definitely helped me write in new ways. The focus of this class was non-fiction creative writing, which entailed that we had to write about ourselves interacting with a work of art. I have never really written this way, so I learned how to make myself into a persona, create vivid descriptions, and decipher an author's purpose in these types of pieces.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-03 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-03.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about how to write creatively, and how to write very different kinds of essays. We experimented with a variety of structures and techniques, and overall I do believe I 100% became a better writer.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-03 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-03.

response_text: Writing about art and relating it to personal experiences/opinions, creating an authorial voice through description, quoting/imitating works of art, giving and recieving feedback on workshopped pieces.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-03 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-03.

response_text: I learned general techniques for the genre of creative nonfiction (e.g. how to make yourself into a character), as well as specific techniques for writing about the arts/fandom. I've improved at writing well-crafted prose, trusting the reader, coming up with good titles, and revising.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-03 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-03.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Shuman was very engaged with our class the whole time, very funny, created a very safe and community-driven space, and supported each and every one of us. I really loved out small group and one on one workshops, as well as the readings she chose for us to do.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-03 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-03.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the structure of this class in that we would read sample pieces that would provide a framework for a component of our writing assignments (imitating, describing, quoting, etc.). I also enjoyed the amount of time dedicated to workshops as I felt all the feedback was really valuable.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-03 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-03.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the class structure that alternated between "reading and discussion" days (when we would read a set of essays and then talk about them in class) and workshop days (when we would workshop our essays in small groups). I also really appreciated that Prof Shuman met with everyone individually to discuss every draft of every essay– this was so helpful!

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-03 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-03.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-03 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-03.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-03 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-03.
question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The essays that we read were interesting and helped to demonstrate a variety of techniques. I liked that the assignments had general themes (imitation, quotation etc.) that helped to teach us particular techniques, while also giving us freedom. There was a good balance between writing new essays and revising older drafts. I liked that we had both small-group and whole-class workshops and received detailed feedback on each draft. In general, I loved the theme of the class– "fan nonfiction" specifically as opposed to general "creative nonfiction."

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-03 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-03.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-03 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-03.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-03 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-03.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Make sure to keep up with your drafts by writing throughout the week. They take a bit longer than you expect, and you probably won't put your best work out there if you cram all of the writing into one day. Definitely make sure to revise a ton.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-03 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-03.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-03 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-03.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-03 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-03.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This was a wonderful course and a highlight of my schedule. Whether you're interested and experienced in creative writing (like I am) or just want a fun seminar or writing class (like several people in the class), I would definitely recommend it. This is an especially good class to take if you're interested in other art forms (music, theater, dance, film, visual art, etc.) and would like to learn how to write about them creatively. There is some work involved (reading essays, writing and revising drafts), but it's work that I really enjoyed. You will get great personalized attention from the professor, who meets with each student to discuss every draft of every essay and offers thoughtful feedback. The class was a small group and felt very relaxed. I looked forward to it each week.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-04 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-04.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to methodologically read a text as well as new ways of thinking about poetry. I used to understand poetry to be serious and to follow rules, but that is not the case. i also learned how valuable peer work and peer editing can be.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about different types of poems (different kinds of sonnets for example), various processes to create poems, and explored some famous problems and the ways that they are meaningful.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about different types of poems and how to use archives for poetry. I also learned how to think differently on my own as a poet and developed a new relationship to writing and poetry. I learned of poem structures and forms.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot of insights about poetry--for one, poetry doesn't always have to "make sense" in a conventional way, it's very helpful to receive constructive feedback from peers, and that poetry is not only about you as the poet but also about letting the poem breathe and shape itself.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.

response_text:
-writing creatively
-writing in different formats and media
-peer reviewing

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned different ways to craft poems, learned different ways to inspire creativity, and the course taught me how to turn what I thought were mistakes into something I am proud of.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much about writing and really expanded my abilities in this course. I can see how much progress I have made since the first class to the last class. We gained exposure to so many different types of poetry (blackout, random selection, sonnets, different types of rhyme schemes, mesostic, etc), and the experimentation that was encouraged in this course has led me to produce some of my best works.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about several unique methods of writing poetry that I had not known of previously, I developed new ways of thinking about what defines a poem, and I discovered a new technique (free writing) that has helped me move past writer's block.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned that poetry isn't just what is on the page, how to give constructive criticism to peers, and how to use archival materials to inspire work

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. new methods of writing poetry: automatic writing (activating the subconscious), cut paper poetry (purposeful spontaneity), persona poems, etc etc
2. how to access and use the archive for both academic and personal pursuits, and how to request none-book materials
3. several new styles of poetry, and new poets who have served as inspiration (Friederike Mayröcker, fractal poetry, .........)

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned more about automatic poetry techniques popularized by poets like Tristan Tzara, and got a chance to put these techniques into practice. I also learned more about thoughtfully annotating poems that other people write, so that I can structure my feedback for them more effectively in class. I learned about the concept of working to continuously improve a poem, and though the criticism of poetry is very subjective, what is most important is receiving feedback and working hard to implement this feedback. Poetry as a practice, not as something that "just happens."

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about entopic graphomania, slant rhyme and full rhyme, metaphor, persona poetry, tarot cards as reference for poems, titling poetry

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: During my time in this course, I was able to push myself to be more creative while thinking about different ways to write poetry. Learning about different styles of poetry while sharing poems with my classmates has helped me understand that the world of poetry is not limited and that you can gain inspiration from anywhere. I also learned that just because you feel comfortable with one style of writing because you use it frequently, doesn't mean that you are not good at other forms of writing either. This course has definitely had a positive impact on my overall writing skills.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a lot of skills in this class, outside of just my poem writing. Professor Martinez de las Rivas organizes the class in a way that allows us to hone skills in poetry writing, poetry analysis, and collaborative work in with the goal of identifying the strengths and weaknesses of poetry of others' and our own. He indirectly also develops introspective skills in his students as he challenged us to use our thoughts as an archive that would serve as an inspiration for our writing. I truly feel I learned a lot about myself in this class, which was unexpected. I also developed an appreciation for the things around me that have always seemed mundane, whether it be a crack in the sidewalk in the gardens or a (respectfully) crazy lady in a herbarium....

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Tarot Card poetry, Entopic Graphomania, and religious poetry

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about entopic graphomania, the duke herbarium, and sonnets.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor had us do exercises and most of our assignments in-class, which really allowed me to engage with other students while learning more about poetry. I enjoyed the one general poem a week structure that helped me to spend some time outside of class to develop my own writing.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the use of different concepts for archives, i.e. nature, sound, books, etc. to find new ways to write poetry and to be exposed to new poetry. I think that using these components allow a deeper connection to poetry and to writing in a way that I would not of expected at all this past August.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: We read different poems based on the theme for the class day, we had weekly writing assignments that we workshopped with our groups, and we also had good conversation on our insights. I really enjoyed all aspects of this class.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: field trips and free writing time in class were great

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor was very accessible after class and by email, actively providing feedback and helping me grow as a creative writer. I have never had a professor so invested in students' works and wanting to see them grow and develop as writers. One of my favorite parts of the class was reading the carefully selected poems for each lesson. I liked learning a bit about each poet's lives with each work.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Toby's incorporation of different types of archives into the course was phenomenal. Our trips to the herbarium, the Rubenstein archive, and the Duke gardens enabled me to look outside of my internal experiences when gathering inspiration for writing. Focusing on the persona poems, you are really able to think critically about the language you are using and how that can be improved. Poetry, after all, is an expression of language. He was an instructor that goes above and beyond to help his students, and spends so much time helping you improve if you would like to. Prior to his office hours, he will spend time reading through your poetry and is prepared with feedback.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the assignment of writing one poem per week and then discussing them in groups, as this motivated me to write regularly and allowed for constructive feedback between me and my peers. I also found the examples of different forms of poetry helpful in class and enjoyed reading new types of poems I had never heard of. Lastly, I found the couple of classes where we were allowed to just write useful, as it gave me time to write without interruption which I don't always have during the week.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor was very welcoming, kind, and relaxed. It allowed for discussion to flow well & comfortably

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved the entire course: the methods of instruction were helpful without being intimidating, everyone was kind and did their best, and Toby facilitated everything incredibly well. The availability of office hours was amazing, the group overviews were helpful from a perspective standpoint, and I feel the amount of time we devoted to reading poetry vs. the time we devoted to writing it was very well balanced.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The mini-workshops are always my favorite, I love getting to read other people's poems and comment on them, and receiving commentary on mine in turn. I think it creates a very low-stakes way to be continuously creating new poems and sharing them with others without the pressure of turning it in to the professor or being edited by the entire class at once. I also liked that there was a very strong feeling that I and other students were safe to be honest and authentic in the class, so we could have really open conversations that went past some of the typical barriers that might keep a class discussion from being that way.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Toby is an excellent, excellent professor. He is calm, caring, and sensitive. He wants all his students to feel relaxed and at ease during sessions, which makes for a great space to write poetry. He provides extensive feedback on the work you submit, and is not afraid to make suggestions-- which end up being truly helpful and thoughtful. I also learned in his class that if you want to get more one-on-one time, more feedback, or life advice in general, schedule office hours with him. Since there isn't much time to speak with him individually in class, you're pushed to act independently and seek out the time you need.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The writing groups, the field trips, the class discussions, and the specific poems/styles of poetry that were selected by Toby helped facilitate my learning in more ways than I thought. While sharing my poems with my writing group, I was able to get feedback from my peers which was very beneficial to my growth as a writer and I was also able to engage with my classmates more creatively. The field trips inspired me to write different poems and it able to learn about Duke during these trips as well which is something that I appreciate. The class discussions that were led by Toby were also very insightful because I got to learn about poetry from an actual poet. Also, I was introduced to so many styles of poetry that I did not know about previously which has been a very fruitful experience for me.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class was structured in a way that divided up instructional time and individual time, giving us a time to learn and then to apply what we learned to our own writing. We took many class field trips, which gave us the opportunity to use many unexpected things as archives and writing inspiration. Something that was really enjoyable for me was our trip to the Rubenstein Library where we all got to pull our own items from the archive and spend as much time with them as we wanted to gain inspiration and insight. Also the class is most effective when it's this size. I don't think I would have gained the same things from this class if there were more students.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Consistent one-on-one meeting availability.

response_text: The use of different parts of Duke as an archive, which allowed me to explore new parts of the University and the wholistic learning experience.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.
question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was intellectually stimulating because unlike my stem courses it really challenged me to think creatively and imagine, something that I have not had to do in any of my chem classes.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.
question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The exposure to different authors and works of poetry was great. I particularly enjoyed reading Walt Whitman and trying to channel his style into my poetry. The trips into the archives were also such a great way to stimulate inspiration and delve into different writing styles. This class was a space to try and fail within writing. I was never afraid to take risks in this class, and was very pleased with the results. The mini workshop groups were also a great component, and I enjoyed reading my peers' work and learning from them as well.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.
question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Our discussions about the nature of poetry were very interesting and had me think about what defines a poem and about various techniques that people find effective or ineffective. I also appreciated the feedback I got on my midterm poem and found it helpful moving forward in my writing.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.
question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Great discussion!

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.
question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class' poem selections were excellent, and I always found myself wanting more recommendations for poems and authors to read. I also really enjoyed the group discussion element of the class.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.
question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I found the class very stimulating. I think Toby's way of engaging with students is what makes him so special. His fluid, sometimes nonlinear approach to writing and school is refreshing when other classes are centered around harsh deadlines/grades.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.
question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The writing groups and the class discussions made the class stimulating because getting feedback from your peers pushes you to make your work better and being asked to write poetry in styles that you are not familiar with also pushes you to think outside of the box to create good writing.

course: ENGLISH-290S-4-61 : SP TOPICS IN CREATIVE WRITING.ENGLISH-290S-4-61.
question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was stimulating in the sense that it pushed me out of my comfort zone with my writing. Some of the methods we used in our writing were out of the ordinary; for example, writing poems based on tarot cards or "cut-up" writing where we took words from other published works and manipulated them in our own way. It was rarely, probably never, an assignment of "go write a poem," there was always something more behind it. I was amazed at the way that anything could serve as an archive. Whether it's our conscious thoughts, unconscious thoughts, the things we have in our pockets, the walls in our room, the Duke Gardens... everything really. It was always a pleasant challenge to see what other places and things I could identify as an archive for the sake of my writing. A lot of this ended up being my own thoughts, which led to a lot of unexpected self-reflection and insight.

response_text: This is a fantastic course, and Toby is a fantastic instructor:) I had an amazing time, and received a lot of incredibly helpful and constructive feedback on my writing and poetry. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed my knowledge of the screenwriting craft while gaining insights into the different techniques to use and avoid using when aiming to tell a story in a well-written and entertaining manner. I also was able to develop my ability to craft and hone in my story ideas.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I honed the skill of delving into unfamiliar topics, conducting thorough research, and crafting compelling stories based on them. The course consistently challenged us to write scripts on subjects we had no personal experience with or prior knowledge of. I gained proficiency in gathering both primary and secondary resources, covering historical contexts, technical details, and cultural backgrounds.Additionally, I mastered the art of writing within tight deadlines. With a weekly writing assignment, I learned to draft quickly and then focus on revisions rather than getting bogged down by details in the initial draft.Lastly, I cultivated the ability to provide constructive feedback to my peers in class. Engaging in script readings and discussions allowed me to refine my communication and comprehension skills while collaborating effectively with my classmates.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I thought the beginning with the short screenwriting assignments with different prompts were a very good way to kick off the class. I also liked the movie watching assignments and it helped me try to watch movies with a new lens.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the method of reading everybody's work in a roundtable is very effective for this class. It allows the class to remain true to how screenplays are read and understood in the film industry but it also really allowed me to get an understanding of what was effective and what wasn't in a way that I didn't really get from just reading the work on the page. I also really liked that we got to stick with one idea for the majority of the semester. I don't often get to do that in other classes and it really allowed me to dive deep into a plot line and into the characters I was writing. I'm really proud of the final product.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This course is very cool. You actually learn how to write a screenplay. You start slow and small, with 5- to 10-page short films, and Prof. Bell walks you through the process, so it's not scary. You also read your screenplay in class, and everybody gives feedback. It's vulnerable, but so constructive. You learn so much from your peers in this course. By the end of it, writing an 80-page script is time-consuming, but not super challenging.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Although it was stressful at times, I appreciated the weekly 10-page requirement because it truly pushed me to write, which, in my opinion, is the hardest part. I also liked the reading and casting in class component, which helped me gain confidence and improved my work progress. Watching and later analyzing the movies was also a lot of fun, and I learned a lot from reading scripts while watching them.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

course: ENGLISH-321S-01 : INT. WORKSHOP WTG OF FICT..ENGLISH-321S-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

course: ENGLISH-321S-01 : INT. WORKSHOP WTG OF FICT..ENGLISH-321S-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a lot of skills regarding how to plot a novel and what to focus on during the plotting process. The biggest thing I took away was the concept of the emotional core. That really helped me figure out how to revise one of my older stories to get it closer to its full potential. Another thing I learned was how to use POV, and how I can zoom in and out. Lastly I learned the narrative engin which is something I now consciously try to include. I try to have some sort of tension or engine in every single scene.

course: ENGLISH-321S-01 : INT. WORKSHOP WTG OF FICT..ENGLISH-321S-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
It is impossible to quantify what I learned in this class into three distinct points, so I won't do it. 
Professor Amin taught us how a novel works. Throughout the class, we read multiple books and each one we analyzed from the perspective of a writer. We talked about different strategies the authors used, why they worked, why they didn't, etc. It is worth noting too, that each book was different. That is, through our discussion of them, we learned how different genres operate, and how writers within those genres create a coherent story that works and sells. After that, we moved on to learning about how to create a novel. Amin put us through rigorous exercises (I wouldn't have it any other way) and through each one we learned more and more about what to do to create an effective story that is compelling and most importantly, works. We did numerous workshops and in those we all gave feedback to one another, and now that the class is all said and done, I can say that I can start a novel. I know what it takes to write a good story, and I can recognize good writing and a good story when I see it. This class was transformational for me, especially as someone who wants to write for the rest of my life.

course: ENGLISH-321S-01 : INT. WORKSHOP WTG OF FICT..ENGLISH-321S-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
How to structure a novel and come up with a concrete plot which follows an act structure.
How to write volume – that is, get stuff on the page.
How to utilize and subvert genre conventions when writing a novel.

response_text: Reading the books in the beginning of the class helped, and the lectures also helped a lot. course: ENGLISH-321S-01 : INT. WORKSHOP WTG OF FICT..ENGLISH-321S-01.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This class was incredible. Amin is not a dogmatic professor in the slightest. Each class was a discussion. Of course, he pointed things out to us and taught us how to effectively write a novel, but he did so by forcing us to see it. He asked us why things were working, or why they didn't work. In doing that, I was forced to think for myself why I liked or didn't like something, and as such I developed an understanding of novel writing and began to construct a solid base that I could use to propel my future writing endeavors.

course: ENGLISH-321S-01 : INT. WORKSHOP WTG OF FICT..ENGLISH-321S-01.

course: ENGLISH-321S-01 : INT. WORKSHOP WTG OF FICT..ENGLISH-321S-01.

course: ENGLISH-321S-01 : INT. WORKSHOP WTG OF FICT..ENGLISH-321S-01.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Sharma was very theatrical, which helped hold our attention for the duration of the class and kept everyone engaged. I loved being able to talk to authors that Professor Sharma invited into class. I also liked when he started assigning short stories and essays to us to read, as I feel like these examples of exemplary writing helped provide us with something to model after. He was also very approachable outside of class and clearly wanted to support all of us both in the context of the class and also more holistically as people.

response_text: The interesting stories and perspective of the professor, and his excellent sense of humor, went a long ways to make the class interesting. Obviously a lot of the interest came from the content and readings themselves, but the professors attitude also helped.

course: ENGLISH-321S-01 : INT. WORKSHOP WTG OF FICT..ENGLISH-321S-01.
question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It forced me to look at writing and fiction in a way I never had before. I always thought of fiction writing as fairly formulaic, especially compared to poetry. However, that's not the case at all. I think of the example of early modernism, where authors played with the tension and anxiety of language being an imperfect communicator to simulate an effect on their reader. I'd read early modernist writers before but never considered this play on the reader's perceptions before.

course: ENGLISH-321S-01 : INT. WORKSHOP WTG OF FICT..ENGLISH-321S-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is probably more work than you would expect but it's worthwhile if you want to become a better writer and reader.

course: ENGLISH-321S-01 : INT. WORKSHOP WTG OF FICT..ENGLISH-321S-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The professor is frank and straightforward. Don't expect adulation or false praise. This is a good thing. It means that you are laser-focused on what you are doing wrong and what you are doing right in your writing, and this helps you improve. Discussions are thoughtful and very interesting. The more you put into it, the more you get out. Try to spend a lot of time writing your stories, or at least spend a lot of time thinking about them. If all you do is try to meet the story word count cause you don't feel like putting work into the class, then there is really no point in taking the class other than an "easy A".

course: ENGLISH-321S-01 : INT. WORKSHOP WTG OF FICT..ENGLISH-321S-01.

course: ENGLISH-321S-01 : INT. WORKSHOP WTG OF FICT..ENGLISH-321S-01.

course: ENGLISH-321S-01 : INT. WORKSHOP WTG OF FICT..ENGLISH-321S-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to read a prolific writers' works (Chekhov's) and deconstruct what they did well. Also how to read another students' works and give constructive feedback. Also how to write better and take constructive feedback. And how to analyze my own emotions to better understand the emotions and motivations of my characters and to write better stories. This was the most constructive, helpful creative writing class I've ever taken, and I truly think I've become a better writer because of it.
