course: ENGLISH-321S-01 : INT. WORKSHOP WTG OF FICT..ENGLISH-321S-01.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Small group setting; culture of frank, constructive, usable feedback

course: ENGLISH-321S-01 : INT. WORKSHOP WTG OF FICT..ENGLISH-321S-01.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The feedback culture was phenomenal. Unlike most creative writing classes where feedback is 80% positive with very minor critiques for fear of hurting feelings, thus creating a culture discouraging truly honest, helpful feedback, this class was brutally honest and helpful. Sharma gave the best feedback on my stories that I have received at Duke thus far, and gave me specific action items to improve my writing. I also felt like I was encouraged to critique others' writings (respectfully, of course). The class was so welcoming toward honesty, I think Sharma and all the students just wanted each other to become better writers, even if it came at the cost of our egos.

course: ENGLISH-321S-01 : INT. WORKSHOP WTG OF FICT..ENGLISH-321S-01.
question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Sharma is direct, but wonderfully so. He will be absolutely honest with the quality of your work, but the feedback is perfectly applicable to elevate your writing. Not only the quality of the work itself but also the sentiment and motivation behind it is analyzed, and if needed, focused to produce better results.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned how to apply aspects of postcolonial theory to analyze the meaning behind different post-9/11 novels. This involved learning about how the cold war fed into modern US foreign policy decision making, and the role of imperialism.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Thi course was very eye opening to me; it taught me to approach 9/11 from a global perspective, introducing me to the historical background that led to its occurrence which are often ignored and concealed in the American retelling of 9/11. It pushed me to interact with a variety of texts, from essays of post-colonial scholars, to novels.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I learned about how the geography of Afghanistan made it particularly unique in setting up the country for certain historical events to occur within it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to compare literary works better, how to contextualize almost everything that I am reading, and I learned how to actually reflect on the words in the page and what they mean rather than just reading just to read.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The background information about historical period, influences, etc. before each new text was introduced was very helpful in guiding my understanding of Morrison's works. Professor Li's facilitation of class discussion was great - she provided knowledge and expertise when needed, but also allowed students the room to discuss their ideas and opinions and experiences as novices. Additionally, the supplements to the novels such as essays by Morrison or other writers painted a clearer picture of the context behind every work.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Learned how there are a multitude of stories behind language, terminology, and our understanding of the environment. 
2. The origin of colonialism and the anthropocene, and how this history shapes our modern outlooks on the environment and environmental justice. (Example - reviewing the influence of darwinism and what is "natural" and "just", etc.)
3. Narratives matter, and there are many of them. The differences between writers such as Locke, Darwin, Thoreau, Simmard, Kimmerer, Marsh, and more are astounding and reflect different understandings of the right of humans to take from this Earth and ultimately what the consequences of this become. These highlight how environmental issues cannot be divorced from questions of power, ethics, and equity. These different narratives allows us to evaluate historical paradigms (like commodification of nature) in context of the issues of today. These narratives show that environmental justice is not a single story and its ever-evolving to include and prioritize different ecological and social living systems. 
4. Environmental justice is not just about nature or wilderness. It's not just about economic opportunity. It's everything that surrounds us. It's about recognizing the right of everyone and everything, and the impact it leaves on everything else. It's about recognizing marginalized communities and preservation of spaces. It's about policymaking that reflects a commitment to the well-being of all things, as all things are interrelated. It shows the interconnected framework that integrates social equity, ecological health, and the well-being of all living systems. Environmental justice transcends any single issue. At its core, environmental justice is about reimagining the boundaries of "us"/"them"/"we" and instead honoring the reciprocity that must come with our globe through shared responsibility.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

2) the importance of language and how it shapes our perspective

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think about Duke with new context of its history within Durham. I also learned about how to think about ameliorating the environmental burdens of certain communities. For example, we spent a class using Beaufort as a case study of towns where environmental injustices have occurred, and we brainstormed ways that things could have done differently and we looked at all of the factors involved in both creating and solving the problem

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. The history of race in Durham
2. Darwin's influence on the world around him
3. How to break down a case study in which one discourse is told that does not reflect the true history and identity of a location and the strategies we can use to prevent this breakdown.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how storytelling and the political interact; how structural violence affects the way Durham looks; and how different philosophers and thinkers view uncultivated and cultivated land.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I LOVED THIS CLASS. One of my favorites at Duke, and Dr. Priscilla Wald was the reason for this. She guides the class effectively while also letting the class flow when my peers and I were discussing related things. For example, the day after the election was solely a time to reflect and she let us talk about whatever we wanted instead of "having" to do the exercises associated with the readings for that day. I also particularly loved that the class was outside most of the time in the gardens and around Duke/Durham. Keep all methods of instruction. I can't say enough how much I loved this class and the hospitable environment we had. She also gave us opportunities to work on creative pieces without any reprecussions, and discussion posts had no particular guidelines we had to follow.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: She is the best! She is so passionate about teaching and cares for each and every one of her students. She is one of the sweetest professors I've ever had!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved having class in the gardens. We also had a lot of field trips, and being able to see the areas that we were talking about in class, like Downtown Durham or the campus farm, was super helpful. I would definitely keep the field trip components. I would also keep the open class structure. This is the first class that I've been in that was able to facilitate such effective open communication. Breaking off into small groups and then reporting back ensured that everyone was involved in the discussion and made the discussion feel very casual. I think that this format, as well as sitting outside in a circle, helped everyone feel able and willing to contribute. Finally, I loved that we were able to adjust the schedule to take time to discuss stressful current events.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved the small size of this class. We were able to get to know each other and feel truly comfortable talking about complex issues. I loved that we had our class outside and sat in a circle. Professor Wald was supportive and engaging. Her passion, and the passion of the TA Maryn Gardner, helped keep students engaged and motivated. We had some of the best discussions I've ever had in this class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Priscilla is an absolute gem. I loved how she would always ask if students had anything they wanted to bring up. Even if we didn’t necessarily, it set a good tone for us to approach the discussion as somewhere to learn rather than proving we did the readings or anything. The variety in readings was lovely, and they built off each other nicely. I liked the little situations Priscilla would pose during disc because it allowed us to apply the readings and get to know our peers. I really enjoyed all the fiction and especially the speeches which we treated as literature and evaluated closely for what it communicated in terms of mood beyond the text on the page.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The literal connection with nature we had all the while discussing deep, stimulating concepts with Priscilla was deeply impactful for me, personally. Her passion is infectious and allowed me to feel comfortable with me speaking my mind on the issues presented to us. I loved the texts that were chosen as well, and genuinely made me rethink environmental justice and the use of narratives + stories being integral to our society.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It's a small class, so class discussions were very engaging.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I really loved this class and how open Dr. Wald was to everyone's ideas. The class really was student-led and it allowed to focus on the ideas that we were most interested in each week.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The discussions. Every student in this class was engaged and had interesting outlooks which made our discussions exciting. Professor Wald asked great questions to help keep the class moving.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was very interdisciplinary and loved the ways that the course approached the topic in distinct but overlapping units.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT! This class, along with Priscilla, will allow you to deeply engage in issues we are all passionate about. And you have the absolute freedom in this course to write and discuss what you wish. Take the opportunity for freedom in this class and run with it. Thank you to the TAs as well, who were outstanding (we love Maryn!) and supportive.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If Priscilla is teaching the class, definitely take it! She is so passionate about the material, which really motivates students.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This has been one of my favorite classes at Duke. Priscilla is a phenomenal professor who loves what she teaches and cares so much about her students. It was a great course for learning about Duke's relationship to Durham, as well as some history specific to environmental justice in North Carolina.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I highly recommend teaching this class. It will help you think about environmental concepts and environmental justice in a whole new, tangible way. While the reading might seem daunting the class and Professor Wald are totally worth it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it!! Priscilla is GREAT and super understanding— really wants you to be the best you can be and gives you freedom to find out what that means for you. The course is so much fun. Doesn’t feel like a lot of work at all because the material is so interesting.

course: ENGLISH-371S-01 : STUDIES IN AMER LIT, WWI-WWII.ENGLISH-371S-01.

Professor Ferraro and his supporting cast (Chadd and Lauren) are all excellent and always add something to every discussion. There really isn't anything I can find to complain about this class. I haven't taken a non-stem class since my freshman year, so I was a little apprehensive coming into an English class, whether it would be interesting to me, if I would be able to succeed (since analyzing literature was never my strong suite), and whatnot. But this class quickly dispelled those fears. I very much enjoyed reading for the first time classics such as The Great Gatsby, Winter Dreams, Absolution, and The Scarlet Letter. It's not an easy A class in the sense that, you need to put in genuine effort into your essays, but they are graded fairly, and work put in is rewarded.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1.  What characterizes modern American poetry.
2.   Some of the critical poets of this era.
3.  Why to love poetry

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- features of modern American poetry (e.g., return to common speech, rejection of traditional forms etc.)
- how to better analyze poetry (looking for imagism, form, sound of vowels/consonants etc.)
- range of modern American poets (TS Eliot, Ezra Pound, Elizabeth Bishop, Marianne Moore, etc.)

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the precepts of modern poetry, how significant figures shaped the development of poetry in the 20th century, and methods of analysis for studying poetry

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Analyzing poetry; writing critical essays; discussing interpretations of poems

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me how to engage with Modern American Poetry in terms of historical context (world wars, Civil Rights movement, etc), allusion (TS Eliot's extensive references), and authorship (personal context of the poet's lives).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Tenants of modern poetry. Tenants of American poetry. How to analyze a poem on its own and through the lens of those tenants. The works and lives of many notable American poets in a spectrum of different identities.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
Definitely the mixture of lecture and class participation. 
Definitely the wisdom and humor of Professor Strandberg.
Definitely bringing in Michael Cavuto to talk about modernist painting in relation to a few poets.
Definitely asking the class to share poems that were meaningful to them and why.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Strandberg made class an accepting and easygoing environment to facilitate discussion. He is also very responsive to emails and is easy to find a time to meet outside of class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Strandberg organized the class so that it was easy to manage the workload while following the material closely.  The lecture-seminar-style crossover facilitated deeper understanding of the poems, as we learned from his interpretations while developing and sharing our own.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor facilitated my learning by demonstrating his clear interest in what I had to say and by offering his interpretations of the poems we discussed in class.  I particularly enjoyed when we got to "present" poems as I enjoyed hearing poems from poets we did not discuss in class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor facilitated our learning by having students present one poem that interested them each week, which I really enjoyed - this helped expand the poetry beyond the syllabus which (while extensive) focused mainly on big-name poets just due to time constraints. I enjoyed reading through poetry on my own to select a poem and hearing the selections of my fellow students. This, in particular, made me more engaged with the class. I also found the professor's insights to be fascinating, and I liked the mix of lecture and seminar-style coursework.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor provided great guidance through the wealth of works in modern American poetry and shaped the works we looked at so that we could meaningfully glean not just a sense of the poet, but of the movement of what poetry means throughout time.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

I loved doing the paper.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

If you are interested in literature, poetry, or art and culture in a historical context, take this class!  The workload is mid-range for an English class and can be distributed relatively evenly throughout the semester.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take it as long as you don't mind having to take two tests along with writing two essays!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this class!! This was one of my favorite classes at Duke, even though I started the semester without a strong interest in poetry. course: ENGLISH-373S-01 : AMER LIT, COLD WAR/ AFTER.ENGLISH-373S-01.
question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to engage with works of literature in a more nuanced way, embracing the possibility that multiple interpretations of the same text can all be "right" (both-and!). I learned to explore the text in essay form and write into the complexity of a piece, rather than reducing it. I learned how to bring in the social and political context surrounding a work's publication.

course: ENGLISH-373S-01 : AMER LIT, COLD WAR/ AFTER.ENGLISH-373S-01.

response_text: The size of the class was great. I really appreciated the way that Ferraro helped structure the conversation and pushed back on our ideas while encouraging us to "keep going" in that direction. He refrained from cold-calling on students and instead let students speak when and if they had something to say, which allowed me to develop my own thoughts in response to the conversation before bringing those thoughts to the table.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: English types: your learning here is what you make of it. Make it hard for yourself. Take this class. Make it a challenge. Read carefully. Try to write well. Your job should be no easier than an enigineering student or a computer science student. This is a more subjective domain. This should not be an excuse to slack. SWEAT. STRIVE. LEARN HOW TO SPEAK AND WRITE WITH ZEST. WITH GUSTO. If you feel like you can’t say anything interesting in a discussion, change.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed listening to Professor Lubiano's lectures—she is one of the most intelligent and well-spoken professors I've ever met—and has a profound ability to integrate the theory and literature we encounter in class. I also appreciated how she elevated "colloquial" knowledge to the level of the academy (asking us, for example, to include hypertext and internet sources within our final paper, or bringing up the example of the online forum on dragons). This is something I haven't seen any other professor do before, and as someone who has a few reservations about the nature of literature and the academy, something I didn't take for granted. Additionally, I enjoyed the format of having one or two students come up with discussion questions for each work we talked about in class.

response_text: This was an extremely tedious course, but the work was minimal (3 short essays and one longer final paper). Professor Lubiano is very intelligent but often struggles with conveying information, so her lectures are quite disjointed and convoluted. Many times, she would leave no room for students to speak during the entire 2.5-hour class. There was a lot of assigned reading, but, as stated, we rarely discussed them and were instead lectured at about them for 2.5 hours. And, as the lectures were so hard to follow anyway, it felt like doing the readings was pointless. If you’re looking to learn something about literature, look elsewhere. There are many other excellent professors in the English department with significantly more engaging methods of instruction.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Analyzing music videos through queer/feminist theory.

Classic film.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to watch and read content while looking out for the gendered, sexual and other themes within. I also learned how to look for how culture is reliant upon itself over time, and echoes things from the past even through modern day, which will carry through to my analysis of modern day content. Thirdly, I learned about stardom and feminism in the 80s, and learned to think about how theories about gender and simulacrum inform peoples decisions to make content.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the time period at which Madonna was at the height of her popularity, how to better analyze image and video, and how to discuss performance beyond technical skills and more so rooted in presence and message.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Seminar style where students were able to speak without worried about being judged / not always have a perfect answer; variation of media ensured it never got boring and the translation of different means of analysis

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved the course and Professor Ferraro. I think my favorite class was the class that we had before Thanksgiving.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really loved the seminar style of this class -- it was the perfect balance of conversation and pedagogy. I also appreciate the use of DVDs and the roller TV. Our dinner party was also amazing, aided by the presence of Beth.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor facilitated learning with discussions that incorporated every member of the class, asking them specific questions and showing lots of different content outside of required reading that helped provide a much more holistic view of the things we were analyzing. None of us would have had this context beforehand, so this was essential to educating ourselves on culture and history.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is incredibly interesting if you are interested in poetry, regardless of your feelings on Whitman. Donahue is a fantastic professor who is passionate about the material – he spends most of class telling relevant anecdotes from his life, interesting background information about Whitman and his time, and reading through the poems. He also has a habit of stringing together a more obscure lexicon to say profound, powerful things; just something to look out for becuase it demonstrates his mastery of english. Above all, Professor Donahue is incredibly passionate about the material and he takes a genuine interest in Whitman. Highly recommend!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One thing I learned from this class is how to approach critiques when editing my writing. Before, I'd have a tendency to either completely disregard a critique (if I disagreed), or apply it in the same exact way ti was presented to me (if I agreed). Through this class, and through seeing how my classmates made edits to their writing, I learned how to take critiques into consideration while still fully making my own decisions about my work.I think that reading everyone's work helped me learn a lot about personal style and form, as there were so many different ways that we approached the same prompt that was really interesting, especially during the discussions after a reading

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- i learned a new way of writing - writing as a process of thinking and discovery rather than argumentation - which really helped me deepen my understanding of the philosophy i learn in class
- The attention journals helped me ground my learning in everyday life and always apply things i learn with the help of attention
- This course really sparked my interest in literature and philosophy and allowed me to decide that i want to major in GCS

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned about looking at literature through philosophy.
I came in with no prior knowledge of Weil, Beauvoir, and Murdoch, but I feel I have a very strong grasp on them and their philosophies now.
I also developed skills in creating a concise presentation.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Just as Simone Weil wrote in her essays, in the right use of schoolwork, attention is extensively practiced. So I guess the most important three things I learned are attention to others and other things, Weil, Beauvoir, and Murdoch’s visions of existence, and of course essay writing methods.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Became intimately familiar with philosophies of Simone Weil, Simone de Beauvoir, and Iris Murdoch through close readings. Learned ethics in a way that was immediately applicable to everyday life. Gained insights about the influence of these thinkers on one another, particularly Simone Weil of whom I had close to no knowledge of before entering the course. One of my favorite things was when Professor Moi filled in historical/philosophical context around these thinkers (wartime, surrounding literature, Wittgenstein, Hegel, etc)--made it feel less like narrowing in on these random philosophers in a vacuum.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned about the philosophies and moral frameworks of Weil, Murdoch, and Beauvoir
2) I recognized ways in which these philosophical theories resonated with me and have a fresh perspective on my own behavior and way of living. 
3) I have become more conscious of the ways in which I do and don't pay attention in my life, and have begun cultivating that skill in my own behavior.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
- i loved the seminar structured way of teaching that was interspersed with explanations of other philosophers (ie i liked professor moi's connections of weil, beauvoir, and murdoch with wittgenstein, cavell, and plato) because they not only allowed me to think deeper about the concepts i learn, but also open up new territories for me to explore in the future
- the weekly attention journals are also very helpful, because it forces me to sit down and reflect on the philosophy and also put things i learn into practice (paying attention)

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Moi encouraged genuine reflection with our attention journals. These were not graded on the A-F scale, which allowed them to be purely for our own building of the skill of attention without having to pander or have a grade in the back of our minds. I would definitely keep this part of the course. I also found Professor Moi's lectures interesting. The breaking up of the three philosophers into three separate parts rather than going between them also made them digestible so that they didn't get convoluted.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Absolutely, when the material gets a bit too hard, Professor Moi made slides to accommodate and overall the in-class discussions were very fruitful. And I really liked the idea of using Slack channel to talk about difficult concepts.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Smaller readings allowed me to pay closer attention to each text and get more out of subsequent lectures and discussions. I liked the attention journals as a way to keep me closely engaged with the texts throughout the week.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I thought that in terms of content, the course flowed quite nicely. I thought beginning with Weil and ending with Murdoch (from our big three names) was the ideal order, with Weil's concept of attention framing the whole course and Murdoch's vision-based moral theory bringing together attention and action, as well as offering a more realistic and individualized moral approach (compared to Weil's saintly expectations and Beauvoir's more politically-grounded perspective).

response_text: I learned about Weil, Beauvior and Murdoch, three female philosphers and their worldviews. I learned how to write more philosphical paper as well as really think philosphically

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The course definitely improved my ability to write both through the activity of writing (blog posts, the first essay), but moreso through an engagement with writers in an active manner that helped to inculcate what effective writing looks like and feels like. Most importantly, the course helped to teach me the importance of attention throughout my life, and to equip me with different tools for the training and use of attention.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Each reading we were assigned was very deliberate in advancing a specific philosophical concept, which I enjoyed. I also appreciated how they were all manageable in length/content such that it was actually feasible to read everything before the next class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the lecture, and the weekly reading posts. It was a perfect mix of discussion and lecturing. Honestly for these types of classes with very thorough dense philosophy, I prefer lecture more which this class leaned towards a bit more.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really loved our discussions in this course, they really solidified my understanding. I also think the blog posts were a good way to analyze the texts more deeply.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Close reading.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the readings that we did and the lectures in class really complemented each other. I really enjoyed the blog posting aspect as well as it gave me a really great opportunity to think, because writing is thinking

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that both class discussion and the blog postings were effective. Some of the moments of the course which helped me understand the texts the most were engagements with the texts on the clas blog, both through my own postings as well as through the exploration of my classmate's ideas on the topics.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I really liked the connections between the philosophy and literature and found I was really able to connect with the main ideas of each of the thinkers and take in what they say as a part of my own world view.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Good in depth exploration and explanation of the thinkers discussed. The selected writings were very well selected and in concert with one another so that each week's reading felt like it effectively constructed my knowledge.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take this class if you are interesting in philosophy, literature, theory or anything related at all. Note that this is not a feminist philosophy class, more so a class about women philosophers. I think these are philosophers that are underrated in the academic canon, although Beauvoir is quite popular now. But definitely Simone Weil is an underrated writer and philosopher that everyone should read. Professor Moi is also a great teacher who understands students and the texts quite well. The amount of texts you read in this class is perfect. Long enough that you get a deep enough understanding of the philosopher, but also not too long so that it becomes unmanageable. The texts are also enlightening and perfectly difficult to understand so when you do get some insight it feels nice and illuminating.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: prepare to read and start your essays ealry!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Readings are not easy but interesting

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: As with most reading based humanities courses, you get in what you put out. I think you should take to heart the teachings of the writers, paying attention, opening yourself up, awknowledgement to really get a complete engagement with everything we learn about

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You should! Its one of the best philosophy and one of the best literature classes I've taken at Duke, and it has spillover not just to the everyday but to the everyday within the University which is helpful.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. How to think and read about what Wittgenstein is doing in Philosophical Investigation. 
2. The context of philosophy of language which Wittgenstein is responding to and that which he himself spurs 
3. Relationship between and stakes of skepticism, knowledge/acknowledgement, literature, and morality as they invoked in ordinary language philosophy

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned to see language in a different way.
I learned about Wittgenstein's later philosophy.
I learned how to do philosophy as an expression of my self.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: A ground-level understanding of Wittgenstein, including terminology like "grammar" and "criteria"; what it means to conduct a Wittgensteinian investigation; some of the consequences of Wittgenstein's diagnoses for philosophy and literary theory more broadly

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

I think we first-time learners of Wittgenstein all somewhat have a tendency to fall into the trap of abstraction and over-philosophicalization, and Wittgensteinian spirit is really all about get outside such a picture.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Learning about a philosopher with a radically new vision of language, and connecting it to literary theory - if this is not stimulating for a philosophy student, I don't know what is.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The content, especially the readings

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I'd recommend it. I think it provides a way of thinking which is otherwise and often missing from other classes and intellectual discussions on the topic of language.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Must take.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are interested in ordinary language philosophy or Wittgenstein, take this class!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed my understanding of archives and the different mediums in which they can exist. I learned about important Black authors, photographers, and musicians that have shaped black consciousness through their work both in the United States and across Africa.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I believe this course was huge in developing my ways of engaging with archival theory. I've learned about Black art and the archive, Black aquatic archive theory, and I learned a generous amount from my classmates through the seminar format.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: While in this course, I learned to expand my perspective on the scope of archival materials. Because of the engagement with the readings, I now value the body as an archive. I also understand that archives possess the ability to dialogue. Most importantly, I gained a significant reading list and resources to support my arguments and theories that I would not have been aware of if it weren't for this class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to think about and narrate Black archival practice expansively (but also the importance of considering the consequences/perils of the impulse to recollect everything); How to think more critically about waterscapes as archives, and as liberatory spaces beyond how they've been narrated historically

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Interpreting Archival Silence: This course deepened my understanding of how historical erasure operates and how silences in the archive are not accidental but structured. I learned to “read between the lines” and to think critically about whose stories are told—and whose are not.
Creative Engagement with Archival Material: Through our exposure to artists, writers, and scholars who use the archive as both material and metaphor, I developed new ways of thinking about memory, storytelling, and resistance. The course showed me how archives can be reimagined through poetry, performance, and visual art.
Diasporic and Transnational Thinking: I learned to think across geographies and histories—connecting the Black experience in the U.S., South Africa, and other parts of the diaspora. The course challenged me to think about the global entanglements of anti-Blackness and creative survival.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: As someone who doesn't work a ton with theoretical frameworks and someone new to archiving, this was a great way for me to expand my own ideas of what an archive is and what the archive has the potential to be. Specifically in terms of the Black archive, I  have the following takeaways from the course1) Theoretical frameworks for archiving: In this course I  learned about the theoretical frameworks about the different forms of archiving. With each of the readings, I was introduced to a new idea or theory about the Black archive.2) redefining my ideas of the Black archive: this course really expanded my thinking about what an archive could be. I  enjoyed how we looked at different forms of archiving such as film, photography, and even forms of non-materiality like the ocean.3) interdisciplinary archival methods: I  really enjoyed this interdisciplinary class. We had people from various disciplines that added to the strength of the discussion.This allowed me to think through other ways that people think about emobidment and archiving outside of the traditional literary forms that I  am used to observing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot more about African countries and traditions, alternative ways of thinking about the archive, and how to write critically in response to archival theory.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
The archival visits to the Schomburg and Rubenstein which were framed by the theoretical texts we read throughout the course was enlightening and helped me to perceive the immensity of what it was to imagine the black body through these analytical tools. This coupled with the alternative forms of archival memory (photography, play writing, filmmaking, etc.) will definitely be useful in my disseration writing. 
Second, the guest speakers we periodically had in class helped to engage the class with the texts beyond surface-level analysis. We were able to tailor our questions or responses to the creator of said texts, rather than spending time on speculating possibilities of textual analysis. I found this interview style of class to be highly beneficial to my appreciation of what we were learning, and it further birthed analytical queries as to what the text entailed. 
Finally, hearing the responses from my classmates as to their analysis of what had been covered that week was beneficial to my understanding of the text, and helped me to think through the class in a fulfilling manner.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: First of all, this course introduced me to archival work in the practical, applied definition of the term. I was essentially going in blind although with the understanding that the archival process was (and is) front and center in my research and scholarly aspirations more generally. Our trip to the Schomburg Center,  as well as to the Rubenstein on a couple of occasions, really cultivated the feeling and process of archival practice from its most rudimentary to much more complex forms. In other words, the practical skills and methods referring to everything form applying for research profiles at the Schomburg to using finding aids to search for materials and beyond were all nurtured  by and through this course. But things do not just stop there. The theoretical knowledge gained in this course has been so vast that it would be nearly impossible to isolate one or two specific insights. I would say that this course cultivated a specific reading practice in me, which I intend to retain as I progress through my studies. Thinking archivally, and, specifically, thinking about the use of archival materials as forms of evidence, their placement in the texts we studied, the rhetorics built around them, and so forth, made me consistently consider the ethics of using the archives – especially those which such traumatic, heavy, or otherwise violence-laden sources. Although I certainly have room to improve, I feel like this course really required me to read closer than ever; to probe not only the arguments being presented, but also to scrutinize the archival sources being cited – often even trying to locate primary sources in order to compare and contextualize how certain citation were being implemented. Sometimes my discoveries were shocking with regard to certain decontextualized or otherwise heavily manipulated usages of primary material. In any case, I consider this a skill or even a reading method that I hope to transfer into my scholarship hence forth. Lastly, I have to mention the community of research fostered by this course. Through this course I have established working, collaborative friendships which I hope will persist. In my field, the caricature of the private, hermetic scholar still remains the more or less hegemonic image of what scholarship is or ought to be. This course absolutely challenged this image, and did so furthermore without resorting to the sorts of romanticized communities you often hear about in higher education. In a very material, working, and concrete sense, this class produced and actualized a real research community.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Methods to engage and understand archival material. An expansion of what I conceive of as "the archive".  The importance of historiography and the difficulties Black people have faced in preserving their past experiences.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the seminar aspect of the course. Discussing the material with my peers was very helpful and allowed me to gain from their perspectives. I also enjoyed the guest speakers and learning about their work.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class was mainly seminar/discussion based after a week of reading and a reflection. I don't always enjoy when classes use repetitive methods of entering into the material, however, I believe that Khwezi and Chris are great facilitators and interject/guide the conversation so that the class time is fruitful for the participants.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I would keep the guest visits a part of the course. Speaking with scholars exploring these topics and uncovering archives in such a powerful way has helped me form my methodologies and thesis.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Yes! I definitely appreciate the option to do a creative project with accompanying writing and I think future students would also find this useful. I also liked how we focused on different categories of archives over the course of the semester (periodicals and print media, photographs, waterscapes, etc)—this gave breadth to an understanding of what an archive is and how they can function.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The balance between theory and creative expression made the course incredibly rich. The readings, while challenging at times, were thoughtfully curated and gave us a solid foundation for discussion. The Schomburg trip was an unforgettable experience—it grounded the theoretical in the tangible and emotional. I would definitely keep that as part of the course in future years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors facilitated our learning through the formats of readings, written reflections, and trips to various archives. I  found each of these to be formative to my own personal experience in the course. With the reflections, I was able to express my own thoughts about the reading and generate ideas about the Black archive in formative ways. The trips to the archives allowed me to gain experience with handling written materials. Personally, I  enjoyed each of these components and found them to be useful for my own research and personal understandings of the archive.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class is discussion-based and relies heavily on the readings to facilitate these discussions. Additionally, the professors brought in some guest lecturers for some classes, and we were able to take a trip to the Schomburg library in New York City. I really enjoyed all the parts of the class! I liked how the readings included both classics in Black archival thought and some emerging research and artworks. These ideas were all new to me, even though I had taken classes about archives before. I suppose those focused more on literature by white people. However, these readings were all engaging and expanded my worldview a lot. The guest lecturers were all super nice in answering all of our questions and giving overviews of their work, which helped a lot in imagining how archival research can manifest in different genres of art. The trip to the Schomburg was also incredibly special. I had never been to Harlem before, and it was wonderful to see how Black thought and art could have really grown in times like the Harlem Renaissance. The Schomburg as a library was also really unique, and I felt lucky to have experienced it.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The integration of guest speakers, physical place analysis, as well as archival research was important to my overall learning experience and enhanced my overall academic insight. In the future as an instructor, emphasis on embodied learning will definitely be crucial to my pedagogy.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The basic format of the course (weekly reading with discussion) was enhanced with frequent guest speakers and trips to the Rubenstein, and, of course, our Schomburg excursion. I'll keep it simply by saying that all of the above should be kept in forthcoming iterations of the course. The addition of public lectures and events was also very successful, as it not only augmented the learning environment and our grasp of course material, but it also allowed us to interact on a quite intimate level with invited scholars and other experts. This as well is, I think, worth retaining. I also always appreciated and found extremely useful Chris and Khwezi's insights and (let's call them, casual or impromptu) lectures. They clearly wanted to cultivate a discussion based classroom, and thus their input was not lecture heavy. Instead, their insights were laced and interwoven into the overall class discussion, which was to the benefit of the learning environment.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the course's co-taught nature. Both professors' styles complemented one another, and their strengths lent themselves to different areas of discussion.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The professors were so knowledgeble about the course material and asked very insightful questions.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The theory we read was incredibly stimulating. Even the text that didn't have to do with my field was generative in the way I approached my work.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This course was very stimulating. We could have spent more at the Rubenstein Library.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The guest speakers (especially Nadia Davids and Brenda Sisane) enhanced the course, as did our trip to the Schomburg Center, and getting to explore not just the materials housed there but also getting to experience the physical space of the institution having read about it from Laura Helton's work earlier in the semester.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Many factors made this class stimulating, the course constantly pushed me to reframe how I think about history, evidence, and narrative. The readings were thought-provoking, and the guest lectures and class discussions challenged me to consider new frameworks and creative approaches.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Having the different perspectives from other students along with the speakers made this an intellectually stimulating environment. One way to add to this could be thinking about ways to increase our time in the archives that we have accessible to us via the Rubenstein, Wilson Library, etc. Being able to interact with the materials, I think would be able to help us put alot of these theories in praxis.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I had never taken an AAAS class at Duke before, so this was a real challenge for me to talk about a culture that wasn't my own or that I had little experience studying at a college level. It was also my first graduate class at Duke, so I was scared for sure! I felt super lucky to have had classmates and professors who were super smart and kind to me as I learned and who listened to my ideas. It was a positive learning environment centered on intellectual growth and radical thought, which felt unique to me.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Kwezi and Chris are phenomenal thinkers, and our discussions obviously reflected that. I feel that I would have benefitted from a more structured question format, instead of the open-ended discussion possibilities.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Lively discussion; engaging, provocative scholarship; frequent visitors and trips. All very stimulating. Wouldn't change much on this front.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I believe this course is incredibly stimulating and thoughtfully led. The student will thoroughly enjoy the course and its facilitators, Professor Khwezi and Professor Chris.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take it!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! This is not just a class—it’s a journey through memory, loss, and imagination. You’ll leave with a more expansive understanding of what archives are and what they can be. Come prepared to read deeply, think critically, and feel a lot.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I  would tell future students to have an open mind about the course. I think when you hear about archives, it can be easy to have preconceived notions about what the archives are and how we are supposed to interact with the archives. Having an open mind when coming into the course can allow students to really benefit from the course and the ways in which this course challenges you to think about the Black archive in new ways.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Please take it, even if it feels outside of your scope! I definitely feel like a better person (hopefully) coming out of this course in that I can be more sensitive with the archives that I work with and that I can work towards more decolonization advocacy in that regard. The class can also easily be tailored to your own research and backgrounds, so there's a space for everyone in the class to bring what they know into the discussions.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take advantage of the range of resources that this course will offer you. The hands-on experiences with archives as well as the interviews from guest speakers is crucial in developing your research expertise.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Make sure you get the reflections in on time, otherwise the group discussions may suffer a bit.
