question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot more about African countries and traditions, alternative ways of thinking about the archive, and how to write critically in response to archival theory.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
The archival visits to the Schomburg and Rubenstein which were framed by the theoretical texts we read throughout the course was enlightening and helped me to perceive the immensity of what it was to imagine the black body through these analytical tools. This coupled with the alternative forms of archival memory (photography, play writing, filmmaking, etc.) will definitely be useful in my disseration writing. 
Second, the guest speakers we periodically had in class helped to engage the class with the texts beyond surface-level analysis. We were able to tailor our questions or responses to the creator of said texts, rather than spending time on speculating possibilities of textual analysis. I found this interview style of class to be highly beneficial to my appreciation of what we were learning, and it further birthed analytical queries as to what the text entailed. 
Finally, hearing the responses from my classmates as to their analysis of what had been covered that week was beneficial to my understanding of the text, and helped me to think through the class in a fulfilling manner.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: First of all, this course introduced me to archival work in the practical, applied definition of the term. I was essentially going in blind although with the understanding that the archival process was (and is) front and center in my research and scholarly aspirations more generally. Our trip to the Schomburg Center,  as well as to the Rubenstein on a couple of occasions, really cultivated the feeling and process of archival practice from its most rudimentary to much more complex forms. In other words, the practical skills and methods referring to everything form applying for research profiles at the Schomburg to using finding aids to search for materials and beyond were all nurtured  by and through this course. But things do not just stop there. The theoretical knowledge gained in this course has been so vast that it would be nearly impossible to isolate one or two specific insights. I would say that this course cultivated a specific reading practice in me, which I intend to retain as I progress through my studies. Thinking archivally, and, specifically, thinking about the use of archival materials as forms of evidence, their placement in the texts we studied, the rhetorics built around them, and so forth, made me consistently consider the ethics of using the archives – especially those which such traumatic, heavy, or otherwise violence-laden sources. Although I certainly have room to improve, I feel like this course really required me to read closer than ever; to probe not only the arguments being presented, but also to scrutinize the archival sources being cited – often even trying to locate primary sources in order to compare and contextualize how certain citation were being implemented. Sometimes my discoveries were shocking with regard to certain decontextualized or otherwise heavily manipulated usages of primary material. In any case, I consider this a skill or even a reading method that I hope to transfer into my scholarship hence forth. Lastly, I have to mention the community of research fostered by this course. Through this course I have established working, collaborative friendships which I hope will persist. In my field, the caricature of the private, hermetic scholar still remains the more or less hegemonic image of what scholarship is or ought to be. This course absolutely challenged this image, and did so furthermore without resorting to the sorts of romanticized communities you often hear about in higher education. In a very material, working, and concrete sense, this class produced and actualized a real research community.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Methods to engage and understand archival material. An expansion of what I conceive of as "the archive".  The importance of historiography and the difficulties Black people have faced in preserving their past experiences.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the seminar aspect of the course. Discussing the material with my peers was very helpful and allowed me to gain from their perspectives. I also enjoyed the guest speakers and learning about their work.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class was mainly seminar/discussion based after a week of reading and a reflection. I don't always enjoy when classes use repetitive methods of entering into the material, however, I believe that Khwezi and Chris are great facilitators and interject/guide the conversation so that the class time is fruitful for the participants.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I would keep the guest visits a part of the course. Speaking with scholars exploring these topics and uncovering archives in such a powerful way has helped me form my methodologies and thesis.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Yes! I definitely appreciate the option to do a creative project with accompanying writing and I think future students would also find this useful. I also liked how we focused on different categories of archives over the course of the semester (periodicals and print media, photographs, waterscapes, etc)—this gave breadth to an understanding of what an archive is and how they can function.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The balance between theory and creative expression made the course incredibly rich. The readings, while challenging at times, were thoughtfully curated and gave us a solid foundation for discussion. The Schomburg trip was an unforgettable experience—it grounded the theoretical in the tangible and emotional. I would definitely keep that as part of the course in future years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors facilitated our learning through the formats of readings, written reflections, and trips to various archives. I  found each of these to be formative to my own personal experience in the course. With the reflections, I was able to express my own thoughts about the reading and generate ideas about the Black archive in formative ways. The trips to the archives allowed me to gain experience with handling written materials. Personally, I  enjoyed each of these components and found them to be useful for my own research and personal understandings of the archive.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class is discussion-based and relies heavily on the readings to facilitate these discussions. Additionally, the professors brought in some guest lecturers for some classes, and we were able to take a trip to the Schomburg library in New York City. I really enjoyed all the parts of the class! I liked how the readings included both classics in Black archival thought and some emerging research and artworks. These ideas were all new to me, even though I had taken classes about archives before. I suppose those focused more on literature by white people. However, these readings were all engaging and expanded my worldview a lot. The guest lecturers were all super nice in answering all of our questions and giving overviews of their work, which helped a lot in imagining how archival research can manifest in different genres of art. The trip to the Schomburg was also incredibly special. I had never been to Harlem before, and it was wonderful to see how Black thought and art could have really grown in times like the Harlem Renaissance. The Schomburg as a library was also really unique, and I felt lucky to have experienced it.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The integration of guest speakers, physical place analysis, as well as archival research was important to my overall learning experience and enhanced my overall academic insight. In the future as an instructor, emphasis on embodied learning will definitely be crucial to my pedagogy.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The basic format of the course (weekly reading with discussion) was enhanced with frequent guest speakers and trips to the Rubenstein, and, of course, our Schomburg excursion. I'll keep it simply by saying that all of the above should be kept in forthcoming iterations of the course. The addition of public lectures and events was also very successful, as it not only augmented the learning environment and our grasp of course material, but it also allowed us to interact on a quite intimate level with invited scholars and other experts. This as well is, I think, worth retaining. I also always appreciated and found extremely useful Chris and Khwezi's insights and (let's call them, casual or impromptu) lectures. They clearly wanted to cultivate a discussion based classroom, and thus their input was not lecture heavy. Instead, their insights were laced and interwoven into the overall class discussion, which was to the benefit of the learning environment.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the course's co-taught nature. Both professors' styles complemented one another, and their strengths lent themselves to different areas of discussion.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The professors were so knowledgeble about the course material and asked very insightful questions.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The theory we read was incredibly stimulating. Even the text that didn't have to do with my field was generative in the way I approached my work.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This course was very stimulating. We could have spent more at the Rubenstein Library.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The guest speakers (especially Nadia Davids and Brenda Sisane) enhanced the course, as did our trip to the Schomburg Center, and getting to explore not just the materials housed there but also getting to experience the physical space of the institution having read about it from Laura Helton's work earlier in the semester.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Many factors made this class stimulating, the course constantly pushed me to reframe how I think about history, evidence, and narrative. The readings were thought-provoking, and the guest lectures and class discussions challenged me to consider new frameworks and creative approaches.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Having the different perspectives from other students along with the speakers made this an intellectually stimulating environment. One way to add to this could be thinking about ways to increase our time in the archives that we have accessible to us via the Rubenstein, Wilson Library, etc. Being able to interact with the materials, I think would be able to help us put alot of these theories in praxis.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I had never taken an AAAS class at Duke before, so this was a real challenge for me to talk about a culture that wasn't my own or that I had little experience studying at a college level. It was also my first graduate class at Duke, so I was scared for sure! I felt super lucky to have had classmates and professors who were super smart and kind to me as I learned and who listened to my ideas. It was a positive learning environment centered on intellectual growth and radical thought, which felt unique to me.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Kwezi and Chris are phenomenal thinkers, and our discussions obviously reflected that. I feel that I would have benefitted from a more structured question format, instead of the open-ended discussion possibilities.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Lively discussion; engaging, provocative scholarship; frequent visitors and trips. All very stimulating. Wouldn't change much on this front.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I believe this course is incredibly stimulating and thoughtfully led. The student will thoroughly enjoy the course and its facilitators, Professor Khwezi and Professor Chris.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take it!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! This is not just a class—it’s a journey through memory, loss, and imagination. You’ll leave with a more expansive understanding of what archives are and what they can be. Come prepared to read deeply, think critically, and feel a lot.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I  would tell future students to have an open mind about the course. I think when you hear about archives, it can be easy to have preconceived notions about what the archives are and how we are supposed to interact with the archives. Having an open mind when coming into the course can allow students to really benefit from the course and the ways in which this course challenges you to think about the Black archive in new ways.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Please take it, even if it feels outside of your scope! I definitely feel like a better person (hopefully) coming out of this course in that I can be more sensitive with the archives that I work with and that I can work towards more decolonization advocacy in that regard. The class can also easily be tailored to your own research and backgrounds, so there's a space for everyone in the class to bring what they know into the discussions.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take advantage of the range of resources that this course will offer you. The hands-on experiences with archives as well as the interviews from guest speakers is crucial in developing your research expertise.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Make sure you get the reflections in on time, otherwise the group discussions may suffer a bit.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed my understanding of archives and the different mediums in which they can exist. I learned about important Black authors, photographers, and musicians that have shaped black consciousness through their work both in the United States and across Africa.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I believe this course was huge in developing my ways of engaging with archival theory. I've learned about Black art and the archive, Black aquatic archive theory, and I learned a generous amount from my classmates through the seminar format.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: While in this course, I learned to expand my perspective on the scope of archival materials. Because of the engagement with the readings, I now value the body as an archive. I also understand that archives possess the ability to dialogue. Most importantly, I gained a significant reading list and resources to support my arguments and theories that I would not have been aware of if it weren't for this class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to think about and narrate Black archival practice expansively (but also the importance of considering the consequences/perils of the impulse to recollect everything); How to think more critically about waterscapes as archives, and as liberatory spaces beyond how they've been narrated historically

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Interpreting Archival Silence: This course deepened my understanding of how historical erasure operates and how silences in the archive are not accidental but structured. I learned to “read between the lines” and to think critically about whose stories are told—and whose are not.
Creative Engagement with Archival Material: Through our exposure to artists, writers, and scholars who use the archive as both material and metaphor, I developed new ways of thinking about memory, storytelling, and resistance. The course showed me how archives can be reimagined through poetry, performance, and visual art.
Diasporic and Transnational Thinking: I learned to think across geographies and histories—connecting the Black experience in the U.S., South Africa, and other parts of the diaspora. The course challenged me to think about the global entanglements of anti-Blackness and creative survival.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: As someone who doesn't work a ton with theoretical frameworks and someone new to archiving, this was a great way for me to expand my own ideas of what an archive is and what the archive has the potential to be. Specifically in terms of the Black archive, I  have the following takeaways from the course1) Theoretical frameworks for archiving: In this course I  learned about the theoretical frameworks about the different forms of archiving. With each of the readings, I was introduced to a new idea or theory about the Black archive.2) redefining my ideas of the Black archive: this course really expanded my thinking about what an archive could be. I  enjoyed how we looked at different forms of archiving such as film, photography, and even forms of non-materiality like the ocean.3) interdisciplinary archival methods: I  really enjoyed this interdisciplinary class. We had people from various disciplines that added to the strength of the discussion.This allowed me to think through other ways that people think about emobidment and archiving outside of the traditional literary forms that I  am used to observing.

response_text: Take it! This is not just a class—it’s a journey through memory, loss, and imagination. You’ll leave with a more expansive understanding of what archives are and what they can be. Come prepared to read deeply, think critically, and feel a lot.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I  would tell future students to have an open mind about the course. I think when you hear about archives, it can be easy to have preconceived notions about what the archives are and how we are supposed to interact with the archives. Having an open mind when coming into the course can allow students to really benefit from the course and the ways in which this course challenges you to think about the Black archive in new ways.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Please take it, even if it feels outside of your scope! I definitely feel like a better person (hopefully) coming out of this course in that I can be more sensitive with the archives that I work with and that I can work towards more decolonization advocacy in that regard. The class can also easily be tailored to your own research and backgrounds, so there's a space for everyone in the class to bring what they know into the discussions.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take advantage of the range of resources that this course will offer you. The hands-on experiences with archives as well as the interviews from guest speakers is crucial in developing your research expertise.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Make sure you get the reflections in on time, otherwise the group discussions may suffer a bit.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed my understanding of archives and the different mediums in which they can exist. I learned about important Black authors, photographers, and musicians that have shaped black consciousness through their work both in the United States and across Africa.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I believe this course was huge in developing my ways of engaging with archival theory. I've learned about Black art and the archive, Black aquatic archive theory, and I learned a generous amount from my classmates through the seminar format.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: While in this course, I learned to expand my perspective on the scope of archival materials. Because of the engagement with the readings, I now value the body as an archive. I also understand that archives possess the ability to dialogue. Most importantly, I gained a significant reading list and resources to support my arguments and theories that I would not have been aware of if it weren't for this class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to think about and narrate Black archival practice expansively (but also the importance of considering the consequences/perils of the impulse to recollect everything); How to think more critically about waterscapes as archives, and as liberatory spaces beyond how they've been narrated historically

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Interpreting Archival Silence: This course deepened my understanding of how historical erasure operates and how silences in the archive are not accidental but structured. I learned to “read between the lines” and to think critically about whose stories are told—and whose are not.
Creative Engagement with Archival Material: Through our exposure to artists, writers, and scholars who use the archive as both material and metaphor, I developed new ways of thinking about memory, storytelling, and resistance. The course showed me how archives can be reimagined through poetry, performance, and visual art.
Diasporic and Transnational Thinking: I learned to think across geographies and histories—connecting the Black experience in the U.S., South Africa, and other parts of the diaspora. The course challenged me to think about the global entanglements of anti-Blackness and creative survival.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: As someone who doesn't work a ton with theoretical frameworks and someone new to archiving, this was a great way for me to expand my own ideas of what an archive is and what the archive has the potential to be. Specifically in terms of the Black archive, I  have the following takeaways from the course1) Theoretical frameworks for archiving: In this course I  learned about the theoretical frameworks about the different forms of archiving. With each of the readings, I was introduced to a new idea or theory about the Black archive.2) redefining my ideas of the Black archive: this course really expanded my thinking about what an archive could be. I  enjoyed how we looked at different forms of archiving such as film, photography, and even forms of non-materiality like the ocean.3) interdisciplinary archival methods: I  really enjoyed this interdisciplinary class. We had people from various disciplines that added to the strength of the discussion.This allowed me to think through other ways that people think about emobidment and archiving outside of the traditional literary forms that I  am used to observing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot more about African countries and traditions, alternative ways of thinking about the archive, and how to write critically in response to archival theory.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
The archival visits to the Schomburg and Rubenstein which were framed by the theoretical texts we read throughout the course was enlightening and helped me to perceive the immensity of what it was to imagine the black body through these analytical tools. This coupled with the alternative forms of archival memory (photography, play writing, filmmaking, etc.) will definitely be useful in my disseration writing. 
Second, the guest speakers we periodically had in class helped to engage the class with the texts beyond surface-level analysis. We were able to tailor our questions or responses to the creator of said texts, rather than spending time on speculating possibilities of textual analysis. I found this interview style of class to be highly beneficial to my appreciation of what we were learning, and it further birthed analytical queries as to what the text entailed. 
Finally, hearing the responses from my classmates as to their analysis of what had been covered that week was beneficial to my understanding of the text, and helped me to think through the class in a fulfilling manner.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: First of all, this course introduced me to archival work in the practical, applied definition of the term. I was essentially going in blind although with the understanding that the archival process was (and is) front and center in my research and scholarly aspirations more generally. Our trip to the Schomburg Center,  as well as to the Rubenstein on a couple of occasions, really cultivated the feeling and process of archival practice from its most rudimentary to much more complex forms. In other words, the practical skills and methods referring to everything form applying for research profiles at the Schomburg to using finding aids to search for materials and beyond were all nurtured  by and through this course. But things do not just stop there. The theoretical knowledge gained in this course has been so vast that it would be nearly impossible to isolate one or two specific insights. I would say that this course cultivated a specific reading practice in me, which I intend to retain as I progress through my studies. Thinking archivally, and, specifically, thinking about the use of archival materials as forms of evidence, their placement in the texts we studied, the rhetorics built around them, and so forth, made me consistently consider the ethics of using the archives – especially those which such traumatic, heavy, or otherwise violence-laden sources. Although I certainly have room to improve, I feel like this course really required me to read closer than ever; to probe not only the arguments being presented, but also to scrutinize the archival sources being cited – often even trying to locate primary sources in order to compare and contextualize how certain citation were being implemented. Sometimes my discoveries were shocking with regard to certain decontextualized or otherwise heavily manipulated usages of primary material. In any case, I consider this a skill or even a reading method that I hope to transfer into my scholarship hence forth. Lastly, I have to mention the community of research fostered by this course. Through this course I have established working, collaborative friendships which I hope will persist. In my field, the caricature of the private, hermetic scholar still remains the more or less hegemonic image of what scholarship is or ought to be. This course absolutely challenged this image, and did so furthermore without resorting to the sorts of romanticized communities you often hear about in higher education. In a very material, working, and concrete sense, this class produced and actualized a real research community.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Methods to engage and understand archival material. An expansion of what I conceive of as "the archive".  The importance of historiography and the difficulties Black people have faced in preserving their past experiences.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the seminar aspect of the course. Discussing the material with my peers was very helpful and allowed me to gain from their perspectives. I also enjoyed the guest speakers and learning about their work.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class was mainly seminar/discussion based after a week of reading and a reflection. I don't always enjoy when classes use repetitive methods of entering into the material, however, I believe that Khwezi and Chris are great facilitators and interject/guide the conversation so that the class time is fruitful for the participants.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I would keep the guest visits a part of the course. Speaking with scholars exploring these topics and uncovering archives in such a powerful way has helped me form my methodologies and thesis.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Yes! I definitely appreciate the option to do a creative project with accompanying writing and I think future students would also find this useful. I also liked how we focused on different categories of archives over the course of the semester (periodicals and print media, photographs, waterscapes, etc)—this gave breadth to an understanding of what an archive is and how they can function.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The balance between theory and creative expression made the course incredibly rich. The readings, while challenging at times, were thoughtfully curated and gave us a solid foundation for discussion. The Schomburg trip was an unforgettable experience—it grounded the theoretical in the tangible and emotional. I would definitely keep that as part of the course in future years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors facilitated our learning through the formats of readings, written reflections, and trips to various archives. I  found each of these to be formative to my own personal experience in the course. With the reflections, I was able to express my own thoughts about the reading and generate ideas about the Black archive in formative ways. The trips to the archives allowed me to gain experience with handling written materials. Personally, I  enjoyed each of these components and found them to be useful for my own research and personal understandings of the archive.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class is discussion-based and relies heavily on the readings to facilitate these discussions. Additionally, the professors brought in some guest lecturers for some classes, and we were able to take a trip to the Schomburg library in New York City. I really enjoyed all the parts of the class! I liked how the readings included both classics in Black archival thought and some emerging research and artworks. These ideas were all new to me, even though I had taken classes about archives before. I suppose those focused more on literature by white people. However, these readings were all engaging and expanded my worldview a lot. The guest lecturers were all super nice in answering all of our questions and giving overviews of their work, which helped a lot in imagining how archival research can manifest in different genres of art. The trip to the Schomburg was also incredibly special. I had never been to Harlem before, and it was wonderful to see how Black thought and art could have really grown in times like the Harlem Renaissance. The Schomburg as a library was also really unique, and I felt lucky to have experienced it.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The integration of guest speakers, physical place analysis, as well as archival research was important to my overall learning experience and enhanced my overall academic insight. In the future as an instructor, emphasis on embodied learning will definitely be crucial to my pedagogy.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The basic format of the course (weekly reading with discussion) was enhanced with frequent guest speakers and trips to the Rubenstein, and, of course, our Schomburg excursion. I'll keep it simply by saying that all of the above should be kept in forthcoming iterations of the course. The addition of public lectures and events was also very successful, as it not only augmented the learning environment and our grasp of course material, but it also allowed us to interact on a quite intimate level with invited scholars and other experts. This as well is, I think, worth retaining. I also always appreciated and found extremely useful Chris and Khwezi's insights and (let's call them, casual or impromptu) lectures. They clearly wanted to cultivate a discussion based classroom, and thus their input was not lecture heavy. Instead, their insights were laced and interwoven into the overall class discussion, which was to the benefit of the learning environment.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the course's co-taught nature. Both professors' styles complemented one another, and their strengths lent themselves to different areas of discussion.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The professors were so knowledgeble about the course material and asked very insightful questions.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The theory we read was incredibly stimulating. Even the text that didn't have to do with my field was generative in the way I approached my work.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This course was very stimulating. We could have spent more at the Rubenstein Library.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The guest speakers (especially Nadia Davids and Brenda Sisane) enhanced the course, as did our trip to the Schomburg Center, and getting to explore not just the materials housed there but also getting to experience the physical space of the institution having read about it from Laura Helton's work earlier in the semester.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Many factors made this class stimulating, the course constantly pushed me to reframe how I think about history, evidence, and narrative. The readings were thought-provoking, and the guest lectures and class discussions challenged me to consider new frameworks and creative approaches.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Having the different perspectives from other students along with the speakers made this an intellectually stimulating environment. One way to add to this could be thinking about ways to increase our time in the archives that we have accessible to us via the Rubenstein, Wilson Library, etc. Being able to interact with the materials, I think would be able to help us put alot of these theories in praxis.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I had never taken an AAAS class at Duke before, so this was a real challenge for me to talk about a culture that wasn't my own or that I had little experience studying at a college level. It was also my first graduate class at Duke, so I was scared for sure! I felt super lucky to have had classmates and professors who were super smart and kind to me as I learned and who listened to my ideas. It was a positive learning environment centered on intellectual growth and radical thought, which felt unique to me.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Kwezi and Chris are phenomenal thinkers, and our discussions obviously reflected that. I feel that I would have benefitted from a more structured question format, instead of the open-ended discussion possibilities.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Lively discussion; engaging, provocative scholarship; frequent visitors and trips. All very stimulating. Wouldn't change much on this front.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I believe this course is incredibly stimulating and thoughtfully led. The student will thoroughly enjoy the course and its facilitators, Professor Khwezi and Professor Chris.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take it!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! This is not just a class—it’s a journey through memory, loss, and imagination. You’ll leave with a more expansive understanding of what archives are and what they can be. Come prepared to read deeply, think critically, and feel a lot.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I  would tell future students to have an open mind about the course. I think when you hear about archives, it can be easy to have preconceived notions about what the archives are and how we are supposed to interact with the archives. Having an open mind when coming into the course can allow students to really benefit from the course and the ways in which this course challenges you to think about the Black archive in new ways.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Please take it, even if it feels outside of your scope! I definitely feel like a better person (hopefully) coming out of this course in that I can be more sensitive with the archives that I work with and that I can work towards more decolonization advocacy in that regard. The class can also easily be tailored to your own research and backgrounds, so there's a space for everyone in the class to bring what they know into the discussions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Reading foundational philosophical texts from the centers and margins really transform my mindset, helps me academically, and religious thoughts. The reading list is both wide in scope and generatively constructed. Ideas and resonance between old european canon and african american studies' texts are outstandingly good.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I read authors I had never read before.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned more about existentialism and nihilism. Those were concepts I wasn't familiar with coming into the course. I appreciated the opportunity to challenge the traditional existentialist canon that centers white men. As a non-white student this was helpful in getting and keeping me engaged in the course. I really appreciated the was that Professor Winters paired traditional existential readings with those that engaged gender, race, and class in different ways. I was also encouraged to think about the ways other scholars engage with themes from existentialism.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Sitting in circle. Giving ample room for first impression of the texts. Introducing each text before the text is assigned (a week before) and when discussion about to start (on the week).

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciated the wide variety of authors we read from a number of different disciplines that all wrote on existentialism. That, along with the variety of disciplines being studied in the class made the course very interesting and covered a wide breadth of material.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The syllabus was interesting.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciated the class discussions. It was helpful to have Professor Winters provide context before allowing us to explore deeper the themes and concepts. I also really like the course progression/ structure of the course. I found the fiction texts helpful in further underlying what we discussed with other readings.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Please give room after discussion to share to us your thoughts in a more systematic form, also of other "respected" interpreters. These are extremely important

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The readings were interesting, but the course was cross-listed in too many departments. There was no overall cohesiveness to the course.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The readings and the responses of my peers made the class stimulating. I was able to engage with readings at varying levels of accessibility. Some required more in-depth reading that challenged me to attempt to engage with texts that I found difficult to read and understand. I also found the probings of Professor Winter stimulating.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Just take it. Wont regret it!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would recommend Dr. Winters as a professor, but I would not recommend this course unless you are particularly interested in philosophy. The other ideas promised for this course were not present; I would not recommend this course for someone interested in Religion.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would definitely recommend a class with Professor Winters. He integrates well Black Studies, religious studies, and philosophy. He brought a unique perspective to Religion, Existentialism, and Nihilism that helps to provide insight into how different philosophical beliefs can play out in the everyday as well as the ways that identity and context shape how we engage with certain themes and ideas.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
This course was excellent. I appreciate the attention to specificity and the care taken when editing writing in groups. I learned the following:
o Note taking is vital - It is more important to capture how I feel about material rather than block quotes and theoretical applicability. This include WHERE the source material comes from.
o Trust my own voice. I don't have to adhere to academic writing standard if they do not satisfy my interpretation
o Solicit peer feedback. Often times, if peers can understand what I am writing, then the writing is clear. I cannot assume people understand what I am writing about.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Took my note-taking more seriously and learned about different techniques 
2. I feel like I was able to get more clear and precise in my writing - working on slowing down and letting a sentence to one thing at a time 
3. Dissecting others' individual sentences and figuring out what's wrong with them - being able to pinpoint this more precisely

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think I learned how to find my own voice in my writing and work on editing my and others' work for clarity and cohesion.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to more critically and self-reflectively read my own writing and assess my own writing practices. I have a better understanding of how to manage long-term writing projects like dissertations. I am familiar with the teachings of the most popular academic style guides and have practiced implementing their suggestions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned how to identity what was going wrong in my writing and how to fix it.
I learned what a plethora of academic authors have to say on the topic of writing through class book reviews.
I learned how to note-take effectively and consistently, and why that matters.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 1) Writing good sentences because my sentences were horribly confusing and prevented my thoughts from being effectively communicated. 2) Writing groups can be very helpful to the overall writing process, both mentally/emotionally through discussion about the process and making progress in writing. 3) Writing class is absolutely needed for graduate students, especially those who are interested in PhD work. In a field of work where writing essentially is the job, it is almost fraudulent that graduate programs do not teach the basic skills. There ought to be creative ways that graduate programs teach students write throughout the curriculum, rather than simply claiming that writing skills should be learned before students enter graduate school. The education system today simply does not work that way anymore.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Perhaps the most important skill I gained from this class was an ability to really critically contemplate the details of my writing experience, in a manner that often seems "irrelevant" to graduate students. We come to think we know how to write and therefore do not pay attention to the minutiae of what we're doing and forget that each little thing is a choice--one that matters significantly. I also gained confidence in (and excitement about) the practice of sharing my work with others productively and began developing a note-taking habit unique to my PhD work that I know will serve me well as I head into my reading year and teh dissertation stage of the program.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned invaluable skills about how to organize my research, take notes with lasting meaning, and write with improved clarity. This class was the first one devoted to writing instruction that I had taken in years, and it was a wonderful addition to a grad school curriculum. People so often assume that graduate students know how to write, but it is very helpful to have a course specifically geared toward improving graduate-level writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned how to take generative notes. 
2. How do I pace myself in writing towards long projects?
3. I learned how to share my work and receive feedback.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Well, I may not raise myself to the level of three here, but in general I found this course refreshing in a semester where I was mired in irritatingly dense theoretical prose that made me want to rip all my hair out and eat it. I do think it taught me to pay a little more attention to brevity in my sentences -- to break them up and make them shorter when I can. For that alone it's been of use. I also think it taught me a lot about how totally irritating and inward-facing academia is, and how difficult it is to really produce anything of worth in this environment.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I love the conversational method of instruction, Professor Moi's class is master class on writing. Here examples are clear, approachable and appropriate. I especially appreciate the amount of content she makes available on Sakai. One of the take aways for me is to be more deliberate about my writing practice, and allow myself to free write without judgement. I also appreciate seeing my peers writing, it validates my writing ability and show me what I am capable of given patience, focus, and time.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Created an environment where critique between students and their respective writings didn't feel personal.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the targeted and weekly individual feedback from the Professor was invaluable. She clearly spent so much of her time helping us improve, and I (and we) am / are better for it.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Moi gave generous and extensive feedback on our writing every week. I felt really privileged to have that kind of attention on my writing. I also benefitted from regularly hearing a wide range of perspectives from other students in mini-workshop settings.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciated how multi-dimensional the learning was. I learned via oral discussion, as well as via written examples ("some sentences" exercise). I appreciated getting to read about writing (book reviews), write about writing (notetaking essay), write (200 words weekly), and edit myself & others.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The collaborative environment allowed me to see where other students are in their writing. I always felt that I was an inadequate writer because in graduate programs, I read published essays that have been refined (thus high quality) and my own writing, which I often submit quickly (thus low quality). But seeing other people write made me realize that writing is difficult for everyone. And working through writing together helped me to be ok with my own writing and see how my writing could improve through writings of others.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I'm not sure how it was done or who was responsible, but from the first day of this course the learning environment was incredibly comfortable, caring, and productive. A course like this requires so much vulnerability, difficult for anyone but especially for those early on in a career in which our ability to do THIS ONE THING very well feels crucial. It was so wonderful to find myself in a space in which that vulnerability, while maybe still a bit uncomfortable, was not frightening--in which I could laugh at myself--in which I felt unconcerned about sharing honest and sometimes challenging feedback with others.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked have regular writing exercises that encouraged us to try different techniques and styles.  The readings were generally very helpful. I also liked seeing examples from my classmates, particularly about how they take notes.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The weekly "some sentences" practice taught me how to edit my work and that of others. Also, knowing that Toril would be giving me feedback on my 200 words, I became more precise in my writing to get more input on content and less on structure. 
The note-taking practice allowed me to get to know my mind and begin figuring out how I am as a writer and thinker.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Toril's frank attitude and her open approach to discussion is probably the most important aspect of the course, even if it is sometimes the most terrifying aspect as well!I would probably keep Some Sentences, albeit with the caveat that sometimes you have absolutely NO DESIRE to stand by anything you wrote in your 200 words some weeks. (There should be a big button you get to push that bails you out of your chair in the seminar room if that's the case, like in a fighter plane that's going down.)I also liked writing the book reviews a lot and wish there were more longer assignments in the course.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The stakes are always high when your writing can be displayed for scrutiny, I appreciate this rigor and grew from it. This aspect of the course kept us on our toes.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Precision and level of specificity and attention to detail to sentences. Writing the 200-word papers and getting feedback very quickly afterward.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The course was very stimulating, but I did feel that some of the style guides got repetitive after a while and those readings (+ the notes I took on them) took up time that I could have spent practicing writing.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: "Some sentences" was by far the most stimulating part. It helped me move beyond recognizing "bad" writing, to knowing what exactly about it was "bad" and how to fix it.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Fixing sentences together as a class was really important. And also, realized that the letters/sentences on paper are the objective mirror of my internal thinking. So I had to fix the sentences if I wanted my thinking to be communicated clearly.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: As I've written above, I would have liked a greater proportion of the course to be spent on writing rather than reading and discussions of what we'd read. I loved the "some sentences" practice we did every day and enjoyed other small writing activities that were a part of the course, and found these to be incredibly intellectually stimulating. I have never had another opportunity to think about my own writing (or the writing of others) like that.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The readings were excellent, and the weekly note-taking assignments made me think more deeply about what I was reading both for this class and for other classes I was taking.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The writing groups were an incredible addition to the class. I appreciated meeting with a group of my colleagues once a week in the second half of the term.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This was really about the same level of intellectual stimulation as all my other courses, but I got something useful out of it at least.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be bold and be vulnerable. Now is the time show blindspots. The course will help you become a better thinker and a better writer!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Great class to take at any level of your process, but also great to take as a first-year.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would strongly recommend the course, but might caution that it is an intense experience to have your writing held up under this kind of microscope. Not necessarily a bad thing :)

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is a writing heavy course that will give you MUCH completed work to look back on. For a graduate student especially, it gave me the time and space and push I needed to get a lot of writing and note-taking done that will use in the future!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Absolutely take it, especially if you are interested in doctoral work (or any other field of work where writing will matter).

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course will get inside your brain in ways that can be very challenging but, in the end, so so useful if you let it be.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would absolutely take this course.  It is a lot more work during the semester than other courses because there are many weekly deadlines, but it is totally worth it.  My writing grew immensely, and I am very grateful to have had the opportunity to take this course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class changed my life and will continue to change my life as I metabolize all that I've learned this term. Though I wish I had taken it in the first semester of my Ph.D. I think having had the first year to understand the particularities and cadences of a doctoral program made taking it in my second year the best time to do it. Writing is Thinking has made me a better writer, reader, and confident person as it relates to both. Receiving weekly feedback on my writing helped me hone in on my personal writing skills and begin to figure out how to change/adjust them. More than that, this class forced me to confront my anxieties around writing and my fears of being seen as not being good enough. Though neither of those has "gone away" per se, I am now more able to sit with them and take more responsibility for how I sometimes allow them to overwhelm me. Toril seems intimidating, but she is so deeply kind. So kind. Receiving consistent feedback and engagement with your writing and thinking from someone so deeply invested in both is not something that happens even 2% of the time in graduate school. Most people never receive that, and the few who do receive it too late. The class might feel scary, but you will be deeply cared for while not being coddled, and you will grow a lot in the process

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Exposure to the main thinkers in psychoanalytic theory, how to construct a class syllabus, how to ask questions

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the intellectual history of psychoanalysis, academic course structure/design, and interdisciplinary methodologies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: learned a lot about Lacanian psychoanalysis and how it's applied in theory

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot of content related to psychoanalysis and theories of subjectification, but I also learned a lot about the cultural, epistemological, and philosophical contexts of those texts. This was stimulating for my own thinking and opened new avenues for me.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Ranjana is a really patient and encouraging teacher, and I appreciated how she took questions seriously and gave thorough, thoughtful answers. She made this challenging and complex topic feel approachable, and I felt able to take from it what I wanted.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor maintained a highly effective learning environment in which the structure and all components of the course were useful.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The syllabus assignment is great, I learned a lot from doing it

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The learning environment is both rigorous and stimulating, but also calming and welcoming. I enjoyed the instructors broad introductions of the texts alongside her attention to questions and textual content.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I enjoyed reading Freud and Lacan. I also appreciated the snacks, given the time.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
