question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Don't miss the opportunity to take this or any course with Prof. Khanna.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. More theoretical background/history to situate my own interests 
2. Presentation skills - dos and don'ts 
3. Having productive conversations with classmates

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Greater knowledge of the history of literary criticism; learned how to better write abstracts, book reviews, and fellowship proposals; improved presentation skills

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I developed a knowledge of the broad history of critical theory from the 1800s - now.
2. I developed experience/skill in writing abstracts and preparing for / presenting at a conference.
3. I really began to understand Marxism beyond just Marx and economic theory.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a great deal about the history of philosophy and critical theory, both on a macro level (in terms of the history of various intellectual movements), and a micro level (in terms of reading specific thinkers who were unfamiliar to me). The overview of structuralism and poststructuralism we were given was especially really helpful. I also found the final assignment — writing a minor list — taught me a great deal about the history and theoretical makeup of my field.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned about the history of the biggest academic theorists.
I learned about how these theorists can be applied to literature.
I learned about my classmates various views on these theorists.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- A relative genealogy of the primary schools of twentieth-century academic literary criticism.
- Comfort with summarizing large and complex arguments, or, rather, interpreting them in broad strokes.
- Skills related to developing coherent exam lists.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a fair bit about the theoretical traditions that remain important to literary studies.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
Allowed for discussion between students after establishing foundations. 
Transparent and open with how the course was run and way, open to change.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked that each week a different person from the class presented on a reading from that week. It was a productive exercise, and I enjoyed hearing what questions other people have about what we read.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciated the practicality of the assignments. And Dr. Stan was very generous and helpful in discussing professional / student life and the practicalities of academia. Meeting one-on-one prior to the final project was also helpful and productive. Dr. Stan's knowledge of the European context and her framing of the class with a critique of Western philosophy's eurocentrism were both very valuable for me in contextualizing the course and its content.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciated the segments of the course that were more discussion-based, where we would come in with questions about the assigned text and we'd all try to work though them together. (I liked it best when we all brought in questions rather than only one person, so we could feel out more organically where to spend our time.) The beginning overview lectures were also a good touchstone, and a really helpful way to think broadly about the history of criticism or a specific critical approach. In terms of the assignments, what I found most useful was the abstract assignment, our mock conference (which, honestly, was so valuable we we could have spent more time scaffolding it even -- i.e., presenting abstracts & talking over conferences the week before, then holding the "conference" the following class), and the minor list assignment. In general, both the other students and Professor Stan were thoughtful and intellectually generous, and the class was an exciting and generative space to spend time in each week. I've come out of it feeling like I have a much better grip on the history of my field.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciated having Corina Stan begin by lecturing a little bit about the text and giving us some historical background, and then opening it up for class discussion.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: - Opening lectures working through the text: with such broadly disparate thinkers, it is helpful to get a consistent and knowledgeable perspective on them.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I thought the amount of reading was appropriate for the course. I also thought the readings tended to be well chosen. Having different options for a final project was a great idea; it really allowed students to tailor the course project toward their individual needs.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Again, having different instructors with different areas of expertise come in. It's hard when the scope is the large, we can miss things that seem interesting or important to me, and we aren't able to do so much close reading.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: More discussion of how the criticism is applied to literature. Also, I personally found the class time and location to be difficult.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The theory is dense and sometimes hard to understand. It could be more intellectually stimulating to apply the theory to contemporary life or to literature/art in order to understand the theory better and to generate discussion/debate.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I wish we discussed whether we agreed with these theorists or not, and why. This would have made the course much more stimulating, and would have helped me think about whether these theorists are worth listening to/applying to our work.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It would have been helpful to include more visuals in the class, whether through powerpoint slides or handouts, especially given how much lecturing the class included.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Find how each theoretical topic relates to your interests so they can have more grounding or feel more applicable. If you can't find their relation, ask questions as to why.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Useful if you are looking to get exposed to a lot of the important texts in literary criticism.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you like theory, go for it!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The professor, Corina Stan, is a wonderful scholar and person. She is brilliant, kind, and patient. The content itself, however, can be frustrating and obtuse, and the classroom (because of the texts covered) will likely feel offensive or painful to you if you think differently than the average academic. Expect to learn a lot about theory, but not necessarily whether these theories are useful or meaningful.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The course is worthwhile, although not quite as helpful as it seemed like it would be on paper, particularly because earlier figures were not covered.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Cultural knowledge about the black south and how to question traditional hierarchy

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Critical thinking relating to readings, interdisciplinary perspective, and effective communication of ideas.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned how to cross analyze different types of media when it came to southern African American literature, write blog posts weekly to express our thoughts about this, and discuss how they may connect to larger themes in class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to use intertextuality to talk about contemporary southern literature and how it relates to many themes in race, identity and socio-economic issues still present today. I learned about unique African-American experiences  and the concept of the "Dirty South" as it relates to OutKast.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to conduct critical analyses of contemporary literature, understanding the nuanced conversations about race and socioeconomic class in grappling with oppression and unjust systems. I also learned how to facilitate and engage in discussions with peers to analyze difficult passages and collectively understand its deeper meaning. I also learned how to discuss contemporary media like Beyoncé's visual album and Outkast's music in an academic setting.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The first method I developed and strengthened in the course was the ability to think critically and to revise, the second was asking important questions about the text, and the third was engaging in a group discussion for long periods of time.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was one of the most unique courses I have taken so far at Duke. The largest skill I've learned throughout this course is to deeply engage with literary works. This course teaches you how to critically analyze themes and meanings that may not be obvious on the surface. This course has taught me how to question literature and how to interpret what the author is trying to express.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I came into the class as someone who did not enjoy thinking about things on a deeper level, especially when it concerned issues I felt I did not have a control over. In this class we talked about issues in the Southern African American society, ranging from culture, slavery, to hip hop. This class taught me how to have academic discussions on issues and learn how to analyze content more critically and effectively. I have found myself not only a better speaker, but more able to form critical arguments and discussion points on the spot.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I very much enjoyed the open ended conversation style of the class, and the ability to interact with my classmates ideas Harkness style

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I like the very discussion based class and different types of media that we are exposed to. This was very helpful in making our learning well rounded and I think it should be kept.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The discussions held in class were helpful in understanding the novels.  The way Prof. McInnis enganged with the students and posed questions allowed for excellent insightful conversations.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I absolutely loved this course and the opportunity to engage with contemporary literature and media to further my ability to analyze and reason about systemic racism and collective healing. The engaging readings were so fun to read, and weekly blog posts were great to keep us accountable in completing readings on time. I loved doing our individual and group presentations to better digest the course materials and form my own understanding of prominent themes. I think the structure of the course worked great! Professor McInnis was so knowledgeable and kind, and was very encouraging for students to share our thoughts in class and experiment. He always brought a lot of excitement but also thoughtfulness to class, which I loved.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professor engaged all of the students and was extremely open to ideas posed by students. Almost always, professors will correct students if they are wrong about something, but professor McInnis was open to any and every idea proposed by students, and he took them and used them for the benefit of class discussion.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor McInnis is one of the most passionate professors or teachers I have ever had. I've never met someone as enthusiastic to teach their content to a group of students. Professor McInnis truly cares about what is taught in class and the deep topics that we are analyzing. What made this course so amazing and fascinating was Professor McInnis. Each day, he would show up to class with enthusiasm to go over class readings. Professor McInnis was so knowledgeable about his field that I would often stay after class to ask him about specific passages or unique real world applications of what we go over in class, and he would always take the time to answer my questions thoroughly.Lastly, Professor McInnis would always make sure to find time to meet with me for office hours outside of class if I needed it. There are very few professors who would meet at 6:00 PM on a Friday to answer a students questions. It truly shows how much Professor McInnis cares about his students.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class was a very respectful and welcoming environment. Everyone participated and all of were engaged in the conversations. Something I liked about Professor McInnis was how he facilitated discussions. There would be times where no one would know what to say and he would be able to ask questions or direct us towards a better discussion. For example, when we were supposed to be discussing an experimental text by Randall Kenan, no one said anything because we were all confused by the structure of the reading. He was able to give us a good explanation and change the format of his questions to help us have a good discussion.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Some of the readings explored interesting themes and ideas.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Lots of new ideas!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The questions that forced us to reflect on past historical trauma and ways to wrestle with it were intellectually stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Super engaging readings, books with exciting plot lines, class discussions pulling on lived experiences and analyzing readings, and having the chance to listen to rap music and watch documentaries, films, and music videos to understand the intersection of racial justice and art!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This is an example of a college course that I will always remember. I often hear the saying that college is a time to learn about things that you will never have the opportunity to learn about again. In 20 years, I can always pick up a textbook and learn about mathematical concepts or chemistry, but I will never again get to sit in a room and discuss such important topics that affect society. This class changes the way that you think about the world around you. It allows you to see aspects of society that you would never notice on the surface.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: We had discussions on issues that concerned the South and were encouraged to critically analyze the texts. He welcomed all of our points and made us realize that, with the issues we were discussing, no answer is inherently wrong.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Do the readings to prepare for the classes and stay engaged in class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Very interesting ideas and workload is not too crazy.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely spend time to thoroughly go through the readings to connect to major course themes.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Make sure you stay up to date on readings, complete blog posts on time, and stay communicative with your group for your final project! Also, if you aren't able to buy your books or if the book isn't available at the library, check out Anna's Archive to download PDFs or Apple Book documents for free, it's super helpful.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say do not be afraid to express your own unique opinions about the text, and even if you think they might be slightly different than others, the chances are that a person agrees with you. There is a decent amount of work in the class, and my main message would be to not fall behind.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: My biggest advice to a future student would be to really embrace what this course has to offer. Take the time to read every assigned reading thoroughly(even the optional ones). Each reading has a unique message or purpose. Secondly, don't be afraid to take a risk in discussion or writing and don't be afraid to question. On the blog posts, it can seem tempting to write about a surface level theme, but try to dig deeper and explore a complex theme. Professor McInnis loves when students have a unique perspective on a reading.Lastly, and maybe most importantly, get to know Professor McInnis. By getting to know Professor McInnis, you start to see how truly passionate he is about his work and his courses. When I flunched Professor McInnis, I got to ask all about his career and research. I got to see how knowledgeable he is in his field and how much he cares about what he teaches. By getting to know professor McInnis, I became very comfortable discussing topics with him during class, which made the class that much more engaging.

A lot of time in class we reflected on our own parents teaching styles and wha we would do differently or the same. I think I will take a lot of these insights and use them as a parent myself.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the best part of this course were the literary cafe's. They were great for multiple reasons. The first being that it allowed us to work with our peers in a collaborative setting, which was not done commonly in the class. Secondly, I just think it is frankly a lot less intimidating and easier to share when the students themselves are the ones presenting and asking the questions. Due to this, I think our best discussions came from our literary cafes. I think that the guiding questions that were used for each book were very effective. However, I think more needs to be done to prompt us to engage with the text rather than just asking questions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned about moral ambiguity and the role of censorship in society. A lot of the discussion encouraged critical thinking to get a holistic view of a situation. The Go Deeper Projects allowed us to learn from each other about some major topics/themes of the course: authoritarianism, moral panic, critical race theory and response, and the concept of a child.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:

Being able to communicate thoughts on a certain topic through discussions was a skill that I developed in this course.
One of the key take aways was how book banning itself is a form of authoritarian control.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Collaboration skill: it is a seminar with 15 people so we have good opportunities to work with each of the other students. 
reading and discussing: there are a lot of reading for this course compared to other courses. discussion also heavily relies on the things we read in class and each person's ability to engage in a conversation. I feel like the course is a really good exercise for me just because we are exposed to discussions all the time. 
Time management skill: because there are a lot of reading, it is up to the students themselves to organize the readings and find time to read them. The course has definitely prepared me for future readings.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I definitely learned more ways to read a book. Like the unjustified/justified margins. It made me realize that when reading a book for class you have to REALLY pay attention to all aspects and details and not just the themes of the book.
I learned how to read critical readings. It was fairly difficult cause it was a different type of academic writing but it was very insightful. 
I learned better critical thinking skills and expanding on others' ideas.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
In this course, I developed a more holistic understanding of medicine, moving beyond the rigid, science-focused perspective that dominates most of my other studies. I learned to view medicine through the lens of the humanities, realizing that understanding human experiences of illness, suffering, and healing requires more than just scientific knowledge. The course taught me that literature and the arts offer essential tools for developing empathy, which is critical in patient care. They not only foster compassion but also enhance our imagination and critical thinking, which are vital when dealing with complex or unconventional medical situations, such as in military settings. This expanded perspective has made me believe that the humanities are as crucial to medical practice as the hard sciences, helping us navigate the emotional and relational aspects of patient care that science alone cannot explain.
Additionally, the course sharpened my analytical skills and taught me the importance of engaging critically with materials. Instead of passively accepting the views presented in texts or media, I learned to question assumptions, contrast perspectives with my own medical experiences, and think critically about the information at hand. This skill has become especially valuable in a world where misinformation is rampant. Moreover, the course provided a unique collaborative learning environment, where I not only learned from the professor but also from my classmates, whose diverse backgrounds and experiences enriched my understanding of the material. Through this, I developed a deeper ability to listen carefully and empathetically, a skill that will be indispensable in my medical practice.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The overall learning environment of this class was shaped significantly by both the course structure and, more importantly, by Professor Apple’s teaching style. One component that stood out to me was the keyword readings, which were especially practical for understanding key concepts in medicine. Terms like “patient” were dissected in a way that revealed their complexity and depth, encouraging us to think critically about language and its implications in healthcare. These readings were invaluable in challenging our preconceived notions and reshaping the way we think about medical practice. The active class discussions that followed these readings further enriched my understanding. Engaging with peers in dialogue, guided by Professor Apple’s expertise, allowed us to explore various interpretations of the texts, connecting them to our own experiences in medicine. I think future iterations of the course could benefit from a balanced approach, perhaps a 50/50 split between didactic lectures and discussions. Having more time dedicated to exploring scholarly perspectives and Professor Apple’s own insights on the texts would be a great way to deepen our analysis and understanding.
However, the structure and components of the course were only part of what made it truly exceptional. Above all, it was Professor Apple’s character and teaching style that created a learning environment where I felt both intellectually challenged and personally inspired. Her positive attitude, enthusiasm, and the respect she showed for each student fostered a space of genuine curiosity and open dialogue. More than just teaching the course content, Professor Apple embodied the qualities of a compassionate, thoughtful, and ethical physician, and I learned just as much from her personal example as I did from the readings. A friend of mine from another university who sat in with me on one of her classes remarked that it was unlike any class he had ever experienced—highlighting the depth of the discussions and the dynamic group activities that Professor Apple facilitated. This feedback, along with my own experience, underscores her exceptional ability to teach and connect with students. Duke is fortunate to have such a dedicated and insightful instructor, and I believe future students will greatly benefit from the structure, content, and, most importantly, the teacher herself.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
This class was undeniably intellectually stimulating, offering a wealth of thought-provoking material and engaging discussions. One of the most stimulating aspects was the class discussions themselves, where hearing from other students exposed me to perspectives I had not previously considered. These diverse viewpoints challenged my assumptions and expanded my thinking, emphasizing the value of deep listening in truly understanding complex issues. I came to realize that true comprehension does not always stem from agreeing with others, but rather from engaging respectfully and thoughtfully with their ideas. This ability to listen deeply and consider opposing perspectives is a crucial skill, both in medicine and in life.
Beyond the discussions, the readings chosen by Professor Apple were another key element of what made this class so intellectually enriching. The texts were not only thought-provoking but also incredibly relevant, as they delved into aspects of human behavior that are central to understanding the practice of medicine. These readings brought a practical dimension to our exploration, offering insights into how we can better understand and relate to patients, colleagues, and ourselves. They grounded theoretical ideas in real-world scenarios, making the intellectual experience both engaging and applicable. In this way, the course nicely combined rich intellectual content with practical applicability, creating a stimulating learning environment that was both deep and meaningful.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you’re considering taking this course, I highly recommend it, whether you're a pre-health student or not. The exploration of literature and medicine offers profound insights into what it truly means to be a compassionate and ethical human being, which is valuable in any field. For pre-health students, the readings are particularly impactful, as they not only deepen your understanding of medical practice but also provide new perspectives on what it means to be a caring and empathetic doctor. The course challenges you to think beyond clinical skills, helping you reflect on the human side of medicine—how to truly listen to patients, understand their experiences, and approach care with both scientific knowledge and deep empathy. It’s a course that will not only shape you as a future healthcare provider but also as a more thoughtful, reflective individual.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Koo structured the course in a way that balanced thematic progression with skill development. Weekly paragraphs encouraged consistent engagement, while short essays scaffolded our final paper. Her clear prompts, regular check-ins, and individualized support—especially during office hours and workshops—made a huge difference. The flexibility to explore our interests (e.g., choosing our own topics/texts for essays) fostered genuine curiosity and intellectual risk-taking. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much in this course, because of Mike and the content he taught. I developed a new appreciation for films and learned how to analyze them through visual language as well as the actual plot. I learned how to rethink a text in terms of both what I thought it meant and what the book wanted me to think it meant. I also learned how to have meaningful discussion about complicated texts and learned that not everything has a straightforward message but that it's important to walk away with a few. Lastly, Mike has taught me a lot about writing and how to develop my writing style without letting go of my personality in my writing. I really learned how to not take things so seriously in a paper while also effectively arguing an intellectual point.

There are a lot of underlining themes and motifs that I never considered when reading, watching, and interpreting such works. I gained a deeper knowledge for identifying these key themes and how characters operate. I think my critical skills of reading and writing improved as well as overall analysis of these fantastical works.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the construction of fantasy and it's associated themes, tropes, characteristics. I learned how to analyze movies and text. I learned that evaluating fantasy as "escapism" is a limited viewpoint.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the different tropes and themes that make up the fantasy genre and how cultural products deconstruct these things in modern times compared to years ago.I learned about Dungeons and Dragons, its history and development, how to play it in an actual campaign, and how it has influenced the mainstream cultural sphere of fantasy and been influenced in return.I learned how to analyze fantasy works on a deeper level, be it text, film, or photos, to find what about the fantasy reflects real-world ideals and how they sometimes mirror movements happening when fantasy cultural products are released.

response_text: It was an enjoyable class. The readings were typically solid and sometimes really good. I never had to work more than 3 or 4 hours in a week. The professors are very fair. As long as you attend class and do your weekly blog post and put in effort on the essays, you will be fine.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: 2 Midterms that are short essay format, then one paper in addition to the readings for each class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's a very enjoyable class, not too much work, the instructors are lovely, and the content is engaging.

response_text: If you like fantasy definitely consider taking the course. You get a lot of reading recs from it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course helped me to think critically about texts and analyze what is happening within them. I had not previously done this with a texts and I found it extremely interesting. I also learned a lot about fairy tales and different forms of analysis.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much in this class! From theories of fairy tale analysis to expanding my repertoire of the fairy tale genre - this class has been incredible.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the concepts of the evolution of storytelling, considered how sociopolitical climates influence stories, and examined the deeper meanings of fairytales.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned the history of fairy tales, from prior to the 16th century all the way to today. 
I learned how to analyze literature and media in a variety of different ways through a variety of different lenses.
I learned how to compare and contrast texts on a high level.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed critical and deeper understanding in fairy tales, and I learned how to interpret them with different perspectives such as historical view, feminism, psychoanalysis, media, etc. I also have an insight of the difference between collective-literature and authorship-literature, which is a very interesting topic that I've never heard of.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned the different scholarly approaches to fairy tales and how to analyze them using those theories
2) thinking about why fairy tales are structured or written the way they are: i.e. the depthlessness of fairy tales
3) how to skim articles

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned how to contextualize

I learned how to compare and contrast the stances of different theorists, many of who wrote in different time periods

response_text: I learned different lenses through which I can interpret fairy tales, learned about adaptation and oral storytelling, and learned about conventions to the fairy tale genre.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the history of Arthurian legends, where the stories came from, and how the British political scene deeply impacted the stories as well as Christianity. We also learned about how Arthur adaptations have changed over time in various forms from Disney, to comic books, contemporary novels, etc,.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Since this was my first university English class, I developed collegiate writing skills including style, structure, and format. I also learned more about analyzing a large stretch of history, especially in the context of a singular frame of literature reestablished and repurposed for hundreds of years. I also gained a higher level of understanding of English history and the traditions of oral history.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

-Some of the the historical bases for the Arthurian legend

-How modern artists have adapted and taken from the legend to apply to discuss the issues of our time

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: We did numerous group presentations that were very engaging and open ended enough to allow for a lot of creativity. The class time was filled with lively discussions and we had 2-3 papers that were relevant to the course and allowed us to input our own interests into the class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Henry worked more than most any of my professors here to engage the class in not only understanding the material, but applying it to itself and to modern society. Bringing in literature ranging from 400 CE to the 2020s showed the incredible depth of the subject topic and also her adaptation as a scholar to the various evolutions of Arthurian literature over time. She was an incredible instructor, providing extensive feedback on essays and assignments and establishing a solid foundation for the rest of my years of studying English here at Duke.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We became well-versed in modern European short fiction and the genre's many renowned authors, such as Kafka, Svevo, Joyce, Woolf, Dostoevsky, Pirandello, Mann, Sartre, Camus, etc. We examined these works through the lens of five primary themes—animals, family and home, love, guilt, and the Holocaust—and determined how the stories can be categorized under one or more of these themes. We learned the distinction between modernism, post-modernism, existentialism, absurdism, communism, syndicalism, anarchism, and other ideologies in a literary context. We had the privilege of visiting the Rare Books library and picking works to analyze closely and the Nasher to look at the works of Chagall, Dali, and other relevant artists, as well as to do a compare/contrast essay on a short story and its film adaptation. These experiences allowed us to appreciate the important differences between different media: short vs. long-form fiction, final versions vs. galley proofs, film, and art. I also learned how to write a concise but effective paper, since our longest paper had a limit of three pages. Lastly, I learned how to appropriately analyze a short story by taking into consideration the plot, characters, author, and political/social implications.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how to analyze literary works in relation to their  historical context. I learned about surrealism in literature and I also learned about the impact of stylistic features and literary devices (as similitudes or imagery) on the reader.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze writing styles, word choice, and how to access the rarebook library.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think my analytical writing improved. I gained a better understanding and general knowledge of European literature.

response_text: Got better at analytical writing, was exposed to writers of Europe's past, and got better at interpretive reading.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained substantial knowledge of authors, works, and movements that are significant to European literature.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I love the way the course was structured, both the overarching structure of different themes for different groups of stories and the day-to-day structure of reading 1-5 short stories for class, coming to class to discuss in-depth, and then writing a short paper about a handful of these stories later on. I loved the unique opportunities the class had to offer, namely the Rare Books and Nasher visits and Francesca Magario guest lecture (I loved that lecture!). I loved the variety of papers: the close reading of a Kafka short short story, Rare Books object paper, animal research paper, and film and passage comparison essay. This is also the only humanities class in which I've had an exam, but I think it made sense to include it as an assessment because it forced me to stay on top of the readings (and come to class) and not just skim them. It meant I thoroughly read each story to learn the author's style and the story's influence. Professor Z is very insightful, prepared for class, engaging, and accommodating with deadlines, and she really shines when her students reciprocate an interest in the content. I was in a class with her last semester where the students were in general less engaged, which I think limited her teaching. This time around, most of the class came having done the readings with interesting takeaways/interpretations and ready to discuss, and this meant she could offer more as a professor as well. The professor and the students, in addition to the stories we read, made this class truly one of my favorites that I have taken at Duke.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this course if you can! It was one of my favorite classes that I have taken at Duke. The readings are both thought-provoking and entertaining, as are the in-class discussions we had about them. By the end of the course, you'll be able to say that you're well-versed in modern European short fiction authors like Kafka, Joyce, Woolf, Dostoevsky, Mann, Sartre, Camus, etc. You get to do some cool out-of-class excursions too, like to the Rare Books library and the Nasher. The professor is very knowledgeable, effectively facilitates class discussions, and is very accommodating with deadlines. Plus the papers are very short (max 3 pages). There is one exam where you have to match 12 or so quotes to their author/work and write about the immediate context and significance of the quote, but it is very doable if you do all the readings and come to class consistently. I genuinely have no criticisms of this class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a knowledge of eras, how those eras and the events during shaped the thoughts of philosophers during those times, and how those philosophers built thoughts on previous thoughts. And all of this knowledge was achieved through reading prominent, classic literature that we were able to learn how to interpret and interact with in order to gain philosophical insights from them. It was very interesting how each philosopher's circumstances drove their thinking, and how that thinking was able to be built upon and developed over time throughout many more eras and philosophers. And it was all about arguably the most important question one can ask themselves: what is the meaning of life? I was able to learn more about philosophers who thought there is an inherent meaning to life and what that meaning looked like to them, that there is not meaning to life, or that certain factors/experiences/mindsets could give one meaning.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

3) I have become more conscious of the ways in which I do and don't pay attention in my life, and have begun cultivating that skill in my own behavior.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really appreciated the openness to questions through discussions and the Slack channel, and I also enjoyed the handouts from the class presentations and slideshows.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
- i loved the seminar structured way of teaching that was interspersed with explanations of other philosophers (ie i liked professor moi's connections of weil, beauvoir, and murdoch with wittgenstein, cavell, and plato) because they not only allowed me to think deeper about the concepts i learn, but also open up new territories for me to explore in the future
- the weekly attention journals are also very helpful, because it forces me to sit down and reflect on the philosophy and also put things i learn into practice (paying attention)

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Moi encouraged genuine reflection with our attention journals. These were not graded on the A-F scale, which allowed them to be purely for our own building of the skill of attention without having to pander or have a grade in the back of our minds. I would definitely keep this part of the course. I also found Professor Moi's lectures interesting. The breaking up of the three philosophers into three separate parts rather than going between them also made them digestible so that they didn't get convoluted.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Absolutely, when the material gets a bit too hard, Professor Moi made slides to accommodate and overall the in-class discussions were very fruitful. And I really liked the idea of using Slack channel to talk about difficult concepts.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Smaller readings allowed me to pay closer attention to each text and get more out of subsequent lectures and discussions. I liked the attention journals as a way to keep me closely engaged with the texts throughout the week.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I thought that in terms of content, the course flowed quite nicely. I thought beginning with Weil and ending with Murdoch (from our big three names) was the ideal order, with Weil's concept of attention framing the whole course and Murdoch's vision-based moral theory bringing together attention and action, as well as offering a more realistic and individualized moral approach (compared to Weil's saintly expectations and Beauvoir's more politically-grounded perspective).

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: some parts I just didn't understand or so much reading was given over a weekend and i have so many other things to do for my other classes that i wasn't able to do it (e.g. a whole novel was given over a weekend)

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was very stimulating because of the ties to other fields of thought and in-depth analysis.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I have not delved deeply into either of these three thinkers in my prior classes and being able to engage deeply with the three thinkers made this class stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The readings are extremely complex and challenging, so it was certainly a class where you would always have to think deeply in relation to every component of the course: writing, asking questions, making presentations, and reading.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The readings are all very enlightening. I think the class was stimulating because of how it connects three philosophers together and shows a connecting thread among very different ideas.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I feel like adding more literature would make the class more stimulating and would make it so that the philosophy actually has to be dealt with and applied to examples. With the purpose of paying attention,  I think there is also a lot more room for poetry!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The discussions and slack channels!!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The course texts and class discussion were both very interesting and illuminating on the moral theories of these three women and the ways in which that could apply to any individual's ordinary life.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: i definitely recommend! great professor and the other students who take this course were amazing. it is sometimes difficult to grasp if you've never read philosophy before but still do-able

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take this course, meet with the professor in office hours, and be ready to devote time to thinking about the readings in order to fully understand their concepts.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is challenging but fruitful - you will learn a new way of thinking about Weil, Beauvoir, and Murdoch. Professor Moi is clearly an expert in her field and takes teaching very seriously. I felt that she was able to open up the readings we did in class in a way that helped me grasp the main ideas more easily.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's certainly a challenging course, and can feel a bit intimidating at times, but it also is extremely rewarding in that you'll end the semester with a thorough understanding of several important and relevant philosophical ideas.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course will give you a good understanding of various philosophers that are not often taught in the philosophy department. Learning about Weil has really expanded my view of the world. I see her influence everywhere and am so glad I learned about her in particular.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Strongly recommend. These philosophers we learned in this class, inter alia, were wonderful and provided a different vision in terms of our daily dealing with others.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are open to this kind of influence, this class will affect the way you move in the world and your relationships. There were times I didn't necessarily feel very intellectually stimulated, but then would find myself considering concepts from class in non-class situations.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would definitely recommend this course, or any course taught by Professor Moi! Though her classes are challenging, she is an absolutely wonderful professor, and the works she teaches will transform the way you think about your own life.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Reading difficult complex philosophy, thinking about the relation between literature and philosophy, and articulating thoughts and writing thoughts about complex philosophy.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned how to analyze philosophical texts and thin deeply about the concepts they cover. I also learned how to write essays that further my understanding of philosophy.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Reading skill. I read many excellent readings with the professor and my classmates.
2. Writing skill. I wrote posts every week and had a chance to develop longer esaay.
3. Presentation skill.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about Weil, Beauvior and Murdoch, three female philosphers and their worldviews. I learned how to write more philosphical paper as well as really think philosphically

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The course definitely improved my ability to write both through the activity of writing (blog posts, the first essay), but moreso through an engagement with writers in an active manner that helped to inculcate what effective writing looks like and feels like. Most importantly, the course helped to teach me the importance of attention throughout my life, and to equip me with different tools for the training and use of attention.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Each reading we were assigned was very deliberate in advancing a specific philosophical concept, which I enjoyed. I also appreciated how they were all manageable in length/content such that it was actually feasible to read everything before the next class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the lecture, and the weekly reading posts. It was a perfect mix of discussion and lecturing. Honestly for these types of classes with very thorough dense philosophy, I prefer lecture more which this class leaned towards a bit more.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
