question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the readings that we did and the lectures in class really complemented each other. I really enjoyed the blog posting aspect as well as it gave me a really great opportunity to think, because writing is thinking

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that both class discussion and the blog postings were effective. Some of the moments of the course which helped me understand the texts the most were engagements with the texts on the clas blog, both through my own postings as well as through the exploration of my classmate's ideas on the topics.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I really liked the connections between the philosophy and literature and found I was really able to connect with the main ideas of each of the thinkers and take in what they say as a part of my own world view.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Good in depth exploration and explanation of the thinkers discussed. The selected writings were very well selected and in concert with one another so that each week's reading felt like it effectively constructed my knowledge.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take this class if you are interesting in philosophy, literature, theory or anything related at all. Note that this is not a feminist philosophy class, more so a class about women philosophers. I think these are philosophers that are underrated in the academic canon, although Beauvoir is quite popular now. But definitely Simone Weil is an underrated writer and philosopher that everyone should read. Professor Moi is also a great teacher who understands students and the texts quite well. The amount of texts you read in this class is perfect. Long enough that you get a deep enough understanding of the philosopher, but also not too long so that it becomes unmanageable. The texts are also enlightening and perfectly difficult to understand so when you do get some insight it feels nice and illuminating.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: prepare to read and start your essays ealry!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Readings are not easy but interesting

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: As with most reading based humanities courses, you get in what you put out. I think you should take to heart the teachings of the writers, paying attention, opening yourself up, awknowledgement to really get a complete engagement with everything we learn about

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You should! Its one of the best philosophy and one of the best literature classes I've taken at Duke, and it has spillover not just to the everyday but to the everyday within the University which is helpful.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. How to think and read about what Wittgenstein is doing in Philosophical Investigation. 
2. The context of philosophy of language which Wittgenstein is responding to and that which he himself spurs 
3. Relationship between and stakes of skepticism, knowledge/acknowledgement, literature, and morality as they invoked in ordinary language philosophy

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned to see language in a different way.
I learned about Wittgenstein's later philosophy.
I learned how to do philosophy as an expression of my self.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: A ground-level understanding of Wittgenstein, including terminology like "grammar" and "criteria"; what it means to conduct a Wittgensteinian investigation; some of the consequences of Wittgenstein's diagnoses for philosophy and literary theory more broadly

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I like the blog posts assignment because I felt the instructor was earnestly asking us to write about what confused us. I appreciated her replies to these posts. I also thought class discussion and the knowledge and context which the instructor provided were very good. I appreciated the instructor's transparency and genuineness in her answers to questions.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The seminar was great. One of the best classes I've had at Duke. Prof does a great job of leading seminars, leading people to the right directions and not straying too far from topic.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Moi really has a great style of teaching. It has been a great journey that she guided us through Wittgenstein's work. I think we first-time learners of Wittgenstein all somewhat have a tendency to fall into the trap of abstraction and over-philosophicalization, and Wittgensteinian spirit is really all about get outside such a picture.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The blog posts and required responses were very helpful; the relatively slow pace of the readings was also very conducive to actual understanding of the material

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: See above.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Learning about a philosopher with a radically new vision of language, and connecting it to literary theory - if this is not stimulating for a philosophy student, I don't know what is.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The content, especially the readings

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I'd recommend it. I think it provides a way of thinking which is otherwise and often missing from other classes and intellectual discussions on the topic of language.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Must take.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are interested in ordinary language philosophy or Wittgenstein, take this class!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
This course was excellent. I appreciate the attention to specificity and the care taken when editing writing in groups. I learned the following:
o Note taking is vital - It is more important to capture how I feel about material rather than block quotes and theoretical applicability. This include WHERE the source material comes from.
o Trust my own voice. I don't have to adhere to academic writing standard if they do not satisfy my interpretation
o Solicit peer feedback. Often times, if peers can understand what I am writing, then the writing is clear. I cannot assume people understand what I am writing about.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Took my note-taking more seriously and learned about different techniques 
2. I feel like I was able to get more clear and precise in my writing - working on slowing down and letting a sentence to one thing at a time 
3. Dissecting others' individual sentences and figuring out what's wrong with them - being able to pinpoint this more precisely

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think I learned how to find my own voice in my writing and work on editing my and others' work for clarity and cohesion.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to more critically and self-reflectively read my own writing and assess my own writing practices. I have a better understanding of how to manage long-term writing projects like dissertations. I am familiar with the teachings of the most popular academic style guides and have practiced implementing their suggestions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned how to identity what was going wrong in my writing and how to fix it.
I learned what a plethora of academic authors have to say on the topic of writing through class book reviews.
I learned how to note-take effectively and consistently, and why that matters.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 1) Writing good sentences because my sentences were horribly confusing and prevented my thoughts from being effectively communicated. 2) Writing groups can be very helpful to the overall writing process, both mentally/emotionally through discussion about the process and making progress in writing. 3) Writing class is absolutely needed for graduate students, especially those who are interested in PhD work. In a field of work where writing essentially is the job, it is almost fraudulent that graduate programs do not teach the basic skills. There ought to be creative ways that graduate programs teach students write throughout the curriculum, rather than simply claiming that writing skills should be learned before students enter graduate school. The education system today simply does not work that way anymore.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Perhaps the most important skill I gained from this class was an ability to really critically contemplate the details of my writing experience, in a manner that often seems "irrelevant" to graduate students. We come to think we know how to write and therefore do not pay attention to the minutiae of what we're doing and forget that each little thing is a choice--one that matters significantly. I also gained confidence in (and excitement about) the practice of sharing my work with others productively and began developing a note-taking habit unique to my PhD work that I know will serve me well as I head into my reading year and teh dissertation stage of the program.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned invaluable skills about how to organize my research, take notes with lasting meaning, and write with improved clarity. This class was the first one devoted to writing instruction that I had taken in years, and it was a wonderful addition to a grad school curriculum. People so often assume that graduate students know how to write, but it is very helpful to have a course specifically geared toward improving graduate-level writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned how to take generative notes. 
2. How do I pace myself in writing towards long projects?
3. I learned how to share my work and receive feedback.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Well, I may not raise myself to the level of three here, but in general I found this course refreshing in a semester where I was mired in irritatingly dense theoretical prose that made me want to rip all my hair out and eat it. I do think it taught me to pay a little more attention to brevity in my sentences -- to break them up and make them shorter when I can. For that alone it's been of use. I also think it taught me a lot about how totally irritating and inward-facing academia is, and how difficult it is to really produce anything of worth in this environment.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I love the conversational method of instruction, Professor Moi's class is master class on writing. Here examples are clear, approachable and appropriate. I especially appreciate the amount of content she makes available on Sakai. One of the take aways for me is to be more deliberate about my writing practice, and allow myself to free write without judgement. I also appreciate seeing my peers writing, it validates my writing ability and show me what I am capable of given patience, focus, and time.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Created an environment where critique between students and their respective writings didn't feel personal.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the targeted and weekly individual feedback from the Professor was invaluable. She clearly spent so much of her time helping us improve, and I (and we) am / are better for it.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Moi gave generous and extensive feedback on our writing every week. I felt really privileged to have that kind of attention on my writing. I also benefitted from regularly hearing a wide range of perspectives from other students in mini-workshop settings.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciated how multi-dimensional the learning was. I learned via oral discussion, as well as via written examples ("some sentences" exercise). I appreciated getting to read about writing (book reviews), write about writing (notetaking essay), write (200 words weekly), and edit myself & others.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The collaborative environment allowed me to see where other students are in their writing. I always felt that I was an inadequate writer because in graduate programs, I read published essays that have been refined (thus high quality) and my own writing, which I often submit quickly (thus low quality). But seeing other people write made me realize that writing is difficult for everyone. And working through writing together helped me to be ok with my own writing and see how my writing could improve through writings of others.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I'm not sure how it was done or who was responsible, but from the first day of this course the learning environment was incredibly comfortable, caring, and productive. A course like this requires so much vulnerability, difficult for anyone but especially for those early on in a career in which our ability to do THIS ONE THING very well feels crucial. It was so wonderful to find myself in a space in which that vulnerability, while maybe still a bit uncomfortable, was not frightening--in which I could laugh at myself--in which I felt unconcerned about sharing honest and sometimes challenging feedback with others.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked have regular writing exercises that encouraged us to try different techniques and styles.  The readings were generally very helpful. I also liked seeing examples from my classmates, particularly about how they take notes.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The weekly "some sentences" practice taught me how to edit my work and that of others. Also, knowing that Toril would be giving me feedback on my 200 words, I became more precise in my writing to get more input on content and less on structure. 
The note-taking practice allowed me to get to know my mind and begin figuring out how I am as a writer and thinker.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Toril's frank attitude and her open approach to discussion is probably the most important aspect of the course, even if it is sometimes the most terrifying aspect as well!I would probably keep Some Sentences, albeit with the caveat that sometimes you have absolutely NO DESIRE to stand by anything you wrote in your 200 words some weeks. (There should be a big button you get to push that bails you out of your chair in the seminar room if that's the case, like in a fighter plane that's going down.)I also liked writing the book reviews a lot and wish there were more longer assignments in the course.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The stakes are always high when your writing can be displayed for scrutiny, I appreciate this rigor and grew from it. This aspect of the course kept us on our toes.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Precision and level of specificity and attention to detail to sentences. Writing the 200-word papers and getting feedback very quickly afterward.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The course was very stimulating, but I did feel that some of the style guides got repetitive after a while and those readings (+ the notes I took on them) took up time that I could have spent practicing writing.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: "Some sentences" was by far the most stimulating part. It helped me move beyond recognizing "bad" writing, to knowing what exactly about it was "bad" and how to fix it.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Fixing sentences together as a class was really important. And also, realized that the letters/sentences on paper are the objective mirror of my internal thinking. So I had to fix the sentences if I wanted my thinking to be communicated clearly.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: As I've written above, I would have liked a greater proportion of the course to be spent on writing rather than reading and discussions of what we'd read. I loved the "some sentences" practice we did every day and enjoyed other small writing activities that were a part of the course, and found these to be incredibly intellectually stimulating. I have never had another opportunity to think about my own writing (or the writing of others) like that.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The readings were excellent, and the weekly note-taking assignments made me think more deeply about what I was reading both for this class and for other classes I was taking.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The writing groups were an incredible addition to the class. I appreciated meeting with a group of my colleagues once a week in the second half of the term.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This was really about the same level of intellectual stimulation as all my other courses, but I got something useful out of it at least.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be bold and be vulnerable. Now is the time show blindspots. The course will help you become a better thinker and a better writer!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Great class to take at any level of your process, but also great to take as a first-year.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would strongly recommend the course, but might caution that it is an intense experience to have your writing held up under this kind of microscope. Not necessarily a bad thing :)

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is a writing heavy course that will give you MUCH completed work to look back on. For a graduate student especially, it gave me the time and space and push I needed to get a lot of writing and note-taking done that will use in the future!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Absolutely take it, especially if you are interested in doctoral work (or any other field of work where writing will matter).

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course will get inside your brain in ways that can be very challenging but, in the end, so so useful if you let it be.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would absolutely take this course.  It is a lot more work during the semester than other courses because there are many weekly deadlines, but it is totally worth it.  My writing grew immensely, and I am very grateful to have had the opportunity to take this course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class changed my life and will continue to change my life as I metabolize all that I've learned this term. Though I wish I had taken it in the first semester of my Ph.D. I think having had the first year to understand the particularities and cadences of a doctoral program made taking it in my second year the best time to do it. Writing is Thinking has made me a better writer, reader, and confident person as it relates to both. Receiving weekly feedback on my writing helped me hone in on my personal writing skills and begin to figure out how to change/adjust them. More than that, this class forced me to confront my anxieties around writing and my fears of being seen as not being good enough. Though neither of those has "gone away" per se, I am now more able to sit with them and take more responsibility for how I sometimes allow them to overwhelm me. Toril seems intimidating, but she is so deeply kind. So kind. Receiving consistent feedback and engagement with your writing and thinking from someone so deeply invested in both is not something that happens even 2% of the time in graduate school. Most people never receive that, and the few who do receive it too late. The class might feel scary, but you will be deeply cared for while not being coddled, and you will grow a lot in the process

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I improved my writing skills, specifically for literary analysis, I learned how to better understand and interpret the genre of literary critique, and I learned how to think critically about books and their social impact.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned about moral ambiguity and the role of censorship in society. A lot of the discussion encouraged critical thinking to get a holistic view of a situation. The Go Deeper Projects allowed us to learn from each other about some major topics/themes of the course: authoritarianism, moral panic, critical race theory and response, and the concept of a child.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned how to write a critical reading piece such as learning how to use words such as "I" in order to convey arguments.
Being able to communicate thoughts on a certain topic through discussions was a skill that I developed in this course.
One of the key take aways was how book banning itself is a form of authoritarian control.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Critical thinking in response to reading texts. Original thinking was pushed and rewarded highly as a way to allow people to think creatively. Balancing reading large amounts of text and distilling important ideas to bring to a class discussion.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The main thing would be critical thinking. I definitely developed the skill of taking into consideration both sides and evaluating how to make sense of the duality.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Collaboration skill: it is a seminar with 15 people so we have good opportunities to work with each of the other students. 
reading and discussing: there are a lot of reading for this course compared to other courses. discussion also heavily relies on the things we read in class and each person's ability to engage in a conversation. I feel like the course is a really good exercise for me just because we are exposed to discussions all the time. 
Time management skill: because there are a lot of reading, it is up to the students themselves to organize the readings and find time to read them. The course has definitely prepared me for future readings.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I definitely learned more ways to read a book. Like the unjustified/justified margins. It made me realize that when reading a book for class you have to REALLY pay attention to all aspects and details and not just the themes of the book.
I learned how to read critical readings. It was fairly difficult cause it was a different type of academic writing but it was very insightful. 
I learned better critical thinking skills and expanding on others' ideas.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

The instructor creates a very friendly environment and makes it easy for every person to share their views.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I thoroughly enjoyed this class. I really liked how prof. Wiegman took feedback from the class, she was always very receptive and realized when the class was going too fast, or when we needed more time to talk about a certain reading. Prof. Wiegman was also great at facilitating class and asked great and thought-provoking questions. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Journalism

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I developed a deeper understanding of the societal impact of journalism, learned to evaluate it from diverse perspectives, and gained familiarity with various storytelling forms and evolving methods. The exposure to superior reporting and writing and an AMAZING, artfully curated lineup of guest speakers enhanced my research and writing skills, and the exploration of social issues expanded my cultural/historical knowledge.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course fundamentally altered the way in which I view my Duke education. Frank Bruni went above and beyond what it means to be a college professor and in the process helped shape the way in which I view my future career. I garnered the knowledge to engage critically with masterworks of journalism, how to speak to (super impressive) people with confidence and intelligence, and how to be a better eriter!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course helped me grow a lot as a critical thinker and as a writer. I have always loved writing, but have never taken a journalism class before so it was really exciting to get to write pieces about current events and issues that matter in the world today.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I've become a much better writer because of this course. 
I have a much better idea of what good long-form journalism looks like.
I've read some amazing writing that I had no idea about before this course. 
By exposing me to some of the best examples of writing that do so, this course has made me think a lot about how to make connections between seemingly disparate things. I believe that I will continue to actively do so in my daily life.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I had never taken a journalism course before, and I certainly learned what good journalism reads like, and how to get my writing closer to that. I also talked to many individuals who have devoted their lives to writing in various ways, which has allowed me to get a better understanding of my own future after college.

3. The goals and motivations of journalists.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Frank truly does a commendable job engaging every single student in this class and making each contribution feel important and worthwhile. He makes sure time is shared fairly and appropriately and does his due diligence entertaining different perspectives. Frank is always professional and prepared, but also adaptable. It was always exciting to come to class and see where he would take us with the material. I particularly liked when he picked specific marvelous sentences out of the readings to share with us.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The interviews were incredible (guest speakers), the readings were astonishing, and the open class debate format was exceptional.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Loved the guest speakers. Such a privilege to be able to ask them questions of our own. The varied reading assignments kept the class super engaging throughout

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
This class was really special. I'm reflecting on the number of great writers and thinkers I've been able to engage with through this class-- both directly and through their writing. It's truly astounding. If I'm counting correctly I've had the chance to speak to six Pulitzer Prize winners. It makes feel really grateful to be at Duke.
Even though it was a two and a half hour class, I never felt disengaged on bored. The way our time was divided between discussing our readings, hearing from guest speakers, and reflecting on what we heard in the context of what we'd learnt made every minute of each session very interesting. I also feel that the workload was very reasonable.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The comments that both Matt Schossler and Professor Bruni left on my writing were insightful and motivated me to put more effort into my assignments. Additionally, having regular speakers from a variety of backgrounds has strengthened my understanding of what being a writer entails.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Out of all the professors I've had, Professor Bruni was the best discussion leader I've had the opportunity to learn under. In the safest way possible, Professor Bruni was able to bring dissent and unique opinions into our discussions. Every reading was also very interesting. Probably one of my top two favorite classes at Duke University.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's not just that you won't regret taking this course. You will regret NOT taking this course. Being able to hear Frank speak about his experiences, career, and network alone would be worthwhile, but the speakers and readings will also broaden your horizons, help you learn more about yourself and your world, and make you feel accomplished.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this course if you want your life to be changed. Period. If you have all bad professors at Duke but you take this class once, you will leave satisfied with your experience.

I would honestly take this class a second time if I had room in my schedule.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned more about existentialism and nihilism. Those were concepts I wasn't familiar with coming into the course. I appreciated the opportunity to challenge the traditional existentialist canon that centers white men. As a non-white student this was helpful in getting and keeping me engaged in the course. I really appreciated the was that Professor Winters paired traditional existential readings with those that engaged gender, race, and class in different ways. I was also encouraged to think about the ways other scholars engage with themes from existentialism.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Throughout this course I learned skills that not only shaped the way I viewed learning material (reading plays and understanding scene work) but it also allowed for me to see how all parts of theater are connected. We learned the historical backgrounds of many pieces while also understanding the foundations of acting in practice (Aristotle) and what makes a piece objectively successful.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. plays as blueprints and artifacts
2. the broad history of the development of Western theater--how we get from The Bacchae to Cloud 9
3. how to think about productions in terms of efficacy, how to direct a scene so that it is an effective adaptation of the text

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

It’s is a class that delves into all of the components that make a successful production. It’s intellectually stimulating but you must do the background work to contribute to the class effectively.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Make sure you set aside plenty of time to do the reading! You lose so much when you speed-read plays.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would tell them that while the course is pretty time consuming, Torry makes it incredibly interesting.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to critically read plays, envision them within the context of a full production, and interpret how the playwright's choices affect different productions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: A greater insight into theater history; critical evaluation of space, lighting, costuming, and blocking as it adds or detracts from themes present in a play; greater understanding of the directorial, acting, and set design process; greater appreciation for playwrights and theater in general

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- analyzing the design component of a play
- memorizing lines
- evaluating a performance in real time

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to read a play critically in relation to its cultural, historical and theatrical contexts. I learned (1) how to analyze presentational v. representational theatre, (2) the format of the script and cast of an ancient Greek play, and (3) the importance and difficulty of making bold choices in theatre.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Acting, directing, designing

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Lots of important theater vocab, the difference between presentational and representational theater, costume design.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the different components that go into a production (with hands-on experience), I learned how to more deeply analyze plays and identify themes supported by the text and production, and I learned new vocabulary used to describe aspects of theatre.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Gained experience analyzing and creating all aspects of theater (writing, directing, acting, design)
Learned about theater history, purpose of theater in different time periods, different artistic movements.
Drawing connections between class material and realized theater productions to view theater through a more critical lens.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: All around theatre basics, acting, directing. scenic design, writing etc.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I cultivated a foundational grasp of the theories that underpin theater production. Additionally, I gained a comprehensive understanding of various facets of theater, including directing, playwriting, acting, and design.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the spectrum from presentational to representational theater. I learned about how the forms of Western theater evolved and were broken by playwrights such as Strindberg, Stein, and Sibbles Drury. I practiced visual design skills such as making a mood board.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I thought the cyclical nature of the class was perfect - I enjoyed reading a play, discussing the text in terms of acting and directing, and then discussing design components and past productions. Doing so for each play allowed me to be prepared for what was going to happen in class. The discussions were lively and it really felt like a safe space.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: open discussion was very warm and welcoming; I appreciated conducting an analysis of the play with the class and then comparing/ contrasting our observations with other productions via pictures and video clips;

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed this class. The instructors facilitated our learning by giving us a large variety of assignments to appeal to all types of learners.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Learning was strongly facilitated through class discussion on plays we had read. This was a great motivator in reading the plays. It felt like a book club with plays!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Loved the shared teaching between Prof. Gobert and Prof. Bend. This has been my favorite theater class, TAKE IT (especially if Darren and Tory are teaching together!)

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I thought the pacing was good - we read a good amount of plays but they were spaced out so it wasn’t an overwhelming amount of reading and we could properly digest them. I enjoyed all the assignments because I think they gave a great sample of the different components of production that we learned about. These assignments were relevant to the plays we were reading and they were unique, so I had a lot of fun doing them.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The co-teaching dynamic was really cool, and we got to learn from both Darren and Torry's different areas of expertise. The instructors facilitated an open yet detail-orientated discussion-based environment and seemed to really value the opinions and perspectives of all students. They were generally supportive of students' creative work while still being appropriately critical and pushing us to do better.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: It was a great learning environment and the course really allowed us to explore all these topics. Keep it divided by writing, design etc!!!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course integrated theoretical analysis of plays with hands-on activities in directing, acting, playwriting, and designing, providing a holistic learning experience. Guest speakers enriched our understanding with workshops and insights from the industry, enhancing our practical knowledge. I highly recommend maintaining this approach, as it offers a comprehensive understanding and prepares students for the realities of the theater world.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The small projects in multiple areas of theater were very effective. So were the group discussions, especially when they were centered around a specific photo or question.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The plays were all super interesting and forced me to think in creative ways about how I would like to see them produced.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I enjoyed reading through each of the plays but Eurydice seemed a little disjointed (I also didn't enjoy it as much as the other plays)

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The plays were remarkably stimulating. The best part of this course was reading plays and then making exciting connections about what I had read from classmates and Dr. Gobert's insights on the script. Professor Bend's design lecture was phenomenal; would've loved to hear more about her thoughts on the scripts we'd read in class discussion, from both a design and regular perspective.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Group discussions!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Loved the discussion style learning, felt like a fun book club at times but also a very good practical component between our monologues and final projects.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The assignments were unique, interesting, and fun. The class discussions were well facilitated -  the professors brought up thought provoking questions and the student discussions in response to those questions were intellectually stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The most stimulating part of this class was getting to read different plays and the energetic, thoughtful discussions we had in class. Part of me does wish we got to read a wider variety of plays and discuss them from a more literary standpoint - we had a lot of great material involving plays as a blueprint, but I feel the balance could've shifted to focus more on the text itself and as an artifact.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was good to read all the different plays and the chapters in the book!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class is stimulating due to its emphasis on promoting fruitful discussions, facilitated by in-depth analysis of all aspects of the script. This approach allows for a comprehensive exploration of the text, encouraging critical thinking and deeper engagement with the material.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Exploring the specific components of a script or production that made it work a certain way (e.g. representation in Fairview, amphitheater setup for the Bacchae) was intellectually stimulating.Suggestion for improvement: I would add discussion of more non-white and especially non-European theater -- or change the course description to clearly indicate that the course focuses on Europe/US.* Even a "there is theater in the Global South too but we won't cover it here" would have been good.*The course description advertised "non-European and non-white perspectives," and while this was technically true, it was a bit disappointing to realize that the only non-European play was from the US.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's like theater 101 - you learn about all aspects of theater and what actually goes into a production, from the very beginning of writing a play to the end result and how to get it funded. If you're at all curious about theater and want to learn more about it, this is the course for you!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Would advise you to take it!! It's incredibly fun and interactive. You get to learn so much in this class and partake in activities that help you understand the process behind directing, acting, and set design.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You will enjoy reading the plays, they give you a great survey of different types of scripts for theatre.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it, some people in our class had never done theater before and some were experienced. At any level, you will learn so much!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Great introduction to the world of theatre! It’s fun and intellectually stimulating. Take the assignments seriously, because they are graded seriously. Don’t be afraid to ask the professors for more feedback or help if you’re unsatisfied with your performance in class. Have a ton of fun!!!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed my knowledge of the screenwriting craft while gaining insights into the different techniques to use and avoid using when aiming to tell a story in a well-written and entertaining manner. I also was able to develop my ability to craft and hone in my story ideas.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I honed the skill of delving into unfamiliar topics, conducting thorough research, and crafting compelling stories based on them. The course consistently challenged us to write scripts on subjects we had no personal experience with or prior knowledge of. I gained proficiency in gathering both primary and secondary resources, covering historical contexts, technical details, and cultural backgrounds.Additionally, I mastered the art of writing within tight deadlines. With a weekly writing assignment, I learned to draft quickly and then focus on revisions rather than getting bogged down by details in the initial draft.Lastly, I cultivated the ability to provide constructive feedback to my peers in class. Engaging in script readings and discussions allowed me to refine my communication and comprehension skills while collaborating effectively with my classmates.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Learned how to write a screenplay with correct formatting

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

I also really liked that we got to stick with one idea for the majority of the semester. I don't often get to do that in other classes and it really allowed me to dive deep into a plot line and into the characters I was writing. I'm really proud of the final product.

response_text: This course is very cool. You actually learn how to write a screenplay. It's vulnerable, but so constructive. You learn so much from your peers in this course. By the end of it, writing an 80-page script is time-consuming, but not super challenging.

response_text: Neal is an amazing and knowledgeable person who created such a fun classroom environment. It was really cool to hear my and my classmates' plays read aloud, and Neal gave great feedback to everyone and clearly cared about our writing.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: New work is read aloud every week. There is pressure in this turnaround, there is anxiety, too,—how will my peers react? will people like me?—but in these circumstances you learn. I loved the challenge. Write well or suffer humiliation.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Writing plays was very challenging and was stimulating when I got in a groove, but I often felt out of my depth and wished I had learned some more concrete things in class I could apply to improve my writing process.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's a good class but be prepared to do a lot of writing this semester. A play per week is a huge commitment and you really need to carve out the time or take it in a semester where you have adequate free time, otherwise this class will be very stressful.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- how to structure scenes and acts
- how to develop characters and relationships

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- stage play writing format, conventions, and techniques
- writing practice and increased stamina to write longer pieces

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Writing specifically for the stage. I had experience with other methods of writing, but did not have exposure to theater writing. This course gave me hands-on experience with that. I also became more comfortable sharing my work with others. Finally, I learned how to tell a compelling story from start to finish, and also how to craft scenes based on specific, engaging prompts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed my writing skills, took constructive criticism, and learned how to make an engaging story.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed my ability to write long-form scripts for the stage. I improved my skills at writing believable dialogue. I worked on my story-writing skills based on a given prompt and creatively interpreting set boundaries.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to write for plays! It is a very new style of writing to me and at first I was quite unfamiliar with it, but after writing a couple of scenes, I've gotten the hang of it and learned how fun and flexible this writing style is. It is interesting since you have to also consider stage directions since ultimately you are writing for a play which will be acted on stage, so it is cool to think about how your story and play will appear on stage and think about what stage directions are the most effective to achieve your vision of the play.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to think about injecting drama in playwriting, how to build plot, and how to improve dialogue.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to write for the stage, how to format scripts, how to best use language for dramatic effect.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to channel my creativity through play writing plays.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Working on dramatic writing, how to work towards good absurdism, and minor play literacy

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Learned how to structure a play
- Learned how to write for a stage, rather than just tell a story throughout words, including stage directions, use of the stage, costumes, effects etc
- Learned how to talk about theatre

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked how we did the work outside of class and read them out loud in class. This gave us time to think our pieces through and see them played out visually.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class structure of bringing in written pieces and casting classmates to read them aloud was very helpful, as well as entertaining. In the dramatic writing format, there is nothing like hearing a piece read aloud to help make decisions and elicit feedback. Both giving feedback on others' work as well as getting feedback on my own writing was incredibly helpful in learning how to successfully write for the stage.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Bell gives amazing feedback. He fosters a learning environment in which everyone feels (or seems to feel) comfortable. I love the workshop style of the class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: He would give feedback in and out of the classroom and check in on you.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Implementing in-class readings of student scripts was both an effective tool for figuring out what did and didn't work in a given script, as well as facilitating a fun and engaging environment for all students. Even when your script wasn't being read, it was exciting to read what other students were working on and fostered a flowing marketplace of creative ideas.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I love the assignments! They are so fun and creative! I also love the structure of the class. It is very interactive and super fun and gives students an opportunity to appreciate other student's work!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Perhaps more readings and discussions of what makes professional plays work and how to incorporate these writing strategies into our work. I know this is hard to balance while prioritizing student work, but if there was a 300-level version of the class that was able to delve deeper into technique, that is certainly something I'd love to take. As an introductory class for all ability levels, however, I don't see this as a shortcoming. More so a humble request for more course offerings for students to explore these concepts on a deeper level.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The writing assignments and the reading out-loud of the student's work made it so stimulating!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! A good class to add to overload with. Not much work but it is fun and energizing.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it!! I learned so much about dramatic writing, Professor Bell is a great professor and a great person, and we as a class had so much fun and bonded so much. Another great thing about this class is that by the end you will have a large portfolio of short dramatic works that you can submit to journals, readings, and competitions - I was able to have one of my pieces performed at the Duke Players Playhouse Shorts event and it was an amazing experience.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this class! Or any class with Professor Bell. Because sharing writing is so intimate, you will form great bonds and connections with your classmates and teacher, which is really special. You will gain more practical writing experience and have the opportunity to workshop your pieces with a decent amount of people! Great for anyone interested in writing in the future, or anyone who loves writing/telling stories just for fun :)

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Engage in class and do your work and you should be fine.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you enjoy creative writing, take this class. If you enjoy theater and want to get more experience on the playwright side, take this class. If you have no experience in writing or theater and want a fun and rewarding creative outlet, take this class. Come to class ready to engage with your peers' scripts, but that may not even need to be said because everyone in the class was eager to read each others' scripts. The only possible reason I can fathom that someone wouldn't be satisfied with this class is if they didn't put in any effort; this was not the case of anyone I know who's taken it, but I suppose in the abstract it is theoretically possible. I would STILL encourage that person to take this class because even shy or "too-cool-for-the-arts" students will get a kick out of this class. It is genuinely the most fun class I've taken at Duke.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: TAKE THE CLASS! It's the best!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's a ton of fun! Buy in with the acting and writing and you'll have a great time.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! Hands down my favorite class at Duke.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze movies in terms of incidents and dramatic action, adapting source material to screen and the many ways that can be done, and how to more accurately describe scenes in terms of action and meaning and uncover what the deeper meaning/main purpose is instead of objectively what happened.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
An understanding of dramatic action

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: You learn an approach to screenwriting that emphasizes dramatic principles---understanding your main character's motivation, how to structure a plot around incidents, and three-act structure.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. How to structure a screenplay

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The learning environment was very hands on, where we would often go over movies or literary works together in class to identify the important parts. After you start writing the screenplay, you also have the chance to read it aloud in class and get feedback from everyone, which was helpful.
